PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2 per cent discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 October 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island Preservation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Moreton Island is an invaluable natural resource for Queensland and the world and that mining on Moreton would gravely compromise its unique flora and fauna and its outstanding recreational archaeological and scientific values.

Your petitioners most humbly pray and the Senate in Parliament assembled, should: urge the government to use its proven constitutional powers to halt sand mining on Moreton by supporting the Moreton Island Preservation Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers, about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia. Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
1. Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia.
2. Ban the import of Cobalt-60 and Caesium-137 and Caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products.
3. Ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation (electron beam, x ray etc.).
4. Ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Vessels in Australian Waters

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION: POSTPONEMENT OF DEBATE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the fact that the Government has now postponed debate on the industrial relations legislation. I ask: In the face of united opposition to and condemnation of the industrial relations legislation by the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia, the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry, chambers of commerce, the National Farmers Federation, small business associations and other business and employer organisations, will the Government give an undertaking that this Legislation will be withdrawn and that clauses which place unions above the ordinary laws of the land will be totally deleted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As always in this Government's policy making, it is prepared to consult and receive the views and opinions of various organisations.
—You have done that?

—Yes, we have. Let me make it quite clear that Senator Chaney gave me a list of organisations that expressed objections to the proposed industrial relations legislation. He might have included some trade unions as well. I am certainly not going to give any undertaking that the legislation will be withdrawn; that is not for me to do. However, there will be a further process of consultation about some provisions in the legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney mentioned in his list two groups of which neither the Government nor anybody else in the community took much notice-the Liberal Party and the National Party. In any decisions made by the Government, very little notice was taken of those two bodies-by us or anybody else in the Australian community. They were not a factor in the Government's deliberations.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the reply of the Minister for Resources and Energy to my question on notice No. 1694 regarding the disposal of nuclear waste in Australia, I further ask him: With approximately 1,000 cubic metres of dangerous nuclear waste now in store in Australia-it is buried in every capital city and is increasing at 50 cubic metres a year-has any register been devised between the Commonwealth and State governments to show positively where dange-rous nuclear waste has been buried or otherwise disposed of? If such a register has been esta-blished, what procedures have been established to make certain local, State and Territory authorities are totally informed of any potential danger before allowing building approvals or land development in those areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Science and Technology Council-ASTEC-in its 1984 report to the Government on Australian involvement in the nuclear fuel cycle recommended the creation, among other things, of a registry of radioactive tailings in waste disposal sites in Australia. The Government accepted that recommendation and in the middle of 1985 consultations were commenced with the States and the Northern Territory to determine what information should be recorded and how that registry should operate. It is my understanding that Commonwealth and State officials have now reached agreement on the kinds of details required in relation to each site for the registry, including the precise location and status of the disposal site and the wastes it contains. Information for specific sites is now in the process of being collected for the registry.

ANSWER.PARA: I would expect that local, State and Territory authorities are already aware, at least in general terms, of the whereabouts of contaminated sites. However, the national registry will provide, in a highly accessible form, precise details on indivi-dual sites throughout Australia and, as I have said, precise details on the content of the material they contain. That exercise is a necessary prerequisite to the exercise in establishing a national low to middle order waste disposal faci-lity. As I have indicated previously to the Senate, that continues to be under very active consideration and it is the subject of joint consultation between the Commonwealth and the States with a view to identifying such an acceptable site and, ultimately, for good measure, transferring to it the material presently scattered around Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FIJI: REPRESENTATION AT SOUTH PACIFIC FORUM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Government know whether Fiji will be represented at this week's South Pacific Forum meeting in Western Samoa and, if so, by whom? Does the Government believe that the only appropriate representative of that country would be the democratically elected Prime Minister, Dr Bavadra, or one of his duly appointed Ministers? Does he agree that if Fiji is represented by other than Dr Bavadra, Australian Government participation would amount to de facto recognition of the post-coup arrangements? What does the Government intend to do in those circumstances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been conflicting reports on the likely attendance by Fiji at the Forum. As I was aware of the situation mid-morning-I have not caught up with it since-there is still very considerable uncertainty as to whether Fiji would seek to be represented at all at the Forum and, if so, by whom. Under those circumstances I do not think it is helpful to speculate further as to what the nature, extent or character of that representation might be.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of Senator Durack's question, we as a government agree that the only appropriate representative of Fiji at the Forum would be the properly and duly democratically elected Prime Minister or a representative of his Government-Dr Bavadra or his representative. It is a matter of profound regret that it does not appear likely to be the case that Dr Bavadra will be there, at least in that capacity.

As to the third part of the question, whether Australia would find it appropriate to attend the Forum notwithstanding some purported Fijian official presence, that is essentially a hypothetical question which it would be inappropriate, for reasons I have indicated, to attempt to prejudge. But I draw attention to the fact that it has been normal multilateral meeting practice for parties to be willing to sit around the table notwithstanding the absence of recognition of other parties around the table. So if a decision were made to attend and participate in the Forum notwithstanding some sort of official Fijian presence, that would not in itself imply anything so far as Australia's recognition of the current regime is concerned. We have made it clear, and I do so now again, that we do not recognise the present regime, notwithstanding the figleaf of constitutionality that has been erected around it by virtue of the Governor-General purporting to be, in effect, the sole government of that country, albeit advised by a council of advisers.

It is a very difficult policy question for the Government. One possibility that is being considered in the event that Fiji should turn up at the Forum is for Australia to be physically present but not actually to participate in the Forum meetings as such, thus allowing an opportunity for contact with the relevant countries in the normal array of bilateral meetings and multilateral meetings of the kind that traditionally accompany Forum meetings. There is no determined policy position on this matter. It is a matter of ongoing consideration by the Government. Mr Hayden will, no doubt, want to have a major say in this matter now that he is back in the country, just as he has had a major say in the course of events during his absence. I further mention just for the record that, as has been foreshadowed, I think, in this morning's media, in the event that Australia officially attends the Forum or goes on some other basis, Mr Hayden will accompany the Prime Minister and be there as an extended Australian delegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment advise which company has recently expressed an interest in mining on Moreton Island? Does the Federal Government have any power to prevent such mining from proceeding if the mined material is sold on the Australian market? Does the company have export licences for other mining products? If so, could those licences be amended to be conditional on the company agreeing not to mine on Moreton Island?

—I am advised that the company in question is Associated Minerals Consolidated Ltd. With respect to the second and third parts of the honourable senator's question, the Government is currently studying the powers that might be available to it to prevent mining from proceeding in the event that it is proposed to sell mined material on the Australian market. I am not, therefore, in a position to comment on what action the Government might take if mining for domestic purposes were to take place. The Government's position regarding mineral sand mining on Moreton Island is well known. It firmly opposes it. To disclose prematurely what action the Government may consider taking in the situation described by Senator Colston's question might not-I am sure he will agree-be the most prudent course.

Can the Minister explain whether any correlation might exist between the sudden widening of that hole in 1985 and the much publicised `hole' which was `burnt' in the earth's atmosphere south of Tasmania by a United States space shuttle mission over the Southern Ocean, also in 1985?

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware that media claims that 16- and 17-year-olds may be denied any income support if they cannot find work are causing anxiety in the community? What provision has the Government made for school leavers who cannot find work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of some anxiety in the community due perhaps to a misreading of some of the emphases to be derived from the Treasurer's May economic statement. It is necessary to put the support which the Government intends to give young people in the 16- to 17-year-old age bracket, as they leave the education system and seek employment, in some sort of perspective. It is very important that the Government not merely hand out an unemployment benefit without giving the support which these 16- and 17-year-olds require. Therefore, the emphasis in changing from the unemployment benefit to the job search allowance over the next several months will be on getting young people into jobs. They will be required to attend a Commonwealth Employment Service office each fortnight as part of their job search activities. If they do not find work or a training place within six months they will be recalled to the CES and subjected to a new activity test, which means that they will be required to accept referral to a suitable job, work experience, training program or job search training place. If unsuccessful after 12 months recipients will be provided with more intensive counselling and job experience offers by the CES.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government will allocate $32m in 1987-88 above expenditure already planned and around $63m in 1988-89 to training programs directed primarily at disadvantaged groups. As honourable senators will be aware-perhaps it needs to be re-emphasised and put on the public record-whilst it is true that in January 1988 the unemployment benefit under that title disappears for under 18-year-olds, a job search allowance payable at that current junior unemployment benefit rate with an activity test after six months will be put in place. In March 1988 Austudy-type parental income tests will be applied to current and new recipients of that job search allowance which will be paid at a rate which can reduce to $25 a week depending on parental income.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the proposed introduction of a $2 coin an admission by the Government that Australia's high level of inflation is to continue unchecked? Has this country arrived at a situation where what was once a pound, a respected unit of currency everywhere in the world, is nothing more than small change? Is the Australian public further to be burdened with the weight of extra coins in its pockets? Can the Government take action not to introduce a $2 coin and retain the present $2 note?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time governments of all persuasions have made changes in currency in terms of the way it is minted, printed or whatever. There is no admission by this Government, nor was there by previous governments, of continuing levels of inflation bringing about such a situation. If Senator Bjelke-Petersen wants to look at really high levels of inflation, even though the current level of inflation in this country is too high, she has to go back to 1982 when the Fraser Government was in power. Then she will see how high levels of inflation can be. I would agree with the suggestion that the pound is not worth much any more because the pound was abolished in 1964.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the grave difficulties of our country cousins from Queensland who represent the National Party of Australia in this place is that they are firmly locked into the policies and attitudes of the early 1960s, and perhaps the 1950s, rather than taking account of what is happening in this country today and what ought to be happening. That is one of the very real problems which National Party representation from Queensland brings into Senate and Federal parliamentary debates. If Senator Bjelke-Petersen is really concerned about people being weighted down with the new $2 coins and she finds that a personal difficulty, she can give all the $2 coins she gets to me. I will put them in my pocket and I assure her that I will be quite capable of carrying them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to reports of proposals put forward by the Queensland Government at yesterday's Premiers Conference for further cuts in public expenditure. I ask the Minister: If the standards of Queensland's fiscal discipline over recent years had been extended to the Commonwealth, what would have been the effect on the Commonwealth Budget deficit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Press re-ports in which the Queensland Government called for further expenditure cuts and fiscal discipline. I understand that a booklet was handed out but I have not seen it.
—I will get you a copy.

—I thank the honourable senator. That is very kind of him. However, I understand that it is pretty long on rhetoric and pretty short on detail, which is just the sort of thing one would expect to come out of the Petersen regime. Looking at the record of the Queensland Government as distinct from the rhetoric, we find that in the six years from 1980-81 to 1986-87, Queensland State outlays have grown at 5.8 per cent real which is much faster than any other State and well above the average, almost 80 per cent higher than the average of 3.7 per cent for all States. The 1985-86 financial year, the last complete year, was the year of the really big blowout in Queensland when outlays grew by 9.8 per cent. Yesterday, Premier Petersen was berating the Commonwealth over alleged excessive spending by the Commonwealth but in this financial year, Queensland's Budget shows on-Budget expenditures increasing at 3.7 per cent real-almost a 4 per cent real increase. Of course, Queensland tax receipts, once the appropriate adjustment is made for taxes disguised as railway freights, are the highest of any State as well.

ANSWER.PARA: The Queensland Government publishes no forward estimates of expenditure, a habit that was shared by the former Treasurer, Mr Howard. Of course, there were very good reasons why he did not publish forward estimates of expenditure, particularly in 1983, and they were because he did not want the public to know the truth. He did not want the public to know-indeed he deliberately concealed from the public-the truth about the Budget he had presented in 1982 and what it was leading to in the next financial year. The Queensland Budget do-cuments do not distinguish clearly--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister has picked his words fairly carefully but he is clearly indicating that the Leader of the Opposition did not tell the truth and I think he should be asked to withdraw that statement.
—The Minister said that Mr Howard deliberately misled the public. I ask him, therefore, to withdraw those words.

—Mr President, I withdraw them if you wish me to. I just refer people to what Mr Stone said at the time. In February 1983-it may even have been 1 March-he asked the then Government whether it wanted the forward estimates published. He was very quickly told `No, certainly not', and they were published after the event. But the Queensland Budget documents do not clearly distinguish between financial transactions and other revenues. Because of that it presents what it calls a `balanced' Budget, but it presents insufficient detail to make any realistic assessment of whether or not it is balanced. The overall deficit in Queensland for this financial year is estimated to be $1.1 billion-we cannot be certain of that fact because the Queensland Government conceals information-which is about double the deficit recorded by Queensland in the previous year. Of course, if the Commonwealth Government had followed that practice the Commonwealth deficit in this financial year would be of the order of $10 billion-the sort of deficit that Mr Howard left behind when he was kicked out of office.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence: Are the elements of the Operational Deployment Force on HMAS Tobruk positioned off Suva on active service? If so, are they entitled to all the benefits that active service implies? If they are committed to land operations, what are the rules of engagement, which must have been defined at this stage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure of the technical characterisation of their present status. I would need to check that with the Minister for Defence. I shall do so and respond as soon as I can to the Parliament. If there is anything in Senator MacGibbon's question to suggest that those servicemen embarked on the Tobruk, who by now should have transferred, of course, to other ships in the region-I am just not sure what the status of that transfer operation is; it may not be until later in the week-are doing something more than we have said they are doing, of course it is utterly without foundation. They are there for an essentially military police role-I think that would be the best way of describing it-to assist in any evacuation that might have or still may become necessary of Australian citizens and others from Fiji.

ANSWER.PARA: It was only in the most remote contingency that any such participation in the process was deemed likely by our military planners but, nonetheless, it is part of any good planning exercise that all contingencies, however remote, are taken into account and properly planned for. It is in that particular context that these men have been embarked. It remains, of course, our profound hope that their use in any capacity to assist in an evacuation will not become necessary and our present assessment of the situation is, of course, that that appears less likely with each passing day but there is still a degree of real uncertainty about the situation in Fiji and so long as that uncertainty prevails the contingency plans will stay in force.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I advise the Minister that there was nothing malicious or whatever word he used in my question.
—That would be a precedent.
—I do not want any back chat.
—Order! Senator MacGibbon should ask his supplementary question.

—My supplementary question to the Minister is: Why would there be a need to transfer those troops from the Tobruk to other ships of the Royal Australian Navy? Will he answer my question about the rules of engagement?

—I cannot answer that question any more than I could answer the earlier question about proper characterisation. One is linked with the other and the honourable senator will get a full answer in due course. The reasons why it is proposed to transfer the soldiers in question from the Tobruk is as was set out in the Press release, which manifestly Senator MacGibbon has not read, and that is that the Tobruk is on its way to Apia for the South Pacific Forum conference, where it is a crucial part of the logistics of the conference and, indeed, for the independence celebrations of Western Samoa, which it was originally planned to attend anyway, quite apart from the Forum situation. That is the context in which the Tobruk is steaming to Apia and diverging marginally to Fiji on the way. It is more or less a geographical straight line. If an evacuation contingency had arisen, it is quite probable that, during the period in which the Tobruk was in the area or in which it could be returned to the area, it would have been involved in that process along with the other ships in the region.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of claims that the income testing of family allowances for families with incomes over $50,000 will adversely affect women and will, over time, push many more families and women into the income tested area? Can the Minister say what the Government's response to these claims is?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a Press release put out by Senator Chaney on 21 March 1987 which referred to the issues raised by Senator Crowley. Senator Chaney claimed that the income testing of family allowances will bite into the disposable income of many more middle income families over time, primarily because `while the income test levels might appear high, there has been absolutely no commitment by the Government to index them'. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: In a very short time inflation will push thousands more families into the phase-out zone and the ostensibly reasonable income test will extend its reach by stealth.
In response to that claim, I refer Senator Chaney to page 37 of the May economic statement, where it says:
The threshold-
that is, $50,000 plus additional income disregard for more children-
will be increased annually from January 1989 in accordance with the movement in the CPI between July and June in the previous financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there will be no capital gains tax, uni fees or any of these other problems.

—Senator Chaney, of course, is rabbiting on now, embarrassed by this obvious, or deliberate, fault in his public statement. I suggest to Senator Chaney that he should acquaint himself with the May economic statement before making public statements which condemn government policy and which are based on spurious grounds. The facts are that 200,000 families will be affected by the family allowance decision, the threshold will be indexed, and those families that do lose all or some of their family allowance will be gaining very substantially from the tax cuts, as I set out for the benefit of the Senate last week. The Government has made difficult decisions in the May economic statement, including having high income earners forgo a very small proportion of their incomes so that those in the community who are most in need can gain some additional benefits. The Government's family assistance packages will, of course, address these issues further.

ANSWER.PARA: I think Senator Crowley asked me to remind the Senate of what those tax benefits would be. From memory, I think it is the case that a single income family on $50,000 a year will be something like $69 a week better off from the combined tax cuts. A dual income family, where one yearly income is $30,000 and one is $20,000, will be in the vicinity of $39 a week better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are taking it away from the family allowance.
—Order! Senator Walters, you are persistently interjecting. Will you let the Minister answer the question?
—Thank you, Mr President. Quite clearly, the loss of a few dollars of family allowance is more than adequately compensated for by the combined effect of the tax cuts for those high income families.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Did the Minister, as Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, in conjunction with the Minister for Defence, agree to the dispatch of Australian troops to waters off Fiji? What are the objectives of this deployment? I recognise that he tried to skate around that point in answer to Senator MacGibbon's question; nevertheless, I ask him to state those objectives. Is the Minister satisfied that the strength and back-up of the force is sufficient to achieve the objectives? Were the troops dispatched at the invitation of, or with the concurrence of, Fijian authorities? If so, which authorities were consulted?

—I refer Senator Newman not only to what I said in answer to Senator MacGibbon but also to the Prime Minister's Press statement of 21 May, which sets out in loving and elaborate detail answers to all the questions that Senator Newman has just asked me.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to considerable Press speculation in recent days that the Chief Minister for the Northern Territory has been jumping the gun in relation to his claims that work on the 1,500-kilometre, $610m Alice Springs to Darwin railway is about to begin. In fact, I believe it is suggested that, despite official pronouncements, Japanese involvement in funding the project is non-existent. I ask Senator Gietzelt whether he can provide further information on this mooted project which, of course, could have implications for my State of South Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be obvious to most honourable senators that what the Northern Territory Government does in respect of any proposed Alice Springs-Darwin railway is a matter for that Government alone. If it considers that it is able to organise the funding and financial back-up essential not only to make the construction a success but also to create an economically viable link between those two important centres, that, of course, would be a matter of judgment to be made by the Chief Minister and the Government of the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of sufficient links between those two cities, the Commonwealth Government has contributed substantial funds to complete the Stuart Highway to a good quality bitumen road for its entire route. The Commonwealth Government is of the view that at this stage that is as far as it is able to go with regard to the contribution of funds for the movement of traffic-both goods and passengers-in respect of that portion of our country. The Commonwealth Government is not involved in proposals to construct a rail link. That is a matter of commercial judgment, which is clearly the responsibility of the Northern Territory Government. The Commonwealth Government is of the view that the first class highway meets the needs of transport at this stage, particularly having regard to the economic conditions facing the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to Senator Gareth Evans in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs at the relevant time. Did the Government consider the use of sanctions against the military government in Fiji? Did the Government reject the use of sanctions as inappropriate at this time? Are Australian maritime unions, with the blessing of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, imposing their own sanctions on Fiji? Did the Minister try to have these bans lifted during talks with the ACTU on Sunday? If so, did he succeed? Is it acceptable that the conduct of a key area of our foreign policy should be conducted by the trade union movement rather than by the elected Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government did consider the imposition of economic sanctions in the form of trade embargoes of either a general or a specific kind and it did, as Senator Hamer indicated, reject the appropriateness of those measures at this stage, although, as the Prime Minister has indicated on a number of occasions, those potential sanctions remain on the table for consideration should the situation further deteriorate and should the judgment be made that their effectiveness and utility would be such that in all the circumstances they should be employed. It is the case that the Government has made the judgment, until now anyway, that it is unlikely that broad-ranging or even narrowly targeted economic sanctions would be particularly effective, not least since the types of commodities of which we are talking, conspicuously petroleum products, are readily obtainable from other parts of the globe, and that action would be unlikely to generate any particular stress in the Fijian economy.

ANSWER.PARA: To the extent that stress would be generated, there is always the argument of who one is hurting, and that factor must be taken into account along with many other considerations. The basic consideration that moved the Government-and I have indicated this on a number of occasions-is that the Fijian economy is so close in any event to self-destructing as a result of the events of the past 10 days that any further exercise of this kind would appear to be manifestly unnecessary in terms of placing any further pressure upon people in Fiji to behave in a more reasoned way. That has been particularly obvious in the context of tourism, but it is also becoming rapidly evident in the drying up of other forms of investment and business activity. It is the case that the trade union movement is presently maintaining a number of bans on shipping to Fiji. I was clearly advised last Sunday by senior representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions that those bans have been placed in response to specific requests from the Fijian trade union movement, because of the denial of rights to Fijian trade unions that had been associated with the Rabuka coup and its aftermath.

As well as explaining at some length to the ACTU the Government's position on the sanctions question, I undertook to establish, as quickly as I could through the Government's communication facilities, just what the current state of play was in Fiji so far as continuation of bans on trade union activity was concerned and, in particular, what the situation was so far as the current views, expectations and requests of the Fijian trade union movement were concerned. Some effort has been made to clarify those points, and it would appear that at the moment the situation is rather fluid and there is a prospect-there is a prospect, I put it no higher than that, as matters stood earlier today-that the bans, limitations and restrictions on trade union activity will be completely lifted both legally and in practice and that as a result the key relevant unions in Fiji may well lift the request that is currently operative for such activity to be maintained by Australian unions. If that is so, to that extent that quite major prop, as it were, of the Australian trade union movement's reaction so far may well be removed, and the ACTU might well be expected to respond accordingly.

I do not think it is helpful for me to speculate further as to what the course of events might be. Feelings are obviously, and understandably, running very high in the Australian trade union movement, just as they are in the Australian community as a whole-indeed just about everywhere in the Australian community except, it seems, in the bosom of the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, who has made a conspicuous fool of himself as we all know by his early reaction to the events in Fiji. But apart from him, and I think with the conspicuous exception of him, I think that everyone in this country has reacted with equally forceful indignation to what has been a very unhappy and distressing time and course of events in Fiji and I believe, as does the Government, it is perfectly understandable that the trade union movement should have reacted as it did in response to the specific requests that were put to it by fraternal organisations elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. As I understood the Minister's answer, he said that the Government had-and I agree with it-rejected the use of sanctions at this time. I ask the Minister, as I asked before: Does the Government approve of the unilateral use by the trade union movement of sanctions against a country, such use not being in accordance with the policy of the Government?

—No, the Government does not approve of that, and that point was made perfectly clear to the ACTU. At the same time, the Government expressed its understanding, as I do now, of the trade unions acting as they did, not in the pursuit of some larger policy objective-which is a proper matter for government-but with the specific objective of responding to a fraternal request from a fraternal trade union organisation expressly designed to ensure the restoration of trade union rights. It is in that particular context that I have made the points I have.

—My question, addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, concerns the present shortage of bodily parts for transplants. Will the Minister consider developing a public awareness campaign to encourage more donors to come forward? Could the shortage be eased by donors endorsing the use of any bodily part, as opposed to a specific part? If so, could the campaign encourage such endorsements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Elstob has raised a matter of great concern to him. It is not a matter of simple sentiment to be very moved when one hears, sees on television or reads about a person whose life has been saved because some other member of the community, either while still alive or in anticipation of death, has provided an organ which has had a life saving effect on that person who has perhaps been in an accident or is suffering from some chronic acute illness. Therefore, the question of the donation of bodily parts is something which should be pursued by Australian Health Ministers. I emphasise the word `Ministers' because arrangements for organ donation are seen, in our federal system, as being primarily a matter for the States and for the legislative framework that each State establishes. I know that the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council is currently looking at various aspects of donor organ acquisition with a view to improving existing arrangements and achieving greater rationalisation of activity. I understand that matters being addressed in that Advisory Council include not only the number of potential donors, but also the various organisational, educative and legislative aspects.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as Senator Elstob is concerned that there should be a public awareness program, clearly in the educative aspects of the questions being addressed by the Advisory Council, the question of a general awareness program perhaps needs more emphasis than it may be receiving at the moment. Certainly, I will not only take steps to ensure that that matter is brought to the attention of the Council, but also seek to ascertain whether the Council is looking at the question of permitting the donation of body parts in general-which is the sense of Senator Elstob's question-rather than potential donors having to specify the particular organs they wish to donate in the event of death.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Fo-reign Affairs. I remind him of Mr Hayden's answer to the House of Representatives on 28 April, when he said that the Libyan People's Bureau would not be closed and that that decision had been made on grounds which were `sound' and which `continue to be sound'. What specific things occurred between 28 April, when there were no grounds for closing the Bureau, and 19 May when the Prime Minister announced that the Bureau would be closed-because it had `intruded into our domestic affairs, causing dissensions and confrontation between communities'-to show that this was causing deep concern and that it was `serving to facilitate Libyan de-stabilising activities'? With respect to each of these things which occurred between the two dates I have mentioned, when did each of them first come to the notice of the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —These questions are not matters of black and white and are not circumstances where there were no grounds for doing something at one time and then a number of grounds for doing something at a later stage. Essentially it is a continuum of evidence that accumulates over time and there comes a point at which the balance of that evidence tips the Government over in the direction of making a particular decision which, until that point, it is not minded to make. A number of things occurred during the period to which Senator Jessop referred which tipped the balance in favour of the Government's making the decision that it eventually made last week.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me mention some of those matters. First, there was the further evidence not only of the nature of Mr Mansell's visit to Tripoli but also of the subsequent course of action that he proposed to embark upon as a result of that visit in the way in which he was manifestly intending to use the Libyan connection as a continuing destabilising consideration in his conduct, and that of a number of like-minded people, of Aboriginal affairs in this country. Over this period there was the emergence to prominence of the abominable Mr Pash and his Matabah office in Melbourne which had made it perfectly clear that the extent to which the LPB in Canberra was exercising, as has been claimed in some quarters, some moderating influence on the conduct of Libyan Government activities in Australia, that moderating influence was clearly incapable of stopping the establishment of the Matabah office through this Australian citizen to whom I have already referred in this place in previous answers and about whom I do not find it necessary to say anything more.

There was further evidence of destabilising activity in a number of forms by the Libyan Government through its various arms and agencies using, to some extent one can presume, the Canberra LPB as the channel of communication in various places around the Pacific. There was the consideration of the coup in Fiji, not because of any evidence to link anything that happened in Fiji with Libya but because it was a further demonstration of the fact that the troubled waters in the Pacific in which the Libyans are all too obviously anxious to fish were even more troubled than anyone had previously contemplated. There was the further consideration of an imminent meeting not only of the South Pacific Forum but also, preceding that meeting, the key group-the spearhead group, so called-of the Melanesian Prime Ministers from the Solomons, Vanuatu and Papua New Guinea.

It was desired to make the point that Australia was willing to match its expressions of concern about Libyan activity in the Pacific with action of the highest form that we could reasonably adopt in our domestic environment. There was the further consideration of the visit to the region during this period of the senior Department of Foreign Affairs officer, Mr Sadleir, which was substantially completed by the time the Government made the decision. He reported, among other things, that the double standard question was continuing to arise, whether justified or not, around the Pacific and that it was difficult for Australia to make the points about dangers of Libyan activity in the Pacific as forcefully as it might want to while still retaining a formal diplomatic office in Canberra, albeit one that was established at a much earlier date and one that, when looked at purely in terms of its own activities, was not doing anything particularly outrageous, as Mr Hayden said.

All those considerations, which between them, I think, amount to a fairly formidable list, not only were squarely relevant to the justice of the case for treating the LPB as we did but also go quite explicitly to the question of timing, to which Senator Jessop's question expressly referred. Let us hear no more of that particular canard.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LIBERAL PARTY OF AUSTRALIA: TAXATION POLICY DOCUMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to a report in today's Melbourne Herald relating to a leak of the taxation policy document of the Liberal Party of Australia? Does the Government propose to implement these measures? What would be the implications for government policy if they were implemented?

—I have seen the report in today's Melbourne Herald. From that report it is not possible to be precise about all the details. However, I assume that the draft document was deliberately leaked-a toe in the water exercise by the Opposition to see whether it could con the public into believing that what it was proposing was credible. It is proposing essentially that just about everyone will have a big increase in his real after tax income because he will get a big tax cut. It is not telling us, of course, that there will be a huge and commensurate increase in the deficit because of it. It is clear that the draft document is not only failing to address the real economic problems of this country but also actually inciting the country to go in the wrong direction because it is fostering and fanning the belief that real average living standards can be improved. There is only one way that that can happen in the short term, and that is if foreign debt were to be accumulated at an accelerating rate, with dire consequences for the future, of course. Indeed, that is the sort of irresponsible policy that I would expect the present Opposition to put forward. Quite clearly, this is the toe in the water exercise to see whether the electorate is gullible enough to be conned into swallowing the line and the bait the Liberal Party is throwing out to it.
—Tell us what this is all about, please.

—What it is all about, when one tacks it on to all of the other promises of the Liberal Party, is blowing out the deficit to about $16 billion. The document, in what it puts up, admits that there would be a net cost to revenue of $5.7 billion plus, of course, the losses to revenue from repealing the substantiation legislation, repealing the capital gains tax, repealing the quarantining of negative gearing provisions, repealing the fringe benefits tax, and all of those other irresponsible promises which this ragtag and bobtail of an Opposition has trickled out over the last couple of years. The net effect of all of that would be to blow out the deficit to about $16 billion a year, which is even more than John Howard left behind him when he was ignominiously kicked out of office.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MEDICARE REBATE FOR CONSULTANT PHYSICIAN CONSULTATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health with a declaration of interest; namely, that I was, until I became a senator, a consultant physician in private practice. I draw to the attention of the Minister the item in the May mini-Budget which will limit rebates at consultant level to patients seeing consultant physicians to one initial and two subsequent consultations. I ask the Minister: What social goal is the Government pursuing with this measure? Is it the intention of the Government that patients with, say, chronic ulcerative colitis, chronic kidney failure, resistant heart failure or progressive crippling muscle diseases should be able to get consultant level rebates for only three visits? Is it the policy of this Government to shift the economic burden for sickness, especially sickness of this chronic kind, to the sufferers; that is, the sick and vulnerable in society?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen claims in various organs of the media along the lines contained in Senator Baume's question. The Government does not believe that the changes in relation to consultant physician arrangements in the May economic statement will have a devastating impact on the chronically ill, as is suggested. Senator Baume would know that the original role of a consultant physician was to provide an opinion, with ongoing management of the patient being undertaken by the referring practitioner. That was the relationship between the general practitioner and the consultant physician. Yet one finds that 17 per cent of referrals between 1985 and the end of December 1986 resulted in consultant physicians providing four or more services in the one episode, and that is what has led to the changes that have been announced in the May economic statement.

ANSWER.PARA: Fees at the consultant rate will be limited from 1 August to an initial consultation and two follow up visits for any particular episode. All services will continue to attract benefits but, after the first three consultations, at an appropriately lower rate. There is no justification for consultant physicians to abandon patients requiring ongoing treatment and to force them to attend public hospital clinics. It is stated in my brief that on Thursday, 21 May officers of the Department of Health had detailed discussions with representatives of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians to clarify misunderstandings. I understand that discussions with the College on the implementation of the changes will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Education advise the Senate whether the recent decision by the Queensland Minister for Education to disband the Queensland New Schools Committee and to push ahead with wide-ranging amendments to the Queensland Education Act will affect Commonwealth-State co-operation in education in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question is yes. I have been disturbed by two recent decisions taken by the Queensland Minister: One-Senator Robertson referred to it in his question-was to disband the Queensland New Schools Committee and the other was to push ahead with wide-ranging amendments to the Queensland Education Act. Both of these decisions have been taken without any consultation with the Commonwealth or with the schools and groups which will be adversely affected. Both reflect a unilateral, disruptive, grandstanding, wrecking way of doing business which is inimical to the spirit of Commonwealth-State co-operation.

ANSWER.PARA: By disbanding the Queensland New Schools Committee the Queensland Minister has removed an essential source of expert advice on the establishment of new non-government schools in Queensland. Queensland Catholic and independent schools will suffer directly from this decision. The Commonwealth is trying to organise alternative machinery for dealing with the new schools applications, but the Queensland Minister has made the job needlessly cumbersome and time-consuming. Only the Catholic and independent schools will be affected. I would have hoped that the Queensland Minister would have taken more account of their needs and rights.

The changes to the Queensland Education Act are another blatant State government grab for power. They ride roughshod over the interests and concerns of the Catholic school sector, of Queensland independent schools and of the Commonwealth. We have always insisted that national objectives and priorities be pursued in Queensland, as in other States, and that the Commonwealth be able to account fully for money spent in Queensland. We will continue to do so, despite the niggardly attempts by the State Government to claim credit for what we have done and to disrupt the established machinery for consultation between the Commonwealth and the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I refer to some of the education decisions announced in the May Budget statement. Given the Government's higher education cuts of $12m this year and $24m next year and the inflexible nature of the Government's higher education policy, does the Minister agree that the meagre growth of some 3,000 places in higher education this year will be reduced to no growth at all for the 1988-90 triennium? Similarly, I refer to the $30m cuts for the technical and further education sector next year, $45m cuts the year after and the consequent reductions to come in the numbers of TAFE students. Is it not true that the Minister has no remedy for the report by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals on unmet student demand released yesterday, which shows that between 13,000 and 20,000 Australians, net, have been locked out of higher education already this year? To take my own State as a typical example, how can the Minister justify the fact that more than one in four South Australians have been turned away from higher education this year? Finally, I ask: What are the Minister's precise estimates for the reductions in students numbers next year in universities, colleges of advanced education and TAFE institutions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague has asked a gaggle of questions but I will try to give information in response as concisely as I can to the Senate. The May economic statement's reduction of one per cent of funding for higher education institutions, amounting to $12m in the financial year, will not be achieved by reducing places, to answer the last part of Senator Teague's question. It will be achieved by increased efficiency in areas such as administration within the institutions. Nor is the decision inflexible in the sense that not each institution will have to achieve a precise one per cent reduction, but, rather, the $12m saving will be gained from the sector. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission is currently considering ways in which the cut can be spread fairly throughout the sector. Some institutions are more able to achieve efficiencies than others. Some have already achieved greatly improved efficiencies and ought not to be disadvantaged for having done so. So there is flexibility in the way in which that $12m financial year saving will be achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the TAFE cut, I point out that there was a $30m reduction from the fees reimbursement element of the Commonwealth's TAFE funding. As was pointed out in the review of TAFE funding, that $100m fee reimbursement grant did not necessarily flow into the State systems. It went to State governments for use as they saw fit. However, most of the $32m of new money which Mr Willis has for spending in the training area will flow directly into TAFE institutions. So TAFE institutions should have expanded Commonwealth resources coming into them.

The question of unmet demand for higher education has been raised by Senator Teague. The Vice-Chancellors Committee has estimated that between 13,000 and 20,000 applications were not able to be met, although in discussions with CTEC I have formed the view that the real figure is closer to 13,000 than it is to 20,000; but 20,000 would be the outside figure. Senator Teague must bear in mind that one of the reasons why the true figure would be closer to the lower rather than the upper end of the range is that both New South Wales and Queensland use very broad definitions of eligibility in estimating the numbers of eligible applicants who have missed out on a place. For example, this year Queensland has deemed eligible for admission to higher education courses all higher school certificate holders whereas in 1986 it deemed only the top 60 per cent of applicants eligible. So quite clearly, amongst those unsuccessful applicants were students at the very bottom of the range of HSC marks who may not have had the capacity to complete a course successfully. Of course, that is not the case for all those students but it needs to be borne in mind. Unmet demand is calculated on the basis of an individual student's identification of the course for which he or she wishes to apply. Consequently, there are students who did not get the place of their choice and who would have been successful had they nominated other courses.

There is some spare capacity in our institutions. CTEC advises that some 10 institutions appear to have student loads below their planning ranges in teacher education, nursing, some applied sciences and post-experience teacher education. But all that said, certainly there is the problem of unmet demand. Volume 1 of CTEC's report has now been made available to the Government and it addresses ways that unmet demand can be overcome. We will be considering this advice in the Budget context, and I believe there will be a further growth in the number of higher education places in the next triennium. In conclusion, I remind Senator Teague and other honourable senators that since we have been in government we have created some extra 40,000 places in the same time in which the Fraser Government created only 8,000 places. I also remind honourable senators that as far as we know Liberal Party policy still states that any new places in higher education are to be created through the payment of full cost fees by students.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to that part of my question that referred to 13,000 to 20,000 being the net unmet demand. The actual gross figure is 44,739 for individual students being turned away. I refer to the reference I made to my State of South Australia where for the first time more than one in four students have been turned away already this year from enrolment, and that is without the cuts. The Minister has not given any indication of a remedy for that situation. I put that to the Minister.

—I simply repeat that the figure of 13,000 to 20,000 is just an estimate. It includes students who had only one choice, and who could have achieved other places. There are places still available in some South Australian institutions.
—Order! I point out to honourable senators that some of the questions being asked from both sides are approaching the length where they ought to be put on notice.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make the Government's response to the inquiry into the hospitality industry report by the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, incorporate the statement in Hansard and move a motion relating to the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

For the information of honourable senators, I report on the action taken by the Government to implement the recommendations arising from the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory hospitality industry.
The Committee was asked to inquire into the ACT hospitality industry because of its importance to the development of the local economy, and to identify problems affecting that development.

The ACT economy is heavily reliant upon the public sector. The private sector is almost entirely dependent upon government expenditure and the demands for goods and services from the local community. It is therefore vulnerable to changes in the local level of economic activity. Development of the tourism and hospitality industry will provide an important diversification of the local economic base. This is particularly important as the local economy feels the effect of a slowdown in construction activities in 1988-89 and beyond.

The Committee's terms of reference were to require into and report on the state of the hospitality industry, its capacity to meet demand, prospects for its future, and the desirability and extent of government regulation of and involvement in the industry. Particular emphasis was placed on employment awards and practices, training arrangements, the health of the industry, and measures that would enhance the growth of the industry in Canberra.

The inquiry received strong industry support. The Committee received 13 submissions from hospitality industry organisations, government departments, unions and other agencies. Forty-one witnesses appeared at three public hearings.
In preparing the Government's response, wide consultation was undertaken between interested departments and agencies and the unions.
The Government has already taken action on a number of major recommendations, and these are described in detail in the attached report.

The establishment of the new Canberra Development Board recommended by the Committee was announced in April 1987. The Board will provide a strong forum to address not only hospitality industry issues but also broader economic development issues in the ACT. It subsumes the functions of the Canberra Tourist Bureau and the former Canberra Development Board. The Board will be provided with support services from the Department of Territories and is in a form which will enable it to act quickly and more flexibly in response to economic and industry circumstances. A national institutions program for the promotion of Canberra during 1988 will be developed before the end of 1987 under the guidance of a high-level industry-government committee.

A strategic development plan for the ACT is under preparation by the Canberra Development Board. The National Capital Development Commission has commenced preparation of a tourism plan as input into this broader strategy plan.

The Government has also taken action on recommendations relating to employment and vocational training programs. I have asked my colleagues the Ministers for Education and employment and Industrial Relations to accord a very high priority to those recommendations involving their portfolios.

A number of programs addressing the needs of particular groups in the ACT, such as young people and the long term unemployed, have been established by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Work placements in the hospitality industry will be the highest priority for the disbursement of funds under the adult training program in the ACT during 1987.

A model for group apprenticeship courses has been developed by the ACT Tourism Training Committee which will be implemented with industry support. Similarly, a program for pre-employment courses has been developed, and funding of industry-initiated courses is available from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.

The possibility of developing a short course for restaurateurs is being addressed by the Minister for Education through the Office of ACT Further Education. The Industry Training Committee is adapting a New South Wales course model and my Department is assisting through the ACT Small Business Bureau.

This Government supports the development of incentives to encourage employers to employ and train juniors, but in respect of recommendation 20 (in relation to the waiving of payroll tax), believes that avenues other than payroll tax exemption for juniors should also be explored. The Government is reluctant to support a recommendation which would confer upon the ACT a taxation advantage not enjoyed elsewhere.
Other industry reforms suggested by the Committee are commended.

This Government regards the diversification of the ACT employment base as an important objective for the economic future of the Territory. The hospitality industry presents significant and positive development options for the ACT.

The timely report of the Joint Committee highlights issues of major concern within the industry, and its recommendations represent a major step towards the recognition of the industry's employment potential. This Government is committed to the enhancement of career prospects for young people and the long term unemployed, and the Committee's recommendations relating to vocational training for these groups are particularly encouraging.

I am heartened by the action already in hand to implement the recommendations. In particular, the establishment of the Canberra Development Board will ensure that the needs of the industry are addressed in a systematic and comprehensive manner. I am confident that a co-ordinated approach to hospitality issues will facilitate a significant contribution to the ACT economy.
I commend this paper to honourable senators and the attached report on the implementation status of the Joint Committee's recommendations.
ATTACHMENT
INQUIRY INTO THE HOSPITALITY INDUSTRY IMPLEMENTATION STATUS OF JPC RECOMMENDATIONS
Following is a detailed accounting of the implementation status of each of the Committee's twenty-two applications:
Recommendation 1

The Committee recommends that the Federal Government recognise the importance of Canberra as the National Capital and that with the opening of the new Parliament House as part of the Bicentennial celebrations take responsibility for developing early marketing strategies to promote Canberra's role in 1988.

(a) A National Institutions Program should be developed before the end of 1987. I have written to the Ministers responsible for the relevant National Institutions to secure their support for the concept and for a National Institutions promotional program for the next three years. This will be an ongoing program which needs to be set in place during 1987/88 in order to have effect beyond the Bicentennial year.

(b) Officers of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet are planning the opening ceremony for the New Parliament House. Steps are being taken to maximise the tourist opportunities provided by this event and to link them with the overall ACT tourism strategy.
(c) The Bicentennial travelling exhibition will provide a Canberra focus for regional tourism.
(d) Future uses for the provisional Parliament House are the subject of deliberations by an Inter-Departmental Committee. Tourism options are among those being canvassed.

(e) The National Capital Development Commission is preparing a new promotional exhibition at the Regatta Point Planning Exhibition focusing on the Bicentennial theme and the future of Canberra. The exhibition will include new audio-visual and display material.

(f) Another proposal currently being considered is the staging of a high-quality photographic exhibition in 1988 which will tell the story of the evolution, present and future of the National Capital. There is potential scope for arranging that the exhibition be held in major Australian cities as part of Canberra's contribution to the Bicentennial celebrations.
Recommendation 2

The Committee recommends that an ACT Development Board incorporating the present Canberra Tourist Bureau and the Canberra Development Board be established to promote, develop and provide economic assistance to tourism and hospitality in the ACT. This body should be established independently of the Department of Territories and have sufficient authority to react to changing needs and provide immediate assistance when required and have direct access to the Minister.

(a) A new Canberra Development Board has been ministerially appointed. It represents a range of economic, community and educational interests, and comprises a Chairman (Mr Fulton Muir) and 10 other members. I have determined
(i) a charter for the new Board and its committees;
(ii) the composition of membership of the new Board and committees; and
(iii) the need to better co-ordinate tourism, commercial and industrial development activities in Canberra.
Recommendation 3

The Committee recommends that the NCDC, in consultation with representatives of the tourist and hospitality industry, should prepare a tourist development plan for the ACT aimed at achieving positive development of the plan from 1988 onwards.

(a) The Government supports this recommendation but the preparation of a Tourist Development Plan by the National Capital Development Commission needs to be considered as one component of a larger Strategic Development Plan for Canberra. Planning for tourism growth must be addressed within the context of an overall strategic development policy which combines all sectors of development activity and city management. This strategic overview will be co-ordinated by the Canberra Development Board with input from the National Capital Development Commission and the Department of Territories.

(b) The National Capital Development Commission has engaged a consultant to analyse current and future trends in tourism, identify opportunities for the ACT and the actions required to realise these opportunities. The consultant's study due in June will provide the basis for industry discussion and the preparation of a Tourist Development Plan Report in August.

(c) This Report to be prepared by the National Capital Development Commission will form the basis for discussion between representatives of the tourist and hospitality industries in order that some positive results be achieved before the end of the year. The Report will provide input into the broader Strategic Development Plan to be prepared by the Canberra Development Board.
Recommendation 4

The Committee recommends the development of more low-cost visitor accommodation in the ACT by the immediate release of land for low-cost accommodation and the promotion of low-cost accommodation options by the ACT Development Board. The Committee further recommends that the National Capital Development Commission give greater encouragement to developers to provide more camping sites in the ACT.

(a) Substantial progress has already been made in the provision of low-cost visitor accommodation in the ACT. Through the Strategic Plan outlined above the full range of accommodation plans for the ACT will be further addressed, particularly as they relate to the tourism infrastructure in Civic.

(b) Beyond Central Canberra, a number of initiatives are being taken by the Department of Territories and the National Capital Development Commission during the next twelve months. Sites have been identified by NCDC at Gold Creek and North Watson. The Gold Creek site, which forms part of the Commission's planning proposals for the development of Gungahlin, will provide opportunities for motel and camping site developments. The Commission will be seeking public comment on the Gold Creek development as part of public consultation on the Gungahlin draft Policy and Development Plan to be released in a few months.

(c) Opportunities for low-cost visitor accommodation have also been identified in the North Watson area incorporating several motel/caravan/camping sites. Sites are expected to be made available by mid-1987.

(d) NCDC has also identified a number of sites for camping grounds within the rural National Capital Open Space System. The sites identified are at Woods Reserve (on the Corin Road), Riverview (on the Naas Road south of Cuppacumbalong), the Molonglo Gorge, Sherwood Forest (north-west of the Cotter) and at the Stromlo Pine Forest.

(e) In identifying these sites the Commission recognises the need for a range of low cost accommodation to meet different demands including lightweight tenting, heavyweight camping, group camping, campervans, caravans and cabins.

(f) NCDC is currently carrying out preliminary landscaping at Woods Reserve and Riverview camping sites. It is proposed that the other sites be released in stages with Woods Reserve and Sherwood Forest in about three years and Riverview in about five to eight years. Consideration is being given to the need for staging of a site at Stromlo Forest.
Recommendation 5

The Committee recommends that a short course be made available to provide assistance to prospective restaurateurs. The Committee regards the Industry Training Committee (ITC) as the most likely authority to conduct such a course but acknowledges that once the nature and resources of the Hospitality Industry Management Committee become clear, that body may emerge as the most appropriate provider of such training.

(a) Training for restaurateurs is considered a high priority task. I have written to my colleague the Minister for Education in order to secure an appropriate course through the Canberra College of TAFE.

(b) In addition the ITC has access to an appropriate course for restaurateurs which has been developed in New South Wales in conjunction with the liquor licensing authority, and can be readily adapted for ACT purposes.
(c) Further, the ACT Small Business Bureau is investigating the possibility of developing a training course for restaurateurs during 1987.
Recommendation 6

The Committee recommends that public health ordinances in the Australian Capital Territory be amended to bring penalties for breaches of the ordinance into line with those in the comparable New South Wales legislation.

(a) This recommendation is supported. Although the penalties in New South Wales are not necessarily appropriate for the Australian Capital Territory, legislation is being prepared which will significantly increase penalties in relation to the handling of food, so that parity with the States is maintained.
(b) This has a high priority within the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority, and should be implemented in the first quarter of 1988.
Recommendation 7
Further, it recommends that the Gaming and Liquor Authority be provided with the necessary resources to conduct adequate inspections of licensed premises.

(a) The thrust underlying this recommendation is supported. The principal impediment to the conducting of adequate inspections has been identified and will shortly be resolved. The Liquor Ordinance 1975 is being amended to streamline the prosecution procedures in relation to underage drinking offences (present procedures are particularly time-consuming). This will enable Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority staff to divert more time and resources to the routine inspection of licensed premises.
Recommendation 8

The Committee recommends that extensions to the School of Catering Studies at Canberra College of TAFE be built as a matter of urgency. To this end it will be necessary for TAFE to accord the highest priority to the project within its building program and also for the NCDC to allocate this the highest priority.

(a) The NCDC on behalf of the Office of the Australian Capital Territory Further Education is undertaking design work on the provision of accommodation for the School of Catering Studies and the Department of Meat and Allied Trades at the Canberra College of TAFE. The building is proposed to be located to the east of the existing College buildings. Design studies are currently being carried out and subject to funding in the budget context it is envisaged that tenders will be called in early 1988.

(b) The total project incorporates two new kitchens, training bars and service areas, guest lounge, restaurant and liquor service areas, office and reception area, lecture facilities and student and support staff areas. Extensions proposed for the Butchery include new meat cutting areas, coolrooms, meat processing areas, classrooms, staff amenities and offices.
Recommendation 9

The Committee supports any College initiative to extend the utilisation of available facilities and recommends that staff levels be increased and specifically allocated to the Food School to allow full utilisation of these facilities outside hours of present operation to include evening classes.
(a) I have written to the Minister for Education to ensure that the provision of appropriate resources be accorded a high priority.

(b) In addition, it may be possible to increase the capacity of existing facilities at Canberra College of TAFE in the short term through variation of the length and nature of the traditional period in which daily tuition is provided, or through variation to the academic year.

(c) With the introduction of the new Associate Diploma in Business (Hospitality) the numbers of Dining Room Service, Liquor Service and Practice of Catering subjects have doubled between 1986 and 1987.

(d) A new group of trainees (Waiting) commenced in February 1987, increasing numbers to twenty-five, and the implementation of traineeships for Front Office Reception (Hospitality) is expected to commence in the second semester 1987. Consonant staffing resources have been provided for these new training programs.
Recommendation 10

The Committee recommends that the Canberra College of TAFE and the Industry Training Committee investigate the possibility of seconding institutional kitchens on a part-time, short-term basis to assist in staff training and that a comprehensive search for kitchen facilities suitable and available for short-term training be made.

(a) The Industry Training Committee has and will continue to seek access to institutional and other industry kitchens/facilities for training purposes. Private sector facilities are used by the Industry Training Committee to conduct short training courses (on a contract basis) under the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations Adult Training Program and other industry-initiated training. However, commercial kitchens are generally unsuitable for training. For example, the commercial kitchen at Canberry Fair is available for five months of the year when the establishment is closed for the season, but the facilities are small and best suited to a teacher/student ratio of one to five.
Recommendation 11

The Committee recommends that the Department of Territories and the ACT Schools Authority within existing resources promote awareness of the hospitality industry through the provision of information in secondary schools in the ACT, reporting back to the Committee about the means by which this will be achieved, and the inclusion in the Australian Traineeship Scheme of both occupation-specific courses to address immediate skill needs and courses offering broader-based training.

(a) Action to address this need was initiated late in 1986. The Industry Training Committee organised an information session on the hospitality industry for all ACT and Queanbeyan Careers Co-ordinators in November 1986. This session was well attended by Schools Authority, Tourist Bureau and Departmental personnel.

(b) Three classes in Dining Room Service are to be offered in 1987 to Hawker College students as an introduction to the hospitality industry. The ACT Schools Authority is to provide staff hours with other costs for technical staff, linen and foodstuffs costing $3,000 per annum. In addition the Canberra Tourist Bureau is sponsoring a Young Achievers Company through tourism education foci at Dickson and Copland Colleges.

(c) The Aboriginal Trainee Tourist Officer Program has been piloted through the Canberra Tourist Bureau. The Program, which provides comprehensive training in all aspects of the tourist industry for young Aboriginal and Islander participants commenced on 3 November 1986.
(d) The ACT has also contributed $20,000 towards a national tourism education campaign through the Tourist Ministers' Council.

(e) The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations provides a number of resources for use by ACT schools. As part of national policy the Commonwealth Employment Service Schools Program utilises CES Youth Officers, the Careers Reference Centre, and industry-specific information resources including two videos covering Tourism and Careers In Food, and additional written and audio-visual information on fifteen to twenty hospitality careers.

(f) The objectives of the Australian Traineeship System are to provide relevant and accredited training to young people which will extend their employment prospects within industry. A prerequisite to receive Commonwealth assistance is that a traineeship offer both occupationally-specific and broad-based industry training.
