The speech read as follows-

This Bill continues the practice of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sittings of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making a large number of non-contentious amendments to legislation not otherwise being amended.

Some of the amendments made by this Bill tidy up, correct and update existing legislation. Other amendments are of minor policy significance or are matters of routine administration. None of the amendments made by the Bill has any significant financial impact.

Many of the proposed amendments will be self-evident or sufficiently explained by the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to addressing the more noteworthy changes included in this Bill.
Anglo-Australian Telescope Agreement Act 1970

The Act currently restricts the functions of the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board to those specified in the agreement annexed to the Act. The United Kingdom and Australian governments have now agreed that it is desirable for the Board to assume from the United Kingdom authorities responsibility for the future management of some additional facilities already in place at Siding Spring. The amendments will enable the Board to undertake other functions as prescribed by regulations.
Audit Act 1901

The amendments proposed in this Bill are aimed at improving the efficiency of the Commonwealth's financial administration and allowing the Auditor-General discretion in reporting minor breaches of legislation.

From the point of view of financial administration, one amendment will simplify the processes by which funds that have already been appropriated by law are subsequently distributed to departments and will save administrative effort. Financial administration will also be improved by another amendment to enable the Minister for Finance to approve methods of performing accounting functions which do not involve written signatures.

The amendments will ensure that departments report to Parliament on their special operations-a requirement which has not existed previously. The Auditor-General will also be given some discretion on which matters are included in his reports.

The Auditor-General, when so requested by the Minister, will be able to audit the financial statements of bodies such as incorporated companies controlled by the Commonwealth. Currently there is doubt whether the Act permits such an audit, as the existing provision refers to the audit of accounts and records only.

Other amendments will enable regulations to be made to re-establish a policy, adopted by previous governments and arising directly from the policy of self-insurance, that the liability of Commonwealth drivers for the cost of replacing or repairing damaged vehicles should be the same as for a driver in the private sector who is covered by motor vehicle insurance.
Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Act 1962

The Act establishes the Australian Capital Territory Authority consisting of 3 members, including one elected by the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly which has been abolished. In order to provide the Authority with a full membership, the amendments empower the Governor-General to appoint a member to the Authority for a maximum term of 3 years in lieu of the former House of Assembly nominee.
Australian Citizenship Act 1948: Migration Act 1958

The amendments remove from the Migration Act all references to `return endorsements'. A return endorsement gives authority to a non-Australian citizen who is a resident of Australia to return to Australia after a trip overseas. However, since 1 January 1987, return endorsements have been replaced by `resident return visas', and the provisions in the Migration Act relating to return endorsements are no longer required. The amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act are consequential upon this change.
Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984

The amendments will enable automotive companies not incorporated in Australia to be eligible to participate in the motor vehicles and components development grants scheme. The amendments would ensure that the original intent of the scheme was maintained by providing continued access to grant funding to all 5 local motor vehicle manufacturers including Holden's Motor Company which, as a result of the restructuring last year of General Motors-Holden's Ltd, is a United States subsidiary.
Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act 1984

The amendments will modify 2 aspects of the Bass Strait freight adjustment scheme. They will specify that funds are to be disbursed on the basis of crude oil ownership at the refinery gate. This will promote maximum flexibility for refiners by allowing them to arrange between themselves exchanges of crude oil in order to minimise costs.

The amendments also provide for a refund of the refiners' contributions to the trust fund in respect of Bass Strait crude oil purchased at import parity prices and subsequently exported by them. Refiners will thus be treated in the same way as Bass Strait producers under the Act.
Commonwealth Prisoners Act 1967

Since 1983, courts in New South Wales are required to set non-probation periods, not non-parole periods, when imposing sentences of 3 years or less. The amendments will ensure that courts in that State may fix non-probation periods for Federal offenders and that these offenders may continue to be released on parole under the Act.

Where a parolee is sentenced to a further term of imprisonment in a State or Territory other than the one in which he was released on parole, the parole order is automatically revoked. The amendments will enable the Attorney-General to request the issue of a warrant to enable such a person also to serve the balance of his first sentence in the place of this second sentence, instead of his having to go back to the State or Territory in which he received that first sentence.
Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981

The amendments will provide for a new conciliation and caution procedure for resolution of minor complaints against AFP members. They will also introduce greater flexibility in the Commonwealth Ombudsman's options after he receives a report on the investigation of a complaint. The amendments have been developed, in the light of operational experience, jointly by the AFP and the Ombudsman, in consultation with the AFP Association.
Crimes Act 1914: Removal of Prisoners (Australian Capital Territory) Act 1968: Removal of Prisoners (Territories) Act 1923

One amendment of the Crimes Act will ensure that the offences of disclosure of information, falsification of books or records, false returns or certificates by Commonwealth officers and impersonation of a Commonwealth officer extend to cover persons who perform services for or on behalf of the Commonwealth, a Territory or public authority.

At common law, it has been held that where a prisoner escapes while serving a term of imprisonment he cannot be detained under the sentence once the term has expired. Amendments to the Crimes Act and the Removal of Prisoners (Territories) Act will make it clear that sentences of Federal offenders and Territory offenders respectively will cease to run for the period they are at large.

Where a prisoner is accidentally released, for example, by the prison authorities before he is due to be released, he cannot be required to return to prison and serve the balance of his term because, at common law, the warrant under which he was committed to prison is spent. The amendments to the 3 Acts will enable a constable to arrest a prisoner unlawfully at large and bring him before a magistrate, who will be able to issue a new warrant for his detention. A prisoner will be unlawfully at large for the purposes of the amendments if he is required by law to be in custody.
Customs Act 1901

The Act currently makes provision for the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy to take control of the property of persons penalised for complicity in certain narcotics dealings, in order to recover pecuniary penalties imposed on them. The amendments are designed to provide for indemnifications by the Commonwealth of the Official Trustee and officers of that statutory corporation in discharging this responsibility.
Dairy Produce Act 1986

The amendments will prevent persons who are members of the Executive Council of the Australian Dairy Conference, which is the peak policy council of the dairy industry, from being appointed as members of the Australian Dairy Corporation. This change is in accordance with the Government's policy that, where a statutory marketing authority is required to account to the peak industry body, the members of the executive council of that body are not to be eligible for appointment as members of the authority because of the possibility of a conflict of interests.
Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983

The amendments will enable the Director of Public Prosecutions to file a Commonwealth indictment against a person who has been committed for trial otherwise than in respect of a Commonwealth offence in certain circumstances. These are that the Director is satisfied that the facts or evidence on which the person was committed disclose the commission of an indictable Commonwealth offence, and that if the person's committal for trial for that Commonwealth offence had been sought on the basis of those facts or that evidence it could have succeeded.

The amendments will also enable the Director to give an undertaking to persons who give evidence in Australia in proceedings brought under the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966 and Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966 and in relation to coronial inquests and inquiries conducted under the laws of the Commonwealth. The undertaking which can be given to such persons is that the evidence to be given by them will not be used against them in civil or criminal proceedings-except for perjury in respect of the evidence.
Export Market Development Grants Act 1974

The Act was introduced to ensure that Government assistance to exporters was provided in a more cost effective manner. The amendments are needed to correct an anomaly in the provisions of the Act covering the export of educational services. Currently it specifically excludes Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory governments from claiming grants under the export market development grants scheme. Some colleges promoting educational services are not established as separate legal entities but are part of Commonwealth, State or Territory education departments. As it was clearly intended that such colleges should be encouraged to promote the export of their educational services, it is proposed to amend the Act to allow education departments to claim in respect of those colleges' export activities.
First Home Owners Act 1983

The Act confers on the Secretary of the administering department the discretion to determine for the purposes of an application under the first home owners scheme that the date of the applicant's contract was later than that stated in the contract. The amendments are intended to clarify the extent of that discretion and the circumstances under which a later date can be so determined.

Another amendment will enable an intending spouse of an applicant to join in the application. This will overcome a difficulty with the existing legislative provisions which put intending spouses at a cost disadvantage compared with joint applicants who are married couples or are living together in a de facto relationship.
Honey Industry Act 1962

The proposed amendments will enable the Minister to extend the terms of current members of the Australian Honey Board to the end of 1988, by which time it is planned that legislation for reform of the Board will have been passed. The amendments are necessary because that legislation will not be introduced or passed before the expiration of some current members' terms in June 1987. An extension of the terms of existing members will overcome problems caused by the lack of time available to hold a poll of producers to elect new producers' members to serve for the brief period until the projected reforms are fully implemented.
Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986: Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986: Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Act 1986

The amendments will replace references in the Inspector-General Act to the former Human Rights Commission and the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 with references to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986. The amendments will also make it clear that the Inspector-General may inquire into an act or practice of an intelligence agency that is or may be contrary to any human right, may constitute discrimination or may be unlawful under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 or the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 where it has been referred to the Inspector-General by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The term `discrimination' is given the same meaning as in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act.
National Companies and Securities Commission Act 1979

The amendments will enable the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities to make determinations about superannuation benefits for full time members of the Commission. They will also empower the Commission to make disbursements pursuant to any superannuation arrangements so determined by the Council for full time Commission members.
National Crime Authority Act 1984

The amendments will extend the scope of the secrecy provisions of the Act to include certain persons who at any given time might be engaged in the operational work of the National Crime Authority without being employed by the Authority.

A new provision is inserted to enable the issue of warrants for the arrest of absconding witnesses, and to enable execution of such warrants even if not in the possession of the relevant officer when making the arrest.
National Measurement Act 1960

As part of the ongoing process of metrication, imperial units used in the real estate industry will be withdrawn as legal units of measurement on 1 July 1987. Since it is unclear whether the Act currently applies to real estate contracts, a new provision will be inserted specifically relating to real estate contracts. The new provision will provide that real estate contracts will be void unless entered into by reference to Australian legal units of measurement or additional legal units of measurement. The voiding provision will not apply however where the units of measurement which are referred to in the contract are the units of measurement which are referred to in the documents of title for that land, or in a plan referred to in the documents of title.

The amendments will specifically except futures contracts from the requirement that only Australian legal units of measurement of any physical quantity be used. It is recognised that futures contracts can cover matters in countries which have non-metric units of physical measurement.

The amendments will also create the office of Executive Director of the National Standards Commission, who will also be an ex-officio member of the Commission. He or she will be appointable by the Commission, not the Governor-General.

The appointment of the Executive Director will add to the Commission's expertise and enhance its effectiveness. It will also be consistent with the findings of the Committee of Inquiry into Commonwealth Laboratories-the Ross Committee-and with the `Policy Discussion Paper concerning the Efficiency and Accountability of Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises'.
Another amendment, which will also implement that policy discussion paper, will raise from $50,000 to $100,000 the limit on contracts which the Commission may enter into without ministerial approval.
National Museum of Australia Act 1980

The amendment is being made to rectify an anomaly. The Act at present does not give the Council of the Museum the power to dispose of historical material owned by, or in the possession of, the Museum which does not, however, form part of the `national historical collection' as defined in the Act. The amendment will confer on the Museum largely the same power to dispose of such material as it now has over material that is in the `national historical collection'.
Navigation Act 1912; Shipping Registration Act 1981
The most noteworthy amendments of the Navigation Act will benefit the maritime industry by eliminating unnecessary duplication of certificating of ships.
The amendments of the Shipping Registration Act are intended to promote the prompt provision to the Registrar of Shipping of accurate information on ships entitled to be registered in Australia.
Pig Industry Act 1986

This amendment removes the restriction on the Australian Pork Corporation Selection Committee which prevents it from nominating for appointment to the Corporation anyone who is a member of the executive of an eligible industry body, that is, the Australian Pork Producers Federation or the National Meat Processors Association. A person will still be ineligible for actual appointment to the Corporation if he or she is such a member.

Removal of this restriction will mean that such a person will not need to resign his or her position in the Federation or Association when nominated for appointment; he or she will have to do so only if and when offered appointment to the Corporation by the Minister. This amendment will bring the selection procedures for the Corporation into line with those for other statutory marketing authorities.
Quarantine Act 1908

The Act does not at present authorise the search of luggage and cargo entering mainland Australia from the Torres Strait area on Australian ships and aircraft. The amendment will close this loophole in the law.
Trade Practices Act 1974

The object of this amendment is to eliminate overlap and possible conflict between the provisions of the Act that import certain terms into contracts for the sale of goods and those of the 1980 Vienna Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods.

Legislation implementing the provisions of the Convention is being enacted in each State and Territory. Once that legislation is in place and the amendment now proposed has been made, Australia will be in position to accede to the Convention.
I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 13 May statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on initial Budget measures for 1987-88, which we are debating today, should never have been necessary. But, given that it did become necessary, it should have been a serious attempt to identify and tackle the fundamental problems facing this nation. Instead, the Government once again dissipated its opportunities and totally misjudged the priority needs of Australians. The mini-Budget not only failed to tackle the fundamentals of our problems but it targeted those in our society who could least afford to be targeted. It targeted the already disadvantaged, the weak, the poor, the powerless. It added to the problems of these people in our society. It furthered the process that the Government embarked on when it took office more than four years ago, the process of butchering the living standards of virtually every Australian. The Government has caused the greatest fall in living standards--
—An overdose of your rhetoric.

—I repeat, for Senator Evans's benefit, that the Hawke Government has caused the greatest fall in living standards in well over 30 years. It has done so in a variety of ways and for a variety of reasons. It has done so deliberately, coldly and callously. It has done so because it has not had the guts to stand up to its powerful friends, the trade union movement, of which the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was the leader for 10 long and miserable years-10 years which saw the trade union movement and its leader become far and away the most divisive and destructive element in Australia's history. The Government has not had the guts to take the axe to its own bloated spending programs, to its vast bureaucracies, to its inefficient, senseless and wasteful spending of the taxpayer's money. These are the reasons which have necessitated this mini-Budget. These are the reasons why the Opposition called over and over again for the Government to introduce a mini-Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: It was totally clear last August when the 1986 Budget was brought down that a mini-Budget would be necessary before the end of this financial year-totally clear to everyone except this incompetent Government and economically illiterate Treasurer. The need for a mini-Budget was clear, as were the reasons. The reasons were these: Government spending had got out of control. The four Keating Budgets have been the four biggest spending Budgets in our history, not just in terms of dollars but as a proportion of our total gross domestic product or, if you like, our total economy. For this reason the Government has also been the biggest taxing government in our history. Because of both these factors the Hawke Government has presided over the lowest value of the Australian dollar ever. It has imposed and is still imposing the highest real interest rates in our history. It has contributed to the largest foreign debt ever, a debt which is now, in net terms, one-third of our total gross domestic product compared with only 13 per cent of GDP which it was when the Hawke Government came to office, a debt which last year increased by $3m every hour of every day of every week in the year, a foreign debt which to pay off would require $26,000 to be taken from every Australian family. The Government has contributed to the largest deficit in our balance of payments on current account in our history, a deficit which continues to increase by an average of $1 billion every month, a deficit which is the second largest of any country in the Western world, a deficit which is placing the future economic viability of our nation in very considerable jeopardy.

This Government's economic policies have led to its being the only Australian government ever to lose Australia's AAA international credit rating. It is these policies which have led to a major reduction in our rate of economic growth. In 1986-87 alone, gross domestic product growth will be at best 1 1/2 per cent compared with last year's Budget estimate of 2 1/4 per cent. The Government is forecasting growth of 2 1/2 per cent again for 1987-88, but one can bet London to a brick that that will not be achieved. The Government has substantially revised downwards the forecasts for growth in 1987-88 which it made only five months ago.

Inflation has remained very high, indeed at record levels relative to the inflation rates of our major trading partners. There is very little substantive evidence to suggest that inflation will decline next year. Private business investment, the engine of future growth and development, has fallen in three of the past four years and will show little or no growth once again in the current 1986-87 year. More disturbing still, surveys indicate that business fixed investment will fall even further next year, 1987-88, possibly by as much as 5 to 10 per cent. These disastrous trends have had a devastating effect on the standard of living of every Australian, and particularly young families with young children.

Let me outline some of the stark, cruel, objective facts. A one income family with two young children is now at least $31 a week worse off than it was when the Hawke Labor Government was first elected. Even after the Hawke Government's so-called tax cut on 1 July next, all single income families with a dependent spouse will be paying a higher proportion of their income in income tax than in March 1983. For a single income family on average weekly earnings, the average tax rate will have increased from 17.5 per cent in March 1983 to 20.5 per cent in July 1987, while the marginal tax rate will have increased from 30 per cent to 40 per cent. After July this year such a family will still require an additional income tax cut of $15 a week just to restore it to the same average tax rate position it faced when the Hawke Government came to office. In other words, the Hawke Government's December 1986 and July 1987 tax cuts merely give back to taxpayers some of the additional tax that four years of fiscal drag have taken away from them. So much for taxation.

Let us look at other areas where this miserable, incompetent Government has savaged Australians. There are now almost three-quarters of a million more people below the poverty line than there were when the Hawke Government came to office. There are now 2.6 million people officially classified as below the poverty line, compared with 1.9 million people in 1983. Some 400,000 Australians live permanently in caravans and another 100,000 are homeless or live in refuges. Public housing waiting lists continue to grow inexorably. There is a waiting list now of 154,000 for public housing-a record, and what a sad record. That figure of 154,000 includes families, of course, so the actual number of people affected is much greater.

Private housing has become unaffordable for many Australian families as a result of the deliberate high interest rate policy of this Government. Four years ago, when the Labor Government was first elected, the average Australian family needed to spend 19c in every dollar of its pre-tax income to repay its housing loan. Today, that figure is almost 27c in every dollar. The real position, of course, is much worse than that because that sum is a percentage of pre-tax income dollars and the average amount of tax that all of us are paying is now that much higher. This amounts to a staggering increase of $281 each month in additional repayments, to a total average monthly repayment figure on an average loan for an average house by an average Australian income earner of $650. No wonder Australian families are bleeding from the wounds inflicted by this Government.

So what does the Government do? In its mini-Budget it increased taxes still further, by between $400m and $500m per year. The Government boasted that this was a much vaunted part of its so-called $4 billion spending cuts-but $500m of that was in increased taxes, not in reduced spending. On top of that, the Government increased the cost of private health insurance. It discriminated against private hospitals and disadvantaged many ill people, particularly the elderly with chronic illnesses. It announced a $1 billion sale of assets but it refused to give sufficient details for us to judge whether these sales are achievable. On the Government's past record, they are not achievable. It tried to have us believe that this selling off of the family silver was a spending reduction. What absolute nonsense.

The Government announced a $1 billion reduction in payments to the States but it refused yesterday at the Premiers Conference-and it stands indicted for this-to obtain any assurance from the States that they will cut their spending accordingly, rather than simply fuel inflation by increasing State taxes and charges. It is clear from the Premiers' reactions after yesterday's Premiers Conference, and from the comments in today's Press about those reactions, that State taxes and charges will be increased. So Australians will be slugged still further, their living standards will be further reduced and additional imposts will be placed on business at a time when business is struggling to survive and, as I said before, when business investment is falling.

I will leave it to other speakers on this side of the chamber to go into more detail on these and other issues. Let me make a few concluding additional points. The Opposition of course does not object to everything in this mini-Budget. Several of the decisions, including for example those relating to the unemployment benefit for 16- and 17-year-olds and the privatisation proposals, were taken from my Liberal Party's policies. What we do object to is the Government's economic incompetence which led to the need for a mini-Budget in the first place and then, having decided on a mini-Budget, the Government's failing abjectly to deliver the goods on its own side and instead trying to force all the pain of adjustment on to the States without obtaining any guarantees that they will not merely increase their own revenues rather than reduce expenditures.

Not one government body, board, commission or department was abolished in this mini-Budget. Not one attempt was made to reduce duplication and waste by Federal and State governments. Instead, all we got was the tired old rhetoric and a further attack on the living standards of Australians. The Government must realise that the time for alibis has long passed-if it ever existed. This Government inherited a situation in March 1983 where the world economy was recovering, the worst Australian drought in living memory was breaking and the Fraser Government's wage pause was bringing stability to costs, prices and interest rates. The Hawke Government inherited a wonderful opportunity but through gross mismanagement, capitulation to militant trade unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and an overwhelming need to be populist, this Government has completely dissipated the wonderful opportunities with which it was presented. As a result, Australia and all Australians are the poorer. This is tragic.

The other tragedy is that the Government appears to have learnt nothing from the past four years. It is not good enough for the Government to blame Australia's economic problems simply on the terms of trade, on the fact that the rest of the world is paying less for our goods. On three occasions during the 1970s, the terms of trade declined by as much as or more than they have in the last couple of years. But the difference between then and now is that in the 1970s the Fraser Government which faced these problems adopted policies which had regard for these declines and for the external situation. As a result it produced policies which caused and enabled living standards to rise. By contrast, this Hawke Labor Government has failed to tailor its policies to take account of its external environment and, as a result, we have all suffered. But, for heaven's sake, let us hear no more alibis. Quite simply, they will not wash any longer.

If Australia is to break out of its present disastrous combination of highest real inflation in our history relative to the rest of the world, its declining economic growth, its rising unemployment, its record interest rates and its record and rising debt, several fundamental steps have to be taken. The Government obviously cannot take them all. Decisions that governments take will affect the future of this country and determine the growth, the activity and the living standards of this country in a fundamental way. What the Government must do-what it has not done since it came to office-is encourage incentive and initiative so as to increase investment and productivity to make us internationally competitive once again. In the last four years we have become increasingly internationally uncompetitive. Depending on how one plays with the figures, they will show that the exchange rate depreciation has made us more competitive than would have otherwise been the case and, of course, that is so. But exchange rate depreciation is the soft, unsustainable option to make a country increasingly competitive and we are not taking the steps to produce international competitiveness on a sustainable basis. Over the last four years our unit labour costs have risen relative to those of our major trading partners and we have become increasingly uncompetitive in that and other ways.

So the Government must adopt policies and take actions to reverse that trend to make Australia a much more productive and competitive country again. As part of that, the Government must restructure the tax system to encourage this productivity and growth. We must have a less overall burden of taxation; we must have a flatter rate of income tax; we must remove the enormous raft of anti-business taxes that have been foisted on the productive sector of this nation over the last four years; and we must remove the bias and positively rebase our taxation system to assist young Australian families with young children because that is the group in our community that has been most savaged by the policies of the Hawke Government over the last four years and that is the group in our community that can least afford to be so savaged.

Quite simply and quite obviously, we cannot afford the continuing decline in our relative position in the world that has occurred over the last four years. Over the last couple of days we have heard sounds, noises and words that we are about to have an early election. All I can say to the Government is that on its record over the last four years, particularly its record on this latest mini-Budget and its continuing failure to take the hard and necessary decisions to put this country right, I, for one, cannot wait to go to an election to help restore a Liberal-National Party coalition to government because that is the only way that this country will get out of its present problems and go on to a vital and prosperous future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating the Budget 1987-88-Initial Measures, May 1987, otherwise known as the May economic statement. I begin my remarks by saying that after three years of strong economic growth in Australia, the Government made a readjustment to Australia's economic policy in the August 1986 Budget. Up to 1986 Australia had experienced the most rapid real economic growth in the Western world. Despite the carping, whingeing and knocking comments by the Opposition and despite the knocking comments by Senator Short this afternoon, this Government had the fastest real economic growth in the Western world in the period up to June 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short claimed that, because of world economic recovery or some other factor, economic growth in Australia took off under this Government. But it certainly does not explain the fact that, over that three-year period, the Labor Government in Australia presided over the most rapid growth of any industrialised country in the world. We had to readjust our economic policy because of the external factors facing the country, most notably the relative decline in the average prices paid for our export items compared with the average prices paid for our import items. As a result of that decline in our terms of trade, we have physically had to export more items to cover the cost of a previously given amount of imports and there has been a blow-out in the recurrent part of our balance of payments, known as the current account. The deficit on the current account increased enormously and that is the reason why the Government has had to readjust economic policies. This May statement is part of that readjustment of policy.

It is very illustrative to compare our export prices on average with our import prices in the financial year 1985-86. We find that they declined by some 10.1 per cent in that year compared with a previous annual decline of around one per cent per annum. So that devastating fall in our export prices wiped off about $4,500m of Australia's national income in one fell swoop. Of course, despite the comments made by the Opposition, most notably by Senator Short this afternoon, the decline in the terms of trade is completely outside the control of the Government of Australia. In fact, it reflects items such as depressed international commodity prices and it has been compounded by the actions of the United States of America and the European Economic Community in subsidising farm prices which have been forcing down the prices of our traditional exports. So those are the sorts of factors that have been causing these problems. The bottom line is that, as a result of those factors, Australia has had to export more to pay for the same amount of imports. That is a very simple way of illustrating the problems facing this country and it is a very simple way of showing the need for measures such as the May economic statement.

The Government has readjusted economic policy to moderate domestic economic demand but, at the same time, permit increasing growth from external sources. In fact, the 1986 Budget calculates that net exports-that is, the excess of exports over imports-will constitute some one and three-quarter percentage points of the projected growth in domestic product in 1986-87, with the domestic sector growing by comparison by only one-half of a percentage point. So the overwhelming contribution to that growth is coming from the external sector.

The low growth in domestic demand will help to turn around the current account deficit on our balance of payments, most importantly, by reducing demand of the economy for imports because there is quite a definite relationship between levels of economic activity and demand for imports into an open economy, such as that of Australia. To achieve this objective of reducing imports the Government has made substantial reductions to its own expenditures. Let me give as an example the 1986 Budget deficit, as distinct from the current account deficit on the balance of payments. I must say that I am surprised at the amount of confusion that exists, even among members of parliament, that the current account deficit is the same as the Budget deficit. It is a rather astounding situation. The deficit of the Federal Budget has been cut to 1.4 per cent of gross domestic product for the current financial year. Of course, that compares with a 5 per cent prospective deficit inherited from Mr Howard when he was the Liberal Treasurer for the 1983-84 financial year. During the current year total public sector borrowings will fall by more than $2,000m and this will help cut, importantly, the growth in public debt interest and hold it at about 10 per cent of Commonwealth government spending through the Budget.

The statement that was brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last Wednesday week includes a number of measures that will have the effect of reducing the Commonwealth Budget deficit in the 1987-88 financial year by some $4,000m. The measures in that May statement will have the effect of reducing the rate of growth of government spending to its lowest level in 30 years and the statement builds on the process of readjustments that the Government initiated last August in the 1986 Budget.

Mr Deputy President, the measures that are contained in the May economic statement fall into three categories: Recurrent expenditure reductions; receipts measures; and the sale of assets. Recurrent expenditure reductions total more than $2,600m for next financial year, of which $1,600m are recurrent expenditure reductions by the Commonwealth Government in respect of its own expenditure with the remaining $1,000m being made up of recurrent expenditure reductions by the six States and the Territories. The receipts measures in the May economic statement will gather some $400m, resulting from the removal of sales tax and customs exemptions for some Commonwealth enterprises. So, the recurrent reductions in prospective government spending next financial year will total $3,000m. This will be capped off by the sale of assets worth $1,000m, which will be used to reduce Commonwealth debt and to provide some savings on interest payments made by the Commonwealth Government. Had the Government not acted to introduce this May economic statement to restructure Commonwealth and State government expenditures, the forward estimates of expenditure show that spending would have risen by some $7,000m or 2 1/2 per cent in real terms next financial year. A very large amount of extra expenditure would have resulted had there not been measures to trim back growth in Commonwealth Government and State government spending.

As a result of the May statement, instead of there being a real increase of 2 1/2 per cent in real terms in government spending next financial year there will be a negative 2 per cent change. The May economic statement introduced by the Treasurer will allow the Commonwealth Government significantly to reduce the Budget deficit in both money terms and as a proportion of Australia's gross domestic product. Next year's Budget deficit will fall below one per cent of Australia's gross domestic product and I would compare that with the figure that was inherited from Mr Howard when he was the Liberal Treasurer. The figure in prospect for 1983-84 was some 5 per cent of gross domestic product. In 1987-88 the Budget deficit will be less than one per cent of Australia's gross domestic product and a figure of around $2,000m is likely to be the Budget deficit next financial year, compared with the figure bequeathed by Mr Howard to the Australian people of $9,600m.

The Government's spending restraint will contribute towards correcting the imbalance in the external economy, reduce public sector borrowings and help to reduce interest rate pressures in the economy. The fiscal restraint practised by the Commonwealth will help to moderate domestic demand and, as I explained earlier, therefore help to moderate and stem the flow of imports. The reduced government borrowing will help stem the growth of Australia's foreign debt. I should here, Mr Acting Deputy President, pick up some of the comments made by Senator Short in this debate this afternoon, because although he waxed eloquent about the level of Australia's foreign debt, I did not hear him refer at all to the fact that the overwhelming majority of that debt is in fact private sector debt owed by many of the largest corporations in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been forced off-shore by your high interest rates.

—As a result of very large scale borrowings by large Australian corporations we have a situation where the overwhelming majority of Australia's overseas debt is owed by companies. It is rather illuminating to hear a National Party senator such as Senator Brownhill, who purports to represent farmers and rural interests, now protecting the largest industrial corporations in Australia and now defending them and their activities to take over Australian assets by large scale off-shore borrowings. It is an indication of the road down which the National Party of Australia has moved since the days when it defended the ordinary farming community of Australia; now it protects the large industrial corporations that borrow billions and billions of dollars overseas to take over Australia's assets.

SPEECH.PARA: The May economic statement brings restraint with equity to the Australian community. The Government has spread the burden of adjustment to the more difficult economic times we face in Australia across all sections of the community. It has not left it to the laws of the market or the laws of the economic jungle. It is, by its own action, spreading the burden of the adjustment to our difficult circumstances across the community. I am very pleased that one of the items that have been cut in the May economic statement is the allocation on the forward estimates for defence, because it is a fact that in the previous two rounds of reductions in expenditure the defence area has been largely untouched. Although it is important that we have a viable defence structure in Australia, it is also important that the defence area shares the burden of reductions at a time of economic restraint such as the present. The one per cent reduction in defence spending next financial year will save some $350m of the $1,600m of Commonwealth outlays reduced by the May statement.

The provision in the May statement to income test family allowances is a very fair measure, again spreading the burden of adjustment more equally-making sure that lower income families are protected but also ensuring that those who have the capacity to pay make their contribution by having family allowances subject to an income test if the income is above $50,000. It is very interesting to note that in the case of, say, a three-child family, family allowances do not cut out until an income of $59,400 is achieved. That is by no means a low income in Australia. It is a relatively high income and I believe it is fair and just that families in those circumstances do contribute to the sacrifices that have to be made by the community as a whole. The savings made with regard to family allowances will save the expenditure of $95m next financial year.

I am also very pleased as a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts that reductions have been made in the schedule fees paid to members of the medical profession in regard to some diagnostic services. The fact is that in recent years enormous productivity gains have been made as a result of high technology being introduced into diagnostic services. Multiple tests are now available with particular equipment, but the schedule of fees that was available to remunerate doctors for performing those services was still very much of a cumulative nature. So doctors could be remunerated by adding a number of services together and getting a very large remuneration from the taxpayer when, in fact, the technology that is available enables a whole range of tests to be performed simultaneously. It is appropriate that these measures have been introduced in the May economic statement to bring the fees that are paid to those members of the medical profession more into line with the technology that is available. I just instance that, in regard to the diagnostic services, that will save the taxpayer some $40m next financial year. That, combined with other adjustments in medical fees, will save a total of $128m, and that is one of the large elements of government expenditure reduction in the May economic statement.

I am very pleased to say, as are all members of the Australian Labor Party, that in constructing the May economic statement-in looking at the sums and in getting the numbers right-we have been able to exempt pensioners from any further sacrifice through cuts in expenditures. We are very pleased indeed that, following the May economic statement, we have been able to retain indexation of pensions for cost of living rises. I am also pleased to announce that on 25 June there will be a 5.5 per cent increase in pensions, reflecting the rise in the consumer price index from July to December last year. The standard or single weekly rate of pension will increase by $5.95 to $112.15. The weekly rate of pension for couples will rise by $9.90 to $187. Of course, as well as going to age pensioners, that 5.5 per cent increase will go to invalid pensioners, widows and supporting parents. It will be available to married couples receiving unemployment benefits and it will also apply to persons over the age of 21 years receiving unemployment benefits but without dependants. It will also be available for persons receiving service, disability and war widows' pensions paid through the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

Even though we have brought down this very stringent reduction in government expenditure, the Government has committed itself to the introduction on 1 July of the so-called poverty trap measures, which will be of enormous benefit to pensioners throughout the Australian community. On 1 July the amount of extra income allowable before a person goes on to a part pension will increase from $30 a week to $40 a week for a single person and from $50 a week to $70 a week for couples. Also, on 1 July the income which is disregarded in the case of pensioners who have dependent children will be doubled from $6 per child to $12 per child. That means that a pensioner couple with one dependent child, instead of having the present income limit of $56 before going on to a part pension, will have an income limit of $82. That is a tremendous increase. The most important thing to bear in mind is that, as a result of the indexation of pensions by 5.5 per cent on 25 June, Australian pensions, as a proportion of the average weekly earnings of the work force, will be heading towards 25 per cent. That is worthy of note. In late 1986 the pension in Australia equalled 24.1 per cent of total average weekly earnings, which compares very favourably with the 22 per cent proportion which applied when Mr Howard was Treasurer.

The May economic statement also introduces an assets test in respect of unemployment and other beneficiaries. That measure will save some $12 1/2m next financial year. The test will apply to persons aged 25 years and over receiving unemployment, sickness or special benefits. That measure closes a loophole which has existed with respect to the pensions assets test. This loophole has been taken advantage of by people who have retired voluntarily before reaching age pension age and who have been able to obtain unemployment benefits without being subject to the assets test which applies in regard to pensions.

I am very pleased to note that in the May economic statement there is provision for very significant rises in Austudy allowances; that is, the allowances for persons undergoing secondary or tertiary education in Australia. The allowances paid to those students will be increased significantly from June 1988. I instance the case of a secondary student aged from 18 to 20 years living at home. In January that person's allowance will rise from $45 a week to $60 a week. In other words, that very important allowance will increase by a third. The allowance for a secondary student aged 16 or 17 years who is living at home will increase from $40 to $50 a week, or by one quarter.

These are some of the specific measures in the May economic statement. In bringing down that document the Government clearly has rejected the two alternative strategies for dealing with the decline in Australia's terms of trade and its external imbalance. It has rejected the option of doing nothing and it has rejected the option which would have been favoured by a person such as Mr Howard, based on his previous track record, of engineering a recession to deflate the economy and thereby reduce the demand for imports. The Government has taken action to stem the flow of imports and to hold down growth in Australia's foreign debt. Had we not done that, the economy would have become trapped in a vicious circle of exchange rate depreciation, mounting inflation and a worsening external imbalance. A deliberately engineered recession would have forced a reduction in the current account deficit, but it would have done so by drastically reducing domestic demand and by just flinging more and more Australians on to the industrial scrapheap. Of course, such a measure would have resulted in substantial falls in family incomes with steep rises in unemployment.

There are very encouraging indications that the Government's economic policies are having their effect. I refer to the situation in regard to the current account deficit. The rate of deficit is coming down compared with the Budget forecast. There are encouraging signs in financial markets in regard to interest rates. All honourable senators will be aware that recently most Australian banks have cut their prime interest rates on major overdrafts from around 18 per cent in April to 16.75 per cent in May. These are some of the major reductions in overdraft rates that have been occurring for large borrowers, but I think the most interesting change in interest rates is that paid on bank bills, particularly the three-month bank bills. Three-month bank bills are a major form of borrowing by the banks, as distinct from lending. They are a device by which banks are able to obtain funds for further on-lending to the rest of the community. It is very illuminating to look at the rate that applied back in January, when it touched 17.7 per cent. But, looking at the figures for yesterday, we see that that rate was not 17.7 per cent but 13.7 per cent, so there has been a four percentage points reduction in that very important borrowing rate paid by the banks and that, of course, has a very big influence on their on-lending rates. I noticed that a commentator said last week that once that rate on bank bills touched the 13 per cent level there would be quite significant scope for reductions in other interest rates such as those for home mortgages.

We have made great strides in keeping down the rate of inflation or cost of living rises in Australia. As at March 1987 Australia had a 9.3 per cent annual inflation rate compared with a rate of 9.8 per cent up to December last year. So the cost of living rises are moderating. While a 9.3 per cent cost of living rise for the community is too high, it certainly compares well indeed with the 11 1/2 per cent rise-the double digit rise-in inflation that was occurring when Mr Howard was Treasurer. We have had very strong employment growth in Australia in the 12 months to April this year. In fact, despite the adverse economic circumstances facing Australia, employment has grown at a rate well in excess of the Budget forecast of 1.75 per cent. That growth far outstrips the employment performance of many comparable countries.

Since the Government's economic summit in April 1983, more than three-quarters of a million new jobs have been created. The Fraser-Howard Government was in office for more than seven years, and its total record for that period was 337,000 new jobs. The Hawke Government has more than doubled that effort, with three-quarters of a million new jobs created in a four-year period. That has had the effect of helping to reduce the unemployment rate, which peaked at 10.4 per cent during the Howard recession of 1982-83. That unemployment rate has now been reduced to 8.3 per cent, which is a significant reduction.

The May economic statement enables honourable senators to look forward to the next financial year, 1987-88, somewhat more optimistically with regard to economic matters. As I pointed out earlier, a Budget deficit of around $2,000m can be expected in the next financial year. I compare that with the $9,600m deficit inherited by this Government from the former Treasurer, Mr Howard. The Government can point to a forecast of gross domestic product growth of 2 1/2 per cent in the next financial year, and it can also point to a fall in the inflation rate. Honourable senators heard Senator Short talking a load of nonsense about inflation rates and how inflation would not fall as a result of the May economic statement. This Government started off with an inflation rate of 11 1/2 per cent inherited from Mr Howard when he was the Treasurer. It has already got it down to 9.3 per cent. However, the forecast as a result of the May economic statement is that by June 1988, the annual inflation rate will be cut not to 8.3 per cent or 7.3 per cent but to the vicinity of 6 per cent. That is a virtual halving of the inflation rate that pervaded Australia when Mr Howard had his go at running the economy of this country. We can look forward to improvements on the economic front next financial year as a result of the May economic statement.

This Government, through its policies, has ended double digit inflation and double digit unemployment, and has ended economic mismanagement. It has created three-quarters of a million new jobs; it has not destroyed 186,000 jobs as Mr Howard did when he was the Treasurer. The May economic statement helps the Government to take better advantage of the competitive edge provided for the Australian economy by the devaluation of the dollar. Australia is now poised to reap the benefits of the redirected and restructured economy, and a key benefit of that will be improved future living standards for the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to Senator Maguire, for whom I have always had an amount of respect, I thought he was talking about fairy tales and as though we are living in a land called Camelot. He is not in the land in which I am living because he is looking at the situation in a quite different way. He is either living in Camelot or away with the pixies. The mini-Budget was forced upon the Government because of its continued mishandling and misinterpretation of the economy. The Government has been repeatedly unable to keep its Budget deficit to acceptable levels. The best that can be said is that it has started to do some of the necessary pruning that it should have done a couple of years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that I have always had some respect for Senator Maguire, I have to say that I cannot understand what he was talking about, because his thinking is in a different category to that of any other person in Australia. The Government has failed to make any substantial cuts in spending of any real nature in any government department. I remind Senator Maguire that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) indicated in his statement that spending cuts would reduce the growth rate of government spending to its lowest level in 30 years. I shall refer to the level of government spending since the Labor Party has been in power in a moment or two.

This is not a real cut. It is not what the community expected the Government would be doing at this stage to get the economy back on the rails. The Government has decided to take the soft options. It has decided to sell assets-and in some cases, it is unlikely that it will find buyers for them. Last year, this same Government was talking of selling rifle ranges in Sydney and Melbourne. Those rifle ranges are still on the market. Other assets the Government has included in its assets sell-off are Commonwealth offices. They are included at a time when the Government is still paying exorbitant rents for space elsewhere. The Government is talking about selling off the Embassy in Paris and parts of the Tokyo Embassy land. Even if those sales go through, they will only slightly reduce the Commonwealth debt, which is now some $46 billion, aided and abetted by the Government's mismanagement of the past few years. The sale of those assets would raise revenue in the short term, but it would do little for the long term economic needs. It has only a small immediate impact and has no continuing benefit for this country.

The sale of those assets will not be of any substantial benefit given the size of Australia's present trade deficit. The sale of part of the Tokyo Embassy seems particularly futile when the Government will be liable for capital gains tax to the Japanese Government. It is a short-sighted move. There is little to be gained from selling an asset at any time, but it is likely that, in the future, Australia will need to expand its embassy area and it could use that land it has now to earn income rather than to have a one-off benefit. No accountant would suggest selling assets to clear debts if there were a possibility of the asset being a potential income earner. It is all right to sell an asset that has no hope of earning income, but it is futile to sell an asset that has a chance of being an income earner, such as the Embassy in Tokyo.
I shall quote from a letter that appeared in the Australian Financial Review of Friday, 22 May from a Mr Harrowell, who visited Tokyo. He stated:

As the result of a most innovative approach by the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services last year I was involved in forming a consortium to provide advice on all aspects of redevelopment of the Australian Embassy site and attended in Tokyo for the purpose of ascertaining the facts and preparing a tender submission.
The letter went on to state:
This low vacancy rate is being maintained in the face of very high rents.
The letter indicates that one can get between $6,000 and $10,000 a month for suitable accommodation in Tokyo, and that is because there is a low vacancy rate. The letter ends by stating:

Australia has already incurred the cost of acquiring lands sufficient to satisfy Australian requirements for many years to come; the commercial decision is how best to capitalise on this valuable asset. The British and Canadian Governments have already considered the issue and incorporated in developments of their sites the ability to let office and domestic accommodation on the local rental market both to fund redevelopment and to maximise site usage.

The scope and possibilities for maximising site usage in Tokyo are enormous and any decision to sell without a thorough evaluation would be extremely short-sighted and not, I believe, in the long-term interests of Australia.

Those comments were made by a person who has been there to look at the situation. The sort of capital gain that can be made from an asset like that is something that the Government has not properly considered. One of the measures that have been suggested concerns gaining revenue from Telecom Australia and Australia Post by taking away the excise exemptions that presently exist. Telecom has already announced that it will increase the cost of local and subscriber trunk dialling calls. It has already indicated that it will almost completely stop its upgrading of telephone services in regional and remote areas. The cost of rural installations will increase from some $1,380 to $6,250. Australia Post is also going to increase its charges. This involves no savings, cuts or reduced expectations; there is no real belt-tightening or greater efficiency in this proposal. This is simply passing on the costs to people in the community. It involves no real increase in productivity and there is no real cutting back of government spending. Yesterday the States' allocation was cut back, supposedly by some $2.4 billion. Predictably, with one exception, the States have said that the cuts will be difficult to absorb without increases in taxes and charges. This morning's Sydney Morning Herald reports comments by Mr Unsworth, the Premier of New South Wales, as follows:
Mr Unsworth said transport, hospital and electricity charges were likely to rise as a result of the $750m cut in NSW funds.

While he hoped cost increases could be kept within the Consumer Price Index, as he had promised earlier, the Government would have to examine the Budget figures more closely . . . Mr Unsworth said the effects of the cuts would begin to flow through after the September State Budget.
`The severity of the cuts places an enormous burden on the State which will result in a pruning of our expenditure and an increase in some government charges,' he said.

This will cause an increase in the cost of living for the people living in New South Wales. In CPI terms it will cost all the people of Australia, and obviously will start a further advance in the inflationary spiral in this country.

I want to refer to a few facts about this Government, some of which Senator Short has already mentioned. This is the biggest taxing Government in peacetime history, with receipts from tax accounting for some 25.5 per cent of the gross domestic product in 1986-87. This is the biggest spending government in peacetime history. In 1984-85 spending reached 30.4 per cent of GDP. It is very easy for honourable senators opposite to criticise the Fraser Government, but I point out that under Fraser spending totalled 27.7 per cent of GDP, while under Hawke the average is 29.9 per cent. I think that Senator Maguire, who has now left the chamber, would most probably be very interested in those figures, in that they could help him when he next plays his Camelot role in this chamber. Under this Government the dollar has slumped to its lowest level ever; on 31 July last year it fell to US57c. Under this Government Australians have suffered the highest interest rates ever. It is all very well to say that interest rates have come back now, but they have come back from an extremely high level to what is still an extremely high level. The interest rate for home loans has been as high as 15.5 per cent minimum; Bankcard has been as high as 22.5 per cent; the prime lending rate has been as high as 21 per cent; and the small overdraft rate has been as high as 20.5 per cent.

Further, under this Government the largest stock of foreign debt ever has been accumulated-$101 billion plus at the end of September 1986. In Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development terms, we have the worst relative inflation rate in the world-some four or five times higher than the OECD average. We have the highest current account deficit ever. In 1986 it was 5.9 per cent of GDP. Whenever the current account deficit for the month is under $1 billion the Government is ecstatic, but what a thing to be ecstatic about. Would it not be nice if it could be turned around? What incentive will be given to this country by this Government? We must remember that this is the first Australian Government to lose Australia's AAA credit rating by two international credit rating agencies. Since 1984 Australia's inflation rate has risen while in the OECD countries inflation has been falling.

An inflation rate of around 9.3 to 9.5 per cent is definitely unacceptably high for any country. The mini-Budget has not addressed this problem. I have already said that Telecom and Australia Post will raise their charges, and I believe that the possibility of inflation rising even above the 10 per cent level is just around the corner. It is interesting to note that the standard six-cylinder Holden Commodore-the average Australian car-has increased in price by 25 per cent in 18 months. In the past year the cost of clothing has risen by some 10.2 per cent; house rents by 10.2 per cent; bus and tram fares by 10.7 per cent; cigarettes by 12.6 per cent; and books and magazines by 15 per cent. The situation is even worse in the country areas. In the Tamworth area, just some months ago the cost of fruit and vegetables rose by 18.5 per cent, and while the cost of wine and spirits rose by 6.4 per cent in the cities, in country areas like Tamworth it rose by 20 per cent. The cost of housing is rapidly becoming out of reach of most Australians. In March 1983, families needed to spend 19c of every dollar of weekly income to pay off the average house loan. By December last year that had risen to 27c in every dollar. That works out to be an extra $281 a month for the average home buyer. That is the real story, the real truth. This is not living in Camelot or going away with the pixies. This is how the Government has affected the real people of Australia, the people living in areas other than those which seem to be frequented by Government members. Some 2.6 million Australians are now below the poverty line, compared with 700,000 in March 1983.

What should the Government do? Should it have addressed the Medicare situation? Should it have done some pruning there? One must remember that not that long ago the Medicare levy was one per cent, increasing to 1.25 per cent and then to 1.5 per cent? Where will it end? Should not this Government have looked at having a wage freeze? We are already pricing ourselves out of our world markets. If we continue with wage rises we will never get our costs in line with those of other countries. Because the May economic statement was just a fiddle we will still not have a balanced Budget in this financial year. As a country we are still living well beyond our means. Because of the progressive tax scale there is still no incentive for people to work harder and be more productive. We must increase productivity; we have to produce more and if we are going to survive it has to be produced at a lower cost.

The Government must prune its inefficiency. Perhaps we need a Peter Grace type inquiry, such as the one that President Reagan commissioned in the United States of America. We need more than this May mini-statement produced by the Labor Government. This statement has been a sleight-of-hand in which the Commonwealth has not really cut back on its own spending. It has left it to the rest of the community to carry the bag for the Government. It has not done the right thing by the people in our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating the 1987-88 Budget-Initial Measures, May 1987 ministerial statement which was brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the House of Representatives last Wednesday and was replied to by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the former Treasurer in the Fraser Government, on Thursday evening. I wish to refer shortly to some of the public responses to both the statement by Mr Keating and the reply by Mr Howard. However, while Senator Brownhill is still in the chamber I cannot allow this opportunity to pass without commenting on a couple of the central propositions he put forward in his remarks. One of the comments that he made was that the Government had taken soft options, that the cuts were not real, but illusory, and the somehow we had shirked the responsibility imposed on those who have the treasury bench-the responsibility which obliges us to conduct the economic affairs of this nation as good economic managers. The belief that the Government has taken the soft options, as Senator Brownhill argues, is not shared by key spokesmen for the Opposition. For example, in a media release on 26 April, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), in anticipation of the May statement, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Not only must there be at least a $4 billion cut in government spending in May, but there also need to be further cuts in the August Budget.
On 30 March Jim Carlton, the honourable member for Mackellar, was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying:
The Government needs to make real cuts in government spending to the tune of about $4 billion if it is to convince international markets of its capacity to regain control of economic policy.

Senator Short, who spoke earlier today in this debate, made a statement on 10 May. I assume this statement was made to celebrate his elevation to the Opposition front bench as finance spokesman. He said:
However, it is certain that genuine expenditure reductions well in excess of $4 billion will be required if a necessary major attack on the Budget deficit is to be mounted.

All those leading spokesmen for the Opposition-Sinclair, Carlton and Short-nominated the figure of $4 billion. What do we find when we read the Treasurer's statement to Parliament? In his first sentence he said:
Madam Speaker, I shall outline to the Parliament and to the people of Australia measures which will reduce next year's prospective Budget deficit by more than $4,000m.

So the target nominated in advance by the Opposition for the Expenditure Review Committee of Cabinet to come up with was met in the statement. It behoves Opposition members at least to recognise that point. One of the necessary ingredients for any government, be it ours or theirs, to succeed in achieving a resurgence of growth and prosperity in the Australian economy is that there should at least be a recognition-as Mr Howard said when he became the Leader of the Opposition-of what the Government is doing right. The Government has done this right. The media commentary has recognised that and it is only the Opposition that does not do so. That partly explains why the Opposition is the most discredited Opposition that one could imagine appearing opposite a government such as ours.

The cuts are real. From time to time I wish that they were not as real as they are because the commentary given by the Liberal Party spokesman out in the electorate and reported in the local media is not the sort of commentary that is given in this chamber. Out there among the constituents, confronting the electors, the Liberal Party spokesmen claim that there is pain and suffering because of the cuts that have been made. They try to win votes in their favour because we have been too harsh. This double standard is something for which the Opposition should be held accountable.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens in here too, depending on who is speaking.

—That is absolutely right. Perhaps double standards are endemic in the Liberal Party. If one turns to the reply to the Treasurer's statement given by Mr Howard on Thursday, 14 May, one sees that in his opening sentence he complains about falling living standards in Australia, which we acknowledge have occurred. Later in his speech he also complains that we have supported wage increases. In the absence of a Liberal Party taxation policy-the one thing that the Leader of the Opposition argues will rescue living standards without there being wage increases-it is pretty hard to see how in present circumstances he can be credible. He puts the proposition that living standards should not have fallen in the way that they have and that the Government should not ease that fall through the social wage-the taxation policy and wages. As I understand it, the reduction in living standards has been to the tune of about 6 per cent. That reduction has been forced upon this Government by a turnaround in the terms of trade-a turnaround that the Treasurer estimates has taken some $6 billion off our national income. That is a significant turnaround in Australia's ability to earn. In those circumstances there needed to be some general reduction in living standards in this country. That is not something that we, as a government, like but it is something that we have sought to achieve with equity and fairness across the board and in concert with the major players in the Australian economy. Our mode of operation is not one of confronting the community and forcing standards on it. In a leaked Liberal Party document, a secret document which deals with the Liberal Party's proposed cuts, it predicts that there will be a general strike because of them. Our approach is to get a degree of easing down and that is something that we have done.

SPEECH.PARA: Having disposed of the points made by Senator Brownhill, I return to my comments about the May economic statement. The reception accorded to the statement has scotched once and for all any suggestion that this Government is not the best economic manager for Australia. The reception by the Press, the commentators, the market and the major community organisations is one in which the mantle of responsibility and capable economic management has clearly descended on the shoulders of this Government, so much so that if one consults yesterday's Australian Financial Review editorial one will see that it enjoins this Government-or the Prime Minister-to hold an early election and it says some revealing things which should be quoted. These comments indicate the degree of support for this Government across the board, across the political spectrum and from quarters that are not traditional Labor supporters. The editorial said:

As far as business is concerned, it is difficult to believe that a Labor Government will ever see a better polling result than the BRW-Hyatt Business Poll published in last week's Business Review Weekly.

It showed that out of 180 chief executives from the nation's biggest companies, almost 56 per cent regarded the Government's performance as `quite good' or `very good' while 94 per cent said the Opposition was `bad' or `indifferent'.
Almost 40 per cent said Mr Hawke would make the best Prime Minister and only John Elliott came anywhere near this score with a favourable rating of 29 per cent.
As long as Mr Elliott remains outside Parliament, opinion polls such as this can only benefit the Government.
They tell the public that even business lacks faith in the conservative leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as Mr Elliott remains out of politics his ratings will be fairly good too.

—That is an appropriate interjection because the editors of the Australian Financial Review go on in that editorial to repine that Mr Elliott's ratings remain good while he does not have to face the task of proving his mettle in one or other of the chambers of this Parliament. As soon as he does, the image of competence will evaporate. To return to the argument, the point is that no longer does business approve of the economic policies or the competence-one would say properly incompetence-with which the Opposition conducts its affairs. Business has deserted it; business approves of the Government. In comments on the day after the delivery of the May economic statement one could read in, for example, the Australian newspaper these words:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Treasurer's economic statement is a serious and impressive attempt to cut public spending and to reduce Australia's Budget deficit.
That editorial concludes:
But none of this can obscure the fact that Mr Keating's statement is an admirable contribution to the struggle for Australia's economic recovery.

That is hardly a damning indictment of the Government; certainly, from a conservative journal, it is an approving one. Other newspapers share that view. In an editorial on 14 May, headed `The Right Direction', the Canberra Times says:
Last night's economic statement by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is a step in the right direction.
It goes on to say:
The savings are significant-
and there is an answer to Senator Brownhill's point-
and should help to restore the deficit to more manageable proportions.
It concludes by saying:

Last night's statement is a step toward getting the Australian economy back on the rails and the Government deserves some credit. If the Opposition has the interest of the country at heart it will not try to score political points by arguing the case of people affected by the cuts. After all, it has been the Opposition that has urged the Government to be tough on spending.
The Sydney Daily Telegraph of the same date, commenting on the statement under the heading `First steps out of the doldrums', said:
Federal Treasurer Paul Keating last night pushed the nation in the right direction.
It concluded its editorial with this paragraph:
The Government has to keep reducing its demands on Australia's finances so that the economy can move out of the doldrums and into activity and prosperity.
Mr Keating's mini-Budget is a very valuable step in that direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are six editorials. What about six million people out in the community? What do they think of their extra telephone charges?

—I will come shortly to the market's response to the economic statement, but there is the approval given by some main journals in Australia and the business community and, as I have said, other major community organisations have greeted it with approval. The aim, of course, of this mini-Budget, as it has been called, is to shift community resources away from consumption to investment and import replacement. That aim is obviously designed to reduce our foreign debt, to make Australia's internal industrial capacity more competitive and to succeed in reducing the imports into this country. It has succeeded in doing that, according to the commentators.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the $4 billion cut is real, and in the current macroeconomic circumstances it is the most appropriate figure to have chosen. We have not cut for the sake of cutting. The cuts have been intelligently aimed to produce the best result.
