For example, the aligning of income support to teenagers who are out of work or who are seeking work with teenagers in education has removed what I think most honourable senators would regard as a long-standing anomaly. The increase in training places is good for the individuals who will be able to take advantage of it and is naturally good for the economy in that it increases the stock of skills and the technical expertise available which an expanding economy will need.

One of the little referred to changes that appears in the mini-Budget is one where the Government has managed to save $10m-one wonders why this has not been done by previous governments-simply by booking government travel through travel agencies and getting commercial discounts. That, for example, is a useful change. As other senators on the Government side have said, the cut in out of hours doctors' consultation fees is sensible and responsible in determining the efficient use of funds for Medicare and in cutting waste. If people want to take advantage of the 24-hour doctors' such as Dr Edelsten and others who have become millionaires at, I believe, public expense, they will have to bear the cost. We have managed a number of cuts-cuts in the defence area, the sale of some public assets and a number of other changes-while not touching pensions. As honourable senators will know, in the last Budget the dates of pension increases were put back. It has not been done in this mini-Budget. Pensions will go up by 5.5 per cent on 25 June, and we will be close to achieving a pension that is equal to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings in Australia.

As a result of these changes, bank interest rates have begun to fall steadily. The prime rate has come down from 18 per cent in April to about 16.25 per cent now. The 90-day bank bill rate in January this year was 17.7 per cent. It has dropped 4 per cent; yesterday it was 13.7 per cent. Home loan interest rates are teetering on the brink of a fall. I conducted an informal survey in Perth last week and found that if one wishes to borrow $50,000 to finance the purchase of a home banks are undercutting the Commonwealth Bank of Australia in order to compete for custom. One is able to get lower rates from banks such as Citibank Ltd and Challenge Bank Ltd. With that type of competition for customers it is likely that very soon interest rates for home loans generally will fall.

As I have said, all of these remarks must be seen in contrast with what the Opposition has been proposing. Mr Howard has, according to the same commentators, delivered a thin, vacuous document, one that has not enhanced any claims that he may wish to make to economic expertise. Coming as it does in the yawning absence of any Liberal Party of Australia policy on taxation, it has no credibility whatever. In this chamber we are able to look across and see the shadow spokesman on tax matters, Senator Messner. Obviously it is discomforting for him-

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not any more.
—No, he has been dropped. He is out.

—I can understand why. Obviously it is discomforting for the whole of the Opposition to know that the central plank that is necessary to an economic platform having credibility in this country-what is proposed to be done about tax changes-is still absent and the people are unable to make any decision. Indeed, on 22 March this year, a secret document was leaked. It had been drawn up by the Liberal Party secretariat as a draft policy document listing controversial spending cuts. It proposed savage cuts in the welfare area, including the scrapping of the indexation of pensions and a number of other programs. It would change the eligible age for women getting the age pension to 65 years. The authors of that document claim that their cuts would save some $5 billion, but they warned the Howard Opposition that, if they were implemented, within six months it would face a general strike in the community. That is the first point of contrast between us and them. We have managed to make the adjustments that are so necessary to the economy without that type of disruptive, dislocative and antipathetic activity.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the secret draft was leaked the Liberal Party has backed away from several of the main spending cuts it proposed. Detailed Government costings produced in the Parliament show the net savings of the complete list would come to just $2.3 billion, still $14 billion short of the cost of the Liberal Party's taxation promises. Indeed, the credibility gap is yawning more widely. In the face of what the Liberal Party proposes, interest rates and inflation rates in this country would go through the roof.

The proposals advanced in the secret document suggest the freezing of pensions, which would save $1.3 billion. Therefore, pensioners would be slammed while they watch the rich friends of the Opposition being rewarded by the scrapping of the tax on capital gains, fringe benefits and entertainment allowances and enjoying their free lunches, free cars and other fringe benefits paid for by taxpayers.

Other highlights of this so-called plan involve cutting the Medicare rebate from 85 per cent to 75 per cent, thus imposing an inequitable cost across the community; tightening up pensions and benefits for widows and supporting parents and abolishing the Schools Commission, the Department of Education and the participation and equity program. Compulsory work for the dole would be introduced, thus imposing an extra cost-it would not save anything-of $700m while freezing Public Service numbers would cost $35m because of existing plans to cut the number of staff. As I have said, all of these programs have not been fully supported since their public exposure. There have been considerable backdowns which have left a program proposing only $2.046 billion in cuts.

On 23 March Mr Blunt, the Opposition spokesman on social security, told Parliament that the Opposition would not abolish indexation of pensions. If that statement were correct, the Liberals would save less than $750m of the remaining expenditure cuts. The Liberal Party's record is one of mismanagement in government and incompetence in opposition. It stands in stark contrast to the confidence this Government enjoys, as I have said, from the market, the business community, editorial writers, commentators, and major community organisations. Therefore, it is clear that this economic statement has the support of Australians and is seen as a responsible measure. I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to debate the 1987-88 Budget initial measures introduced by the Government only a couple of weeks ago and to point out how catastrophic these measures are in terms of the real decisions that need to be made by this Government if it is to remain with any sense of economic credibility whatsoever. The statement headed `Budget 1987-88-Initial Measures' was brought down by discredited Treasurer Keating, who introduced us to the banana republic only 12 months ago. He told us that somehow he will save $4 billion on the Budget deficit. Let us look at how he will achieve that.

SPEECH.PARA: First and foremost the Treasurer says that he will get $1,000m from the sale of assets. Some of those assets include the Australian Embassy in Japan. Senator Brownhill from the National Party of Australia pointed out very clearly in his speech how that will be impossible to achieve in the situation that exists in that country. Questions overhanging the sale of that property in Tokyo concern whether capital gains tax on the sale of that property will have to be paid to the Japanese Government by this Government. Such a tax is likely to reduce substantially the amount the Australian Government would finally obtain for the sale of the property.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean the Japanese have a capital gains tax too?

—Over the years the Japanese Government has found that such a tax is appropriate to its particular circumstances. That is not the case in this country, which is a capital starved country. As the honourable senator well knows, Japan is a capital surplus country and has very considerable resources. Were it not for the fact that we are able to borrow on Japanese markets at the moment and bring in equity capital from Japan our currency would be in a most parlous state. Senator Button would know that only too well. Consequently, circumstances are entirely different in Australia. Australia does not need a capital gains tax and its introduction is entirely the wrong move for this country to make as it will destroy investment potential.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on the subject of tax, I should also mention that this Government is the highest taxing government since Federation. In 1984 it promised that it would reduce taxes; in fact it has increased them. Each year in which it has been in office we have seen a breach of its so-called trilogy. That is how much this Government thinks about taxation and the ordinary welfare of Australians. We have seen the introduction of the fringe benefits tax which has added substantially to the cost of manufacturing goods and carrying on business in this country.

I draw to the Senate's attention the very simple point that in every year in which the Fraser Government was in power the marginal rate of taxation applied to people on average weekly earnings went down; every year under the Fraser Government the tax rate on average weekly earnings went down. In March 1983, when this Government came to power, the rate of tax applicable to average weekly earnings was 30 per cent. Today the rate under this Government is 43 per cent; it has gone up by nearly 50 per cent. Is it any wonder that the average family is screaming under the pressure of tremendous taxation imposed on it by this Government? Not only that; interest rates are at astronomical levels in real terms and they are causing people to rent rather than to buy their own home. That is a most important point to realise. I will repeat it so that every honourable senator on the Government side can understand it: The marginal rate of tax for average weekly earners went down every year under the Fraser Government; it has gone up every year under the Hawke-Keating Government. That point deserves to be made over and over again.

While I am on the subject of dealing with some of the myths that the Australian Labor Party puts around, let us consider the latest one it has got on to; that is, that the foreigners overseas and our terms of trade are reducing our standard of living and that is why the Government has to take measures that appear to be harsh. The Government says that it lost $6 billion from our gross national income as a result of the change in our terms of trade. It then says: `The Fraser Government made such a mess of things back in 1982 it could not possibly have coped with the situation that has arisen during the period of this Government'. The truth of the matter is that in the 1982-83 financial year-the last year of the Fraser Government-we lost double that figure, $12 billion, from our terms of trade. Did we hear a squeak from the Labor Party about how the terms of trade had so disastrously turned against this country at that time? We witnessed a huge drought when we did not even have the volume of wheat, wool and other farm produce to sell on world markets to make up for the loss in prices, causing a fall in our terms of trade. At the time we heard nothing from the Labor Party. It just rubbished the suggestion that somehow the crisis in our economy in 1982 was due to a change in the international trading situation. Of course it was. The extent of the change in 1982 was double what this country has suffered in the last year.

The myth, the absolute shibboleth, the nonsense that is perpetrated by the Government side to try to justify its weakness in economic policy and management deserves utter condemnation. It is wrong. It is an utter lie. It has been put around by the Government to try to justify its weak decision-making capacity. It deserves to be exposed. The people of Australia should understand that nothing of an unusual character has occurred in the last year. The history of Australian trade over the last 100 years or so demonstrates that the terms of trade have always been inclined to move against this country because of its dependence on primary production and mineral products which are subject to violent change in the world market.

Those are some of the lies which ought to be put down before we start to discuss the Government's initial Budget measures as announced earlier this month. I would like to discuss one or two decisions in respect of the Industry, Technology and Commerce portfolio which were announced in the May statement. The first would have to be one of the most stupid decisions of any government I have ever seen, having been in this Parliament now for 12 years. Having observed government for many years, and going back as far as I can remember, this decision is the classic stupidity. I refer to the imposition of the new $400 concessional charges for overseas travellers returning to Australia with goods they have purchased overseas or, alternatively, within Australia from duty free shops. The decision is absolutely amazing. The charges will apply from 1 July this year, a time when a great many people travel overseas as the northern summer is viewed as the most propitious time to travel. Probably about 65,000 or more Australian tourists have now left Australia to travel overseas without any warning that when they return after 1 July they will be subject to very stringent requirements, far more stringent than those prevailing when they left the country. No arrangements appear to have been made with the Australian Customs Service as to how it will cope with such an influx of people whose goods will be subject to stringent checks, not only in respect of the value of each good they have purchased but also of their volume, quality and so on. One can imagine the streams of people at the Customs barriers after having disembarked from their aeroplanes at six o'clock in the morning, waiting to be processed by the immigration and Customs authorities--

TALK.START.PARA: —You can imagine all sorts of things. It is your greatest strength.

—I will be pleased to hear the Minister's views on how the Government is to handle this matter. There will be considerable difficulty in handling such a large volume of people with such a large number of demands, especially given the confusion there will be as to what the law is when the new arrangements come into force on 1 July 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: The spokesman of the union which represents Customs Service personnel, Mr Spanswick, has commented on how incredibly difficult it will be for Customs Service workers to patrol, look after and check the thousands of people who will enter Australia without the proper declarations and without an understanding that the law has changed. Quite apart from that, the new arrangements will have a devastating effect on the duty free shops that operate within Australia. It will be very easy for people who want to circumvent the new regulations to do so, evading the new regulations at the barrier by making declarations to Customs officers that cannot be possibly checked. If the Government is to institute a system of the proper checking of all goods that are taken out of Australia by travellers and the subsequent checking of those goods when the travellers return to ensure that the full and proper amount of duty is paid, it will mean that every item of personal jewellery, every watch, camera, pair of binoculars or any of the things which, normally, travellers take overseas with them will need to be recorded in a register so that they can be subsequently checked when the travellers return. The item will have to be codified, and consequently the full dutiable amount will be payable. Otherwise, it will be very easy for people to wear a cheap watch, for instance, cast it aside when they get overseas, buy a more expensive watch, wear it back into Australia, and in that way circumvent the Government's regulations, avoiding duty.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a creative shadow Minister!

—Creative it may be, but I would like to hear how the Government will handle the problem. The new arrangements will clearly have an impact on the duty free market in this country. As the Minister can clearly see from my example, people, instead of buying duty free watches in this country, will buy them overseas. So the original purpose of establishing a duty free goods industry in Australia, which was to keep the purchase of such goods within the country rather than overseas, will be entirely circumvented and undone. It is clear that the Government has not thought through this proposal very well.

SPEECH.PARA: The other proposition in this portfolio area that is causing concern is the new processing fee of $200 to apply to customs agents seeking a refund of duty for overpayments. Overpayments can occur for a variety of reasons. Some overpayments are not just the fault of the individual customs agent but are the result of mere human errors that occur within the Customs Service or in respect of the valuation or quantum of goods that are incorporated in documentation, documentation errors and so on. Each customs agent will be required to pay a $200 fee up front in order to be able to obtain any refund. That will apply to an individual refund rather than to a batch of refunds which is commonly the practice at present. A customs agent at present lodges many refund applications in a batch for processing through the Department. That is the normal process, which I understand is well accepted and is considered efficient on the part of both the customs Service and the customs agent.

The Government has now introduced this $200 fee which people will have to pay up front. It is akin to the payment that has to be made by taxpayers who seek to have a reference of their disputed assessment sent to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, introduced in the Budget last year. The Government is merely imposing a tax on people who want their just deserts, who want to obtain, in the case of the Customs Service, a refund of an overpayment of customs duty and, in the case of taxes, an amount which is legally due to them. They can appeal against their tax assessment, and in previous circumstances this would have cost a mere $2. This is causing a great deal of concern in the industry, naturally enough, but it is especially horrifying to know that the estimate I have seen for the average cost of processing a refund application from any customs agent is a mere $30 or $40, whereas this Government is charging a fee of $200. How can the Government possibly justify that? When the legislation passes through the Senate we will certainly ask questions in that respect.

Finally, we hear speakers from the Government side making a great deal of the way jobs have been created since this Government came to power. The fact remains that unemployment in this country is a long intractable problem that this Government has done very little to alleviate. The average time for which a person is now unemployed has just about doubled since 1983. It has gone up from an average of 26 weeks to around 46 or 47 weeks. That is a very disappointing and disturbing fact of the unemployment situation. People unable to get jobs are remaining unemployed for longer periods. Their opportunity to rejoin the work force is declining. Those people virtually have been thrown on the industrial scrap-heap.

These measures are incomplete, inadequate, and totally without foundation in terms of the reality that the people of Australia were seeking when this statement was first announced. The fact is that the Government ought to be spending a great deal more time tackling the real issues rather than presenting what is merely a cosmetic document in the way it did last Wednesday week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Government's May economic statement. We have just heard from Senator Messner, who discussed industry policy. I cannot help feeling that he indulged in a rather nit-picking exercise when he resisted commending the Government's efforts in trying to make sure that Australian products are not disadvantaged by people who travel overseas buying duty free goods. As far as I am concerned we need to look at industry in a much broader way. As we have in this May statement, we need to increase the pool of savings available for investment in Australian industry. It is this broad view of industry that we have to take. The $4 billion reduction in the 1987-88 deficit, announced in the May statement, will provide a pool of savings able to be used in import replacing and export creating Australian industry. That is what the May statement is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: The May statement therefore reflects the continuing challenge for this Government to create an industry base which can compete with the rest of the world. It is this lack of industrial base which has been the problem for so long. It is the reason behind our growing international debt and the explanation for our not having responded as quickly as possible to the J-curve effect that has been so often talked about. In other words, we have not had the export boost which was expected after the devaluation of our currency. Unfortunately, we had a number of decades of conservative government. We did not have conservative governments alone, but they were responsible, particularly in the Fraser years, for the overvalued currency and our reliance on primary products. At the same time, our industry crumbled. During the Fraser years we relied on digging up the country and not building it.

I am pleased to see that Senator Button is at the table. As Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce he has probably gained a few grey hairs as he has put package after industrial package together to make sure that Australian industry is leaner, hungrier and more export oriented. The well-known steel plan, the shipbuilding plan, the car plan, the textile, clothing and footwear plan and the heavy engineering plan are just a few of the plans with which this government has approached industry. So in the context of the May statement we can see great possibilities for our industry development. That is very important because the decline in world prices has been a serious problem for us. This process could not have occurred without complete co-operation between this Government and the trade union movement. That is one of the contrasts with the previous Government that every Australian has to face up to. Everything that the coalition parties-they are now divided parties-stand for involves confrontation and scapegoating ordinary wage and salary earners. It is part of the policy of divide and conquer that both conservative political parties stand for.

When we look at the advances made by this Government in manufacturing industry, which are reflected in increases in manufacturing, we see a contrast with the previous Government. In 1983-84 there was a 1.5 per cent increase, in 1984-85 a 2.1 per cent increase, and in 1985-86 a 4.5 per cent increase. In the last nine months we have seen manufacturing exports increase 25 per cent whereas imports rose by only 4 per cent. Industry at this moment can see that although we had a problem in the early stages with interest rates after deregulation, when billions of dollars went off-shore and we had to keep interest rates high to attract capital, now with the greater exchange rate stability that has been clearly evident in the last few months there is a pleasing drop in interest rates. That trend will continue and will soon be reflected in lower housing interest rates. Senator Cook has referred to the fact that already that movement down is starting.

The expected 5 per cent of gross domestic product deficit is going down to one per cent. So next year we will face a gross domestic product deficit of less than one per cent. This Budget statement will probably lead to great improvement in industry. Of course there are real problems that the Opposition continually skates over, such as the fact that we have had $9 billion knocked off our national income and there is a depressed world economic climate with predicted low growth in demand. For example, a recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development assessment has suggested the possibility of `a catastrophic scenario in which low growth of major economies, falling world trade and trade conflicts could produce world recession and international financial crisis'. That is a problem but nevertheless the decisions made by the Government put us in good stead even if that low growth becomes worse. We have another problem. The private sector has failed to show enough faith in Australian industry to re- invest rapidly enough in the many opportunities that exist. But the $4 billion reduction in government expenditure in the coming year represents this Government's commitment to helping overcome those problems.

I would like to focus on a particularly significant aspect of the May statement-the theme that successful restructuring of industry requires a more highly skilled and involved work force and the promotion of what might be called industry culture; that is, an environment where importance and support is given to training and retraining. In this May statement, therefore, along with the deficit reduction which will provide increased encouragement for industry, as I have said, there is also a major restructuring of education allowances and unemployment benefits which will have a particular effect on young people. This restructuring will not involve the abolition of the dole, which some people have mistakenly proposed and which unfortunately is the policy of the Opposition. In fact, 16- and 17-year-olds will continue to receive $50 per week-$25 per week as a job search component and $25 which will be subject to a fairly generous means test.

There are other important changes to social security and welfare programs all of which reflect this Government's desire to promote an industry culture. For example, in social security there is to be a reduction in the children's qualifying age for benefits for supporting parents and for widows' pensions, and the phasing out of class B widows' pensions with protection for women over 45 years of age. These women will receive greater support from the Government through the establishment of a child support agency to collect child maintenance. The most important additional training places for affected women are in the adult training scheme which will help them re-enter the work force. There is no way of pretending that these changes will not be difficult and that many women and young people could be affected adversely. I, and I believe many other senators, will make sure that the bureaucracy handles these people both sensitively and humanely.

But the other side of the coin is that the only way out of poverty and the way towards economic independence is through employment. That is what this Government is doing through its training and retraining programs. The Government's task is to ensure that, in changing eligibility for social security, there is sufficient financial and other support to ensure that the people concerned are not short changed. In the same vein, the Government announced that the community employment program is to be phased out. One of the problems of the CEP, which is reflected in its poor rate of success in helping people find work after a program is over, is that it is simply not enough to have a short period of work experience. The Government has given emphasis in its May statement towards training in the future. Work experience in itself is not sufficient to supply the needs of an increasingly skills-based industrial work place. At present nothing could be clearer than our need to make sure that people have an adequate skills base to go into industry. The phasing out of the CEP must be seen in the light of the need for training programs and the fact that simple, short term job-creation schemes are inadequate. It is very significant, and it cannot be denied, that Commonwealth spending on training programs in 1987-88 is to be 50 per cent higher than spending this financial year. That is proof of this Government's commitment to training and it reflects the Government's commitment. I believe that, where there is an increasing problem with youth unemployment throughout the world, this is the way for us to go.

In the last decade there has been a steady increase in the number of people seeking work-this is reflected in women seeking work-and the figures are still increasing. In 1982, 44 per cent of all women were in the work force. Now 49.5 per cent of all women are in the work force. So we have special problems in the areas of youth employment and women re-entering the work force. But I believe that it is a very positive thing for women to be able to take their place in the work force. The Government's creation of 750,000 jobs has been very beneficial to women wishing to come into the work force.

I am concerned that the Government is trying to change the way in which training programs will be dealt with. It has arranged for $30m to go to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. I have some concern about some worrying aspects of this because over the years I have had quite a lot of experience with technical and further education colleges, in particular the Sydney Technical College, which has 44,000 students. Although it is to be hoped that some gains will be made by TAFE as a result of changes in the Budget to the charges for hobby courses, I know that fewer than 2 per cent of the courses at the Sydney Technical College could be described as hobby courses. As the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations is naturally concerned that people have short, narrow skill courses so that they can quickly enter the work force, I am concerned that there could be a problem of increasing the load of TAFE and not making sure that the skills-based courses, which are so necessary, are properly planned and advanced within the TAFE system. In some cases money is taken away from TAFE and handed to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. We have to consider here the case of, say, a 40-year-old woman who left school at the age of 17 and now wants to return to the work force. In my view, TAFE institutions are best equipped to help these women. For example, courses such as the new opportunities for women-the NOW courses-introduce women to a range of possible work areas, such as computing, electronics, mathematics, accounting, as well as social skills such as self-confidence, an essential ingredient for any young person or any woman entering the work force, so often forgotten when people talk about re-training.

I am also aware of the participation and equity program courses. There is a difference in what is seen in some ways as a failure of PEP courses in the school area but, of course, they are a great success in the technical education field. For example, one survey of TAFE PEP courses showed that between 1984 and 1986, 76 per cent of young people doing the course found work and were in work one year later, and 44 per cent of students had enrolled in further education courses showing their success rate. A great deal of effort went into making sure that people were matched adequately with the courses and in emphasising the need for pre-training courses. So it is in this area that I hope the Government will be very careful when it considers-and I know that it will consider very carefully through various committees and through discussion-how we will advance the Government's plans to make sure that people are trained and not left to their own devices at the delicate ages of 16 and 17. I have explained that the financial incentives are virtually the same and we must make sure that we have people competing in the TAFE courses that exist at present. At the moment TAFE colleges run individual learning centres where students receive individual attention tailored to their needs. This is very important because some people who feel that they have failed at school need extra help and they need the confidence to be able to get work in industry. We must make sure that the TAFE system is able to cope with those people and we must tailor the learning programs so that people are able to take a place in industry.

I commend the Government for these developments. I believe that, in the next six months of planning time that we have, we must watch carefully to make sure that the courses are not quick courses designed to get young people off the street but that they cater for the needs of young people, and ensure that they will be in courses that will allow them to go on to further courses and take their place in industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The element of the mini-Budget affecting health is discriminatory and unfair and it impinges most on those people who are least able to protect themselves. This Government has set out to save $100m a year in one area alone. In effect, that relates to a discriminatory additional charge on privately insured hospital patients. The Government then has to raise a bit more than $100m-odd from changing the rebate system, the support system for those people who are obliged to undergo a whole range of medical treatments. There is no doubt that there is scope for saving very large amounts of money in Medicare. Of course, this has emerged from the remarkable waste and misallocation of resources that have taken place under such elements of Medicare as bulk billing and the Government's most curious socialist approach to medicine. However, it is vital to recognise the extent to which the particular measures this Government has chosen to take-while, at the same time, rejecting clear opportunities to save money that emerge through administration and in other waste-are discriminatory and unfair and the Opposition strongly objects to them. There are far better ways of saving money in the area of health if only the Government were not so committed to its Medicare madness.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Senate is well aware of the $117m that is being added to the health bills of those Australians who take out private health insurance to protect themselves from the Medicare mess. The discriminatory way in which the Government has done this has, frankly, not been defended. The Government has not even tried to defend its discriminatory approach where it is providing a massive disincentive for people to take out private health insurance, despite the fact that the people affected in this way are largely those people earning less than average weekly earnings. Something like three million people in this category have taken out private medical insurance and they, of course, in income terms will be relatively the worst hit by these uncaring and discriminatory health measures.

The people most affected by the reduction from 85 per cent to 75 per cent in the amount of benefit available for privately insured patients receiving medical treatment in hospitals are those ordinary Australians who have taken this safety first option to protect themselves and their families through private medical insurance, mainly to ensure that they are not forced to join the 100,000 Australians already waiting in public hospitals queues-some of them have been waiting as long as two years and some of them have been waiting in pain in hospital queues for treatment that, frankly, is not available to them, simply through having their Medicare cover and no more because of the pressure of demand that Medicare has generated on the public hospital system while leaving something like 9,000 empty beds throughout Australia in the private hospital system.

There is no prospect of the nonsense uttered by the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, of the bulk of the added cost involved in this area being absorbed by the private health insurance funds. That is a nonsense and the Minister knows it is a nonsense. There has been, in effect, an admission here by the Minister representing the Minister for Health that, no doubt, some of that increased cost will be conveyed to the users and, as I say, those users include three million people who are earning less than average weekly earnings.

The amount of this increased cost-which is probably around $1 a week-that will be passed on entirely to users of the private health insurance system will depend, of course, on the financial level of the funds, and some funds are in serious difficulties as a result of this Government's policies. They are the funds that have a big proportion of aged members as against those funds that have a much higher proportion of younger and healthier members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you agree that some of the reserves of half a billion dollars should be used in this way?

—The reserves should be used in the best interests of the members of those funds and if those reserves are required to protect the funds from the incidence and expected incidence of massive usage because of the age pattern of members of those funds, I think it would be improper of those funds to run down those reserves in order to accommodate an unreasonable, unfair and discriminatory charge imposed by this Government to get itself off a specific hook, a hook it has created for itself by its incompetent administration of health care in this nation. I thank the Minister for encouraging me to pursue that course.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality of this discriminatory behaviour, of course, extends beyond the area of hospital care, and the Government's activities in this area are totally indefensible. There has been no attempt by any Government speaker so far-and certainly not by the Minister on that night-to establish any honourable reason, apart from saving a quid, why the Government should be discriminating against a specific group of Australians in this way.

Let us now look at what some of the other elements of this mini-Budget package in health will do because it has some serious consequences for the users of many different medical treatments. The intriguing thing is that the Minister tried falsely to create an impression that these changes had taken place after discussions with-

TALK.START.PARA: —I would ask for a withdrawal of the expression that the Minister falsely created an impression. I think that that is a reflection on the integrity of the Minister and I ask that it be withdrawn.

—I am happy to withdraw the word `falsely'. All I shall do is demonstrate the facts that show how the Minister set out to mislead this chamber, and I will do so in this way: He claimed in his statement that there had been discussion and created an impression that these discussions had taken place with the great bulk of the medical organisations involved. That claim is false. Those discussions did not take place in any detail whatsoever. There were no detailed consultations. I have been assured by every medical body involved that there had been no detailed consultations and to pretend so, as the Minister did, is to mislead this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Again I am interested to hear the Minister's sensitivity on behalf of his colleague. There were, and I restate it, no real, meaningful consultations with the bodies involved before these major changes bringing major disadvantages to Australians-particularly sick, frail and aged Australians-were imposed on them by this uncaring and incompetent Government, certainly incompetent in the area of health care. If the Ministers in this chamber want to pursue this matter they can do so by asking the medical bodies involved what sort of consultation took place with the Minister for Health before he made his incorrect assertion in the statement that consultation had taken place. As I said, an impression was generated by the Minister that is not in accordance with the truth, but that is nothing unusual in this situation.

Now let us see who are the people who will suffer under this mini-Budget. I refer to a statement put out by the Royal Australian College of Physicians. The heading is `Chronically ill to bear most burden'. In other words, the people least able to protect themselves are those who are to suffer the greatest burden caused by one of the changes in this mini-Budget. I quote from this release from Professor Kincaid-Smith from the Royal Melbourne Hospital. She said:
The Royal Australasian College of Physicians views with alarm the reduction in health funding announced by the Treasurer.
Those with serious chronic illness will bear the major burden of these changes.
A major reduction in standards of care for patients with complicated medical conditions will result. Alternatively, this disadvantaged group will carry a considerable increase in health care costs.
An example of the sort of patient who will suffer most is someone with diabetes, heart disease and kidney failure who clearly requires more than the three visits allowed by the new arrangements.

Provisions for this type of continuing care have been cut by 40 per cent and the patient will either have to bear this cost or will have to resort to care within the already overcrowded public hospital system.
The College of Physicians has requested urgent discussions with the Department of Health about the arbitrary decisions which have led to these inequities in health care.

There was so much consultation that the College of Physicians has had to ask for it after the event; it simply did not take place before the event. In a letter to the Age, Professor Kincaid-Smith gave another example. She wrote:

. . . a patient with cancer requiring highly specialised and potentially dangerous drugs may need to have such treatment monitored over long periods by a physician who has had years of specialised training in that field. Under the new regulations that patient will now need to be supervised by a medical practitioner who has no such specialised training or join the waiting lists at a public hospital.
A patient with a chronic painful illness like rheumatoid arthritis needs continuing specialist care . . .

The list goes on and on and, as I said, people with chronic illnesses such as cancer are the ones who suffer most. The Australasian College of Dermatologists found out about these changes not by consultation but by reading the newspapers, which shows the level of the Government's consultation in this area. In respect of services 3332 to 3346, the College of Dermatologists says:

Patients requiring these services are those referred for management, because they cannot be managed by a GP, either for diagnostic and/or therapeutic reasons. Whilst an initial consultation item may cover a first visit for referred patients, follow-up treatments on a regular basis are required for many.
In the case of solar keratoses which are pre-malignant, this ensures the early detection of malignant change, in addition to allowing regular examination and treatment of lesions.
The College has been taking part each year in extensive Skin Cancer Prevention Campaigns and has always understood that you-
`you' referring to the Minister, to whom this letter is addressed-
express a contention that preventative medicine should be practised more extensively.

If patients are not fairly rebated for these regular visits for treatment and if the fee gap widens substantially, particularly for pensioners, this will act as an inevitable disincentive for such prophylactic treatment.

The relevant items numbers also cover the treatment and removal of warts. These may be on fingers or feet, for example or on genitals. Their removal can be time-consuming and difficult, requiring the injection of local anaesthetic, etc. As you know-
again, referring to the Minister-
genital warts are a sexually transmitted disease and may be pre-malignant. The procedures involved in their treatment and removal are not just a consultation.

So this is another example of a problem relating to cancer which this Government is exacerbating by its ill-considered actions which did not follow consultation with the medical profession in any meaningful way whatsoever. The Australian Medical Association complained about the discriminatory nature of the changes for patients with private health insurance. Its President, Dr Pickering, said:
These patients are being victimised by the Government.
If they are forced out of private health insurance by rises in premiums of up to $1 a week, the AMA says:
They will have to compete for access to the already overloaded public hospital system.
Dr Pickering also said:

. . . there could be adverse consequences from the wide range of reductions in benefits for individual medical services which are additional to the across-the-board cut in benefits for medical services in hospital.
Most of these individual reductions were not discussed with the medical profession. Doctors will not be able to reduce their fees in line with the reduction in benefits.
Patients will have to pay these extra costs out of their own pockets.
He said:
. . . the reductions in benefits included such important and frequently used services as consultations with physicians, C.A.T. scans and after hours consultations by general practitioners.

That matter of after hours consultations by general practitioners is a disaster, particularly for those frail aged people who depend on their local, friendly general practitioner to come to visit them at all hours of the day and night. In these days when it costs an enormous amount to get a plumber or any other service man at night this Government is reducing to something like $23 the fee for a home visit by a general practitioner at night. This is a ridiculous situation. The Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists has also objected violently. It said:
The aged and the visually disadvantaged will be the hardest hit by the new Medicare arrangements . . .
Cataracts are still the most common cause of blindness in the world today.
The most common operation performed by ophthalmologists on the aged and the visually disadvantaged is the removal of the cataract which restores their sight.

The rebate to the patient for this operation has nearly been halved meaning that patients will have to find out of their own pockets, on the average, $250 towards the cost of the operation in addition to their present charges.

There is no doubt that eye surgeons will continue to charge their present fee and that bulk billing will become a thing of the past. It is inevitable that those eye surgeons who currently bulk bill welfare patients will cease to do so-
as a result of economic pressure on them. Really this is a ridiculous situation. As claimed by the ophthalmologists:

Cataract surgery on uninsured public patients in public hospitals will almost certainly cease and those people unable to afford the above fees will be forced onto the ever-increasing public hospital waiting lists.

The Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia complained bitterly. The whole profession-everyone involved in health-has been complaining, quite properly, about the discriminatory and unfair nature of these cuts which were taken, in the main, without consultation. As the Voluntary Health Insurance Association said:
If the Government really wanted to save money it should start discussing ways in which the Medicare program can be administered by private health funds.

I must say that that fits in very well with the philosophic view of the Opposition. I conclude my remarks simply by saying that overall, over the whole range of health care, this Government has behaved in a disgraceful way in this mini-Budget. It has sought to save money by specific measures which are unfair and which particularly hit the frail aged. Yet it had an opportunity. Had it been prepared to buck its philosophic shackles and reject the proposition that Medicare and bulk billing are the answer to everything-if it had been prepared to bite that bullet-it could have done effective and reasonable things in health care which would have diminished the inefficiencies that exist within the health area. The inefficiencies have been bolstered by this Government's approach and have been multiplied by its determination to stick to Medicare and bulk billing.

There is money to be saved in the area of health-there is no doubt about that-without diminishing the quality of health care, particularly for those people who cannot afford to pay large amounts for it and for those people who are in other ways disadvantaged. Instead of that, this Government has chosen in this mini-Budget to direct its attack at those people who have sought private health insurance, those people who are frail, those people who have greater demand for the services that are listed in the Government's discriminatory attack. Of course, aged people are particularly affected by many of these specific measures. This is a most unsatisfactory mini-Budget, particularly for health.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The May economic statement was brought down less than two weeks ago, and during that period it has become clear to me and to many other senators that, in spite of media reports of accolades for the tough decisions that were made, in the wider community a great deal of demoralisation, fear and even despair has been created by many of the measures contained in the statement. It seems to me that the decisions with which the Government was faced less than two weeks ago in looking at our legitimate economic problems were made in macro terms. The problem is that the Government has failed to look at the impact of many of its decisions on the members of the community who will be most affected. It has taken some time for many of the permutations of this statement to come to light and to affect the thinking of people who have been asked to make cuts, particularly youth, women and families, especially low-income families, and even families who exist on that mythical average weekly earnings level, families with a number of children, who are faced with considerable difficulties as a result of many of the measures contained in the mini-Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: It cannot be denied that the Australian economy is between a rock and a hard place. Australia has suffered a collapse in terms of trade, a loss of overseas markets for our primary produce and resource exports due to increased competition, much of it subsidised, which has wiped out over $10 billion of our export income. Any economy would find such a collapse of income catastrophic. In an economy such as Australia's, which is internationally uncompetitive in manufactured goods and, therefore, badly placed to respond to the collapse in the commodity trade, adjustment will be slow and painful at best. No alternative exists but a fundamental restructuring of our economy and a decline in average living standards. There will have to be, as we were told by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last year, restraint with equity. However, is that what the mini-Budget contains? I do not believe so.

Let us look at the situation facing Australia's young people and the families in which they live. There has been a full year reduction in recurrent funding for higher education of $24m. That is supposed to be achieved by increased efficiency, despite the fact that funding for higher education has fallen in all but one year of the past decade and despite the fact that Australia's participation rate is still below that of any comparable Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country. The mini-Budget contains a reduction of $47.5m for 1988-89 recurrent funding for technical and further education as well as another change to the functions of TAFE. It outlines a reduction in student assistance provided by Austudy of $59.2m, despite the fact that the Government is committed, or says it is, to increasing participation in education, particularly by students from low income households. Approximately half the reduction in Austudy will come from rate changes and the other half will come from a tightening of the already over-stringent eligibility criteria, including the requirement that independent status will be given only where a person has worked a 35-hour week for three of the last four years.

The number of students on full Austudy is dramatically down and the amounts they are receiving is also dramatically down even before these changes are implemented. How they are supposed to increase equity or provide an increased incentive for students to continue in education or return to education is unexplained apart from the Humpty Dumpty logic of-to quote from the statement-`A further rationalisation of the rates and eligibility conditions has been undertaken to reinforce the Government's training and education policies and to simplify the common allowance structure'.

A significant group of young people affected by the May economic statement are those who, through inability to find work, are forced on to the social security system. Unemployment benefits for people under the age of 18 have been abolished. That has caused considerable demoralisation among young people. An inconsistency exists in the new structure that has been established, with the job search allowance of $25 a week, which implies that looking for a job costs at least $25 a week, but it provides no assistance for job seekers in the first three months in which they are seeking employment.

The statement contains a freeze on junior and intermediate unemployment benefits through which the Government wants to save an additional $32m. It also implements the two-week income test to replace the one-week income test with the rather extraordinary claim that it will provide increased scope for genuine clients to supplement their benefit payments by part time or casual work. Regardless of whether the income test is over one week or two weeks, it is inescapable that people currently on unemployment benefits can earn only $30 per week before they loose entitlement on a 50 per cent basis. The poverty traps legislation that was delayed by the Budget last year will come into play on 1 July, but the Australian Democrats believe that if the Government wants to provide an incentive for people on unemployment benefits, the area of free income limit must be looked at. Young people should be entitled to earn twice what they are currently entitled to earn as a genuine incentive to get out into the community, to get experience, to engage in entrepreneurial activities or to take up significant part-time work and find their way into the work force through their own initiatives. That claim is, at the very least, extravagant and it is some kind of window-dressing that will not make any significant difference to incentive in that area.

The same young people are those who are affected by cuts in education funding. It is extraordinary that the May economic statement contains a de facto raising of the school leaving age by the Federal Government, which does not have the responsibility for that as it is in the hands of the States. However, by the withdrawal of the unemployment benefit for people less than 18 years of age, the school leaving age, effectively, rises. At the same time, millions of dollars are being taken out of the education system and redistributed in a somewhat dubious fashion.

Even when Maggie Thatcher, the doyenne of the New Right, quite openly raised the school leaving age, she showed the good sense to sink some millions of pounds into the school system, recognising that if young people are not staying at school there must be some problem either with the school system or with the young people. On this occasion no one has gone to representatives of the school systems and asked why young people are leaving school and getting unemployment benefits. No one has asked the young people why they are not in education or training and what their problems are. The cuts have simply been made and the young people are expected to cope with them, as are the education systems-which are a State responsibility. Alongside the direct cuts in education funding, there is a cut to the funding of the States, which have the ultimate responsibility for education, particularly at the secondary level where many of those young people will be forced to stay. That is a very insensitive approach to the problems facing these young people. It is encouraging to see that groups of students who find themselves under siege following the mini-Budget-and after the previous Budget, with the implementation of the $250 fee-are beginning to express some sense of solidarity with those people under 18 years of age who previously were unemployed beneficiaries. Also in the run-up to the mini-Budget the pensioner group began to express some sort of solidarity with the student groups. It appears that the Government is targeting those people in the community who are the least able to defend themselves as being those who must accept a large measure of the restraint-restraint which we all accept must take place but which cannot be imposed to an unjust extent on these people. These groups are taking the view that they will work together in order to resist this kind of approach from the Government.

In the area of family support we see in this mini-Budget a further extension of the stress being imposed on all kinds of families at several levels of income. I refer first to the reduction of $17m in the supporting parent's benefit and class A widow's pension, achieved by stopping support once a dependent child reaches 16 years of age. I do not know whether other senators have received the sorts of telephone calls that I have received in the less than two weeks since this statement was brought down. However, I have been extremely distressed by a number of those phone calls, particularly one which I took in my office late last week. This was a call from a supporting mother with three teenage children. She had supported them for several years on her own, one of them having moved on to tertiary education, one to a college of technical and further education and the other still at secondary school. She revealed to me her concern about how she would cope for the next few years, following the shock of learning of the reduction in the age of the children on which eligibility is based from 24 years to 16 years. That is an enormous drop and one that was quite unexpected by these individuals who have been eking out an existence on this benefit. This woman also revealed to me that she had in fact attempted suicide the night before phoning my office. That kind of personal distress is not considered enough when people in government and razor gangs sit down to make decisions about who will bear the brunt of economic restraint in Australia in the 1980s.

We have also seen a reduction of $95m in family allowance payments by the application of a means test, affecting those with a gross family income above $50,000. The Australian Democrats believe that a much more preferable course is to leave family allowances as a universal payment, but they should be taxed in the hands of the recipient. I refer to the comments made by the former wife of Mr John Elliott, as published in the Melbourne Age of 22 May. She was asked whether she supported her husband's view that he should not get the family allowance and that families like his should not get it-although it was pointed out that of course he had not received the allowance as it is an allowance that goes to women, and in large measure has gone to women as the carers of children. She responded, referring to an interview between her husband and a newspaper reporter, that she thought that newspapers should be seeking the opinions of women who receive family allowances rather than men who do not. I suggest that she made a very telling point. When governments and Ministers make these decisions they should seek the opinions of those people who are going to be affected. I refer to opinions from people such as Nicole Hassett of Melbourne, who in this morning's Age outlined how enormously difficult it is for her, a student still at school and with intentions of undertaking tertiary education and a professional career, to get work experience. Of course the Commonwealth work experience program was one of the casualties in the May economic statement. Nicole Hassett is a young person who understands the importance of work experience in the whole context of a difficult employment situation. When young people attempt to obtain employment they have to face the question: What experience do you have? Nicole said that she believed that it was ironic that the Federal Government had attempted to keep students at school or in training and employment by cutting the dole for people her age, when potential employers were so unwilling to help `even on the small scale of work experience'. Not only are young people facing the barrier of lack of support from government but also the experience is that those people more fortunate than themselves are not always prepared to help them either. If the Government withdraws its support obviously it will have to do something about encouraging the private sector to pick up some of these responsibilities. I must say that past experience does not give a lot of hope for the future.

There are other aspects of the difficulties experienced by families. I refer in particular to single parent families, which of course have been hit by these reductions in the eligibility criteria for the supporting parent benefit. The Government has placed a good deal of moment on its restructuring of funding for training. Money is being taken out of the TAFE system, an existing system with programs already set up, and put into Department of Employment and Industrial Relations training programs. My concern is that these programs are not already established. Some of the supporting parents who have contacted me have asked me where these programs are, how they will get on them and, most importantly perhaps, whether they will get a job once they have been through a program. Of course, there are no such guarantees. The promise of funding for new programs is a worry, and I think it would be far more effective to continue to fund programs that are already in place rather than to shift them around and obviously delay access for those people who have been tossed off the income support that they have received in the past. Allied to this-and for many families this is of enormous concern-is the reduction over the next two years of $23m in government support for children's services, to be achieved by replacing child care centres with family day care facilities and postponing the implementation of the promised 20,000 new places.

The provision of housing-always a problem for many families-has been subject to a reduction of government support under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement of $40.9m in 1987-88 and $77.9m in 1988-89. This is despite the collapse of the housing industry and the crisis facing young families seeking housing accommodation and the tens of thousands of homeless young people. The community employment program and the job start scheme have been scrapped. The Government has withdrawn support for schemes which certainly were not perfect but which for very many people were the means of moving into an employment opportunity as a result of their having gained some experience. I do not believe that these sorts of measures can be claimed as essential to the restructuring of the Australian economy. Before I talk more specifically on that matter might I just say that the Australian Democrats deplore the reduction in overseas aid which was also outlined in the package and, of course, it is part of the package which hits at people, like those unemployed people under 18 years of age, who cannot hit back by voting at the ballot box. This reduction of $20m a year for the next two years comes on top of a reduction of $67m in the Budget last year. This is compounded by the increase in the overseas student charge to 55 per cent of full average course costs which, in effect, is a cut in foreign aid and is a counter-productive move which will make access to Australian education much more difficult for young people from low income families in neighbouring countries. That whole package demonstrates a lack of commitment in the area of overseas aid on the part of this Government and the willingness of the Government to use that area in its attempts to balance its Budget.

The May statement is a package of measures, some of which I have addressed specifically, which will not really have any substantial effect on the recovery of the Australian economy. They certainly do not represent restraint with equity. Most of the measures deal with services to those who are already considerably disadvantaged and who have suffered more than others in the community through the economic decline. The cuts represent the sacrifice that the Government felt it must make in order to appease the money markets, the business community and those members of the financial Press who clamoured for evidence that the Government was prepared to take tough decisions to get the economy back on the tracks. I do not believe that the May economic statement contained tough decisions because I do not believe it is any longer politically a tough decision to cut funding to education or reduce benefits to the unemployed. With the major opposition party attempting to outbid the Government in terms of how much government expenditure and services can be cut and with the media and the business community almost unanimous in their support for so-called `tough measures', it takes a government of some courage to maintain welfare services at a civilised level and to increase government support for education and training, even where this means that the Budget cannot be cut by the magical $3 billion or $4 billion.

The strategy behind the May statement of less than two weeks ago of reducing consumption to reduce imports, thus arresting the decline in our current account is one way of managing the economic crisis facing Australia. It is arguable to what extent the measures announced will actually reduce imports. For instance, the sale of assets-another feature of the statement-will decrease government indebtedness without decreasing net expenditure. That is akin to a person who has trouble with the family budget running out and selling some of the family silver, and is about as permanent a redress to the problem. The cut in funding to the States may not lead to decreased expenditure if the States meet the shortfall in Commonwealth funding with the savings that they have supposedly accumulated. The savings in the statement, apart from the assets sales and the reduction in grants to the States, is about $1.6 billion in 1986-87. If one applies to this the most commonly used formula for estimating the effect of reduction in total expenditure on a reduction in imports of 1 : 5, the result will be a fall in imports of only about $300m. If one assumes that the States will reduce their expenditure in line with the cut in funding and borrowing limits, the total cut in imports would be around $700m to $800m.

The reduction in overseas borrowings due to decreased Commonwealth and State borrowings will also flow through to the current account. To the extent to which these improvements in the current account take pressure off the dollar and allow interest rates to ease investment activity may pick up, and with it employment. That is one side of the balance sheet. The other side, of course, is increased unemployment due to decreased government expenditure. For example, the South Australian Government figures suggest an increase in unemployment of about 40,000, resulting from the $1 billion decrease in funding to the States. The total reduction of government spending across the board-both Commonwealth and State-is likely to reduce economic growth by about 1 1/2 per cent which will increase unemployment by about the same amount. The Treasurer's optimism that this unemployment will be soaked up by growth in export and import replacement industries is cavalier to say the least if one looks at the performance of those industries over the past two years. In fact, there has been a massive increase in investment within Australia, but little of it has flowed through to investment in the long term restructuring of Australian industry. The lion's share has gone into share trading activities as the value of companies on the Australian stock exchange has increased by more than $80,000m. This has brought a windfall profit to the Government through the capital gains tax, which passed with Democrat support, but it has done very little to improve our ability to produce tradable goods.

The need to reduce government expenditure in order to reduce the deficit stems not from excessive levels of government expenditure, but from a fall in revenue which the recent tax reforms have only partly addressed. As I, and other Democrat senators, have pointed out on numerous occasions, the use of debt rather than equity financing, particularly the use of negative gearing, has been a major source of revenue loss. The 10 April edition of Business Review Weekly lists the best 60 tax shelters. The first tax shelter mentioned for companies is `getting a proper gearing'. It states that by and large companies have greater scope for negative gearing than individuals. It points out that under present rules a company can borrow and use the borrowings to subscribe to capital in gold mining companies or to organise a takeover. The article continues:

Dividends from a takeover or from a gold mining company are exempt from tax because of the section 46 rebate. By appropriate structuring, the interest expense can be offset against the other taxable income. The imputation system, announced in December, will not change this practice.

The negative gearing restrictions on rental real estate apply to companies as well as to individuals: However, by appropriate structuring, the provisions can be avoided by owning real estate investments outright, and unmortgaged, and by borrowing against other non-real-estate assets of the company.

On the same page of the same edition of Business Review Weekly there is information on arranging one's borrowing off-shore. Some weeks ago Senator Haines asked a question of the Finance Minister regarding pre-paid S23Q schemes, which involve an arrangement for circumventing the foreign tax credits legislation. At the time the Minister said that he did not know whether such a scheme was possible, but the fact is that these schemes have been operating for some time and are presently under investigation by the Australian Taxation Office.

It is not as if there are no alternatives to hitting people who are already living below the poverty line; to striking out at young people who have their whole lives before them and who should be supported whether it is in education, training or income support; to hitting out at families who are managing on low incomes or even on average incomes where support levels are way below what one might expect in a community of this kind, where family allowances, for instance, have gone down markedly, a fact which has been noted again and again in recent times. There are alternatives in looking at how we, as a nation, can cope with the economic circumstances in which we find ourselves. The way that was pursued in the Budget of August 1986 and then again in the May statement this year is not the way to go. There are alternatives. There is not necessarily any magic in balancing the Budget either. The concept that the public sector must move over and make room for the private sector is not accepted on a prima facie basis by the Australian Democrats. Our economy can gear itself up and get back on the road again if we have a government which is prepared to do other than accept the force and pressure coming from world bankers and businessmen. In our view, it is a disgrace that this Government continues-and no doubt the Opposition will support it, as it has in past Budget legislation-to hit those people who are less able to hit back, and in this statement particularly those people who do not even have a vote at the ballot box.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the May mini-Budget. This debate should give us an opportunity to criticise the fundamental direction that the Government is taking. It is a great pity that a party such as the Australian Democrats which holds a very important position in the Senate can do little other than make mild comments, a little bit of criticism here and a little bit of acquiescence there. We just heard from Senator Powell a typical Democrats' speech. There was no fundamental criticism of the Government at all. They have made their position very clear; they are there to support the Government. They will criticise little pieces, but the fundamental thrust of what the Government is doing is being supported by them.

SPEECH.PARA: If ever an opportunity has been lost it has been lost by the Democrats on the basis that somebody should be criticising the fundamental thrust of what this Government is doing. The Democrats are neglecting that great responsibility that they have and are letting the whole of this country down. It is very important that the Australian people see that there is an alternative approach to economic management. The Democrats are not making that clear. If ever we needed evidence of the Democrats' desire to support this Government we heard it today when their leader, Senator Janine Haines, was lamenting the fact that they could not support the Government's industrial relations legislation. There was no concern about small business and no concern about sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act and the fact that the Government was about to introduce legislation which would have a disastrous effect on small business. The Democrats were there, ready to support the Government, as they have fundamentally supported it in its economic thrust.

In the few minutes that are available to me I want to point out that something different should be happening with our economic management. There is no doubt that the mini-Budget, the May statement, has made it very clear that ordinary Australians will pick up the tab for the Government's mismanagement. Youth will be hit; parents will be hit; State taxes will be increased; and telephone charges will be increased. The financial sector is to be let off scot free. It will be allowed to continue to borrow the massive amounts of money overseas so that it can continue to slush around the money markets. The Government has not attempted to tackle the fundamental problem. It is as simple as this: We are spending each year $14 billion more than we are earning. We are making up that deficit each year by borrowing $10 billion and selling $4 billion of our assets.

Anybody who has had any experience in business knows that certain fundamentals have to be followed. The first one is that if one is borrowing money to meet current expenditure rather than to put into assets that can generate more money in the future and one cannot meet the interest repayments on the money that one is borrowing, one stops borrowing. Thirty per cent of our exports goes towards paying for money that we have already borrowed. What is the Government doing? It is continuing to borrow at the rate of $10 billion a year. There is no attempt to address that fundamental problem. We have been selling out our assets for years. I first became involved in politics in 1972 because I was concerned about the rate at which we were selling out our assets. In all the years that I have been involved with politics neither the Australian Labor Party nor the Liberal Party of Australia has done anything about redressing the rate at which we have been selling out our assets. Now we are selling them out at the rate of $4 billion a year. This cannot continue. Sooner or later there will be no farm left to sell.

The rate at which we are overspending can be put in very simple terms. It can be put this way; every family in this country is spending $60 per week more than it is earning. As a nation that is what we are doing. That is a fast track to the bankruptcy court. What has this mini-Budget attempted to do? It has attempted to depress the whole economy as the only solution to slow down the rate at which we are importing, to slow down the rate at which we are spending money on consumer goods that are imported. There is no doubt that we must face up to the fact that we have to run this country as we run any business. I point out that international businesses have a higher turnover than the whole of the Australian economy. I think the first thing that we have to face up to is the need to be self-sufficient. That requires a plan-a five-year plan of self-sufficiency, I suggest. If we look at the short term five-year period ahead it becomes very clear that if we are to solve unemployment we have to increase our gross domestic product year by year. In the fifth year we will have to increase it by something like 6 per cent on the previous year. We will have to increase our exports by about 10 per cent a year compound if we are to solve our balance of payments problems. Is there any plan for self-sufficiency? No. The Government says: `We will screw the economy down a little and in that way we will stop some of our imports. In five years' time, God knows, we may not be in government.'

Before we look at this mini-Budget in detail, let us get our priorities clear. The Government is congratulating itself that it has saved $2 billion to $4 billion in expenditure, which will come off the deficit. That is a big deal, we are told. This $2 billion to $4 billion fades into insignificance when we consider that Australia increased its debt in the non-bank financial sector by a massive $43 billion last year. If anyone doubts these figures they are, plain as a pikestaff, on page 9 of the February issue of the bulletin of the Reserve Bank of Australia. The fundamental tragedy is that of this $43 billion that was borrowed by the non-bank financial sector only $5 billion went into increasing the country's productive capacity, into creating jobs. The balance, $38 billion, went into financial investment-stock market speculation and other sorts of speculation, such as buying land. We have to look only at what happened last year when $5.5 billion alone went into buying shares in Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd during the proposed takeover and defence of that company. The $5.5 billion which was borrowed mainly overseas went into the stock market, yet this Government is concerned and congratulating itself that it is cutting expenditure by $3 billion or $4 billion. We have to get the whole situation into perspective.

One of the fundamental and serious criticisms that can be made is that there has been no attempt to encourage investment in productive areas. A friend of mine has just published a very important book. He is Dr Marzouk of Macquarie University, and his book is titled `The Flow of Funds and Monetary Policy in Australia'. It has just been released. I will quote a couple of passages.
