The whole book, I might add, is addressed to the fact that there has been a massive increase in financial investment in Australia and a massive decrease in productive investment in Australia. He says:
There has been a major expansion of credit for paper investment . . .
He goes on:
. . . paper investment is largely speculative, and unproductive and represents an undesirable diversion of funds away from the creation of productive capacity . . .
He continues:
For some eight years before the Labor government came to power in 1983, the Coalition government passed policies of `fight inflation first', through fiscal restraint.
The benefit from eight years of restrictive fiscal policy, in the form of decline in the rate of inflation, was very modest . . .
He continues:

Open market operations are not sufficient to restrain the lending of NBFIs. The additional burden of restraint must fall on the only alternative available, which is direct control of the distribution of credit extended by banks and NBFIs with clear directives for all financial institutions to curtail credit for paper investment under the Reserve Bank of Australia Act 1959 and the Banking Act 1959.
I also quote this passage from Dr Marzouk's book:
James Tobin, Nobel-Laureate in economics, examined the efficiency of the financial system in the United States.

He expressed a suspicion that the immense power of the computer was being harnessed to this `paper economy', not to do the same transactions more economically, but to balloon the quantity and variety of financial exchange.
These observations by Tobin apply with equal, if not greater force, to Australia which has deregulated the financial system further than has the United States or any other developed market economy,

I do not know what it is about Australians and Australian governments but they seem to think they have to do things better and go to greater extremes than any other country. As Dr Marzouk pointed out, we have now deregulated our economy to a greater degree than has any other Western country. Why do we want to break records-all the time? Why do we have to go extremes, particularly when there is a lot of criticism by people such as Tobin, who is an authority on economics, about the degree of deregulation of the United States market, which is nowhere near as deregulated as the Australian economy? We are going from extreme to extreme.

Let me turn to what should be done to get ourselves out of this mess. First of all, obviously, we have to tell the banks and the non-bank financial institutions that they should restrict lending for stock exchange speculation and encourage lending for productive investment. That is fairly obvious. The next obvious thing we must do if we are to run our economy in a businesslike way is to work harder. We have to earn more foreign exchange. It is obvious to anybody with even half an eye that the only avenue for doing that is to expand our manufacturing industries. There is nothing very new about the situation now but I must point out to the Senate that I said that about 12 months ago; everybody is saying it now.

What is the Government doing about encouraging our export of manufactured goods? It is doing very little I believe. It is busy reducing the protection that industry has. It is busy talking about new car plans but there has been no dramatic and fundamental approach. We need some dramatic solutions, we need to reduce dramatically the amount of money we are spending on consumer products and we need to increase our exports dramatically. This means that we have to get our manufacturing industries efficient and we have to do it quickly. We have to follow the best of what has been done in Japan. We have to encourage worker participation. I would have thought that we have to get an alternative to centralised wage fixing, such as collective agreements.

The industrial legislation that the Australian Democrats were so keen to support made it very clear that there was to be no opting out at all and that all agreements had to be centralised through the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That is a fundamental mistake: There should be a clear option, an option that is not forced on industry or the trade union movement, to centralise wage fixing so that industries can negotiate together with the unions and management on a broad range of issues-which includes worker participation, work practices, penalty rates and so forth-as well as a system of wage fixing by agreement which is independent of the centralised system. This should be done on an enterprise by enterprise basis so that the conditions and situations that apply to an enterprise's particular work place can be negotiated. Of course, this is particularly important for small business. It is small business that will be at the cutting edge of Australia's salvation, if we are to be saved.

I need hardly remind the Senate that small business represents some 65 per cent of the work force. There are some 800,000 small businesses and small business has to be the engine of the future. But has the Government done anything to solve the problems of small business?

TALK.START.PARA: —They are going broke by the day and the week.

—Enormous numbers of small businesses are going broke but nothing is being done about it. Nothing is being done to encourage the entrepreneur. The much vaunted tax package has virtually been nullified by the fact that the Government has refused to index personal income tax. So any income tax cuts that the Government gives on the one hand on the other hand are well and truly overtaken by inflation by the time we actually get them. We still have to pass the imputation legislation. I hope we will get the opportunity of doing that before the Government calls an early election.

SPEECH.PARA: Small business has to be encouraged and that means we have to have some innovative and exciting initiatives. We should not screw the economy down and congratulate ourselves because we saved $2 billion of expenditure. I am not saying that there is not any government waste. Certainly some urgent consideration has to be given to government waste but that is not an excuse for not facing the fundamentals which are our balance of payments and the amount of money that is being borrowed overseas. On the positive side, it is no excuse for not facing the problems that are inhibiting small businesses and the Australian entrepreneur from developing new products that have export potential and new markets.

I would have loved to see a political party in this country that represented farmers, small businesses and manufacturers. They are the powerhouse of our economy. Instead, we have political parties representing one of those sectors of the economy and not the others. Consequently, there is dissension, political debate and no cohesive approach to getting a forward plan that will get us out of this problem. I worry about the future of my country. For some years I have stood in this place as an industrialist. I wish more people who have had experience in business and industry were prepared to be senators. There are some but they are very few. We have to run the country as a business and we have to come up with innovative solutions to the big, deep problems that are now facing us.

When I first became involved in politics I had a vision: I wanted to see an Australia that was the sort of country I enjoyed when I was a kid. That vision is disappearing rapidly. It is a great tragedy that the vision we are putting before our young people today is lengthening dole queues, the danger of an acquired immune deficiency syndrome epidemic, drugs and so on. There is no incentive before our young people. It is symptomatic of the attitude of governments today that one of the areas the Government attacked in this mini-Budget was that of young people. The facts are very clear. Twenty-five per cent of the people aged between 16 and 20 are unemployed. Presumably, those figures are accurate; they speak for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is wrong. Twenty-two per cent of those on the labour market. Nine per cent of the age cohort is unemployed. The rest of them are in school.

—I am not able to dissect the Minister's comment at this stage. It is new to me. I have looked only at the overall figures. The last figure I saw was very close to 25 per cent. Whatever excuse one can give for that sort of a figure, the fact is that a large number of young people are not able to get work. I know that from experience. Many people have not been able to make the grade in secondary school and certainly have no hope of making the grade in tertiary education. Many people are not qualified to learn a trade. What are we to do with those people? They have opted out of secondary school. Are we going to leave them on the scrap-heap?

SPEECH.PARA: It is amazing how many young people who apply for employment cannot read or write. I can guarantee that at the technical school I was attending at the age of 14 not one student could not read and write. Yet that same technical school today, which is located close to a factory in which I have a direct interest, is turning out large numbers of students who cannot read or write. I ask: Why is this happening? It is happening, without a doubt. What are we going to say to the people who have gone through secondary school but who cannot read or write? Are we going to say: `You are unemployable for the rest of your life?' There are ways of getting those people into the work force. They can be encouraged into the work force on the basis of permanent part time work. We can give them one day's work per week on a permanent basis, which is what I have done in a company I am associated with. One is amazed at the change of attitude and the enthusiasm that is very quickly engendered.

I have spoken on this matter before in the Senate. I have implored the Government to do something about permanent part time work. The Government has tried every other solution under the sun, but not permanent part time work. Is the Government going to face up to these young people who are illiterate, the products of our secondary schools, or is it going to say to them: `You are unemployed and, what is more, you are not going to get the dole'? Many of these young people have left home because their parents have abandoned them, or for whatever reasons. Presumably, they will scratch out a living by thieving or whatever because they will have no other means of support if the Government refuses to give them at least some basic unemployment benefit.

The mini-Budget can also be severely criticised on the basis that many things were done which were not made clear in the speech by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the matter. This comment is appropriate, more than anything else, to the May statement's effect on women. There was no mention in the Treasurer's speech that the Government was to reduce its commitment to child care centres. The Government originally pledged to increase the number of child care centres. Apparently, that pledge is now to be discarded and there is to be a scaling down of new facilities. There was no mention of the fact that class B widow's pensions were to be scaled down and eventually to be cut out.

I conclude by saying again that it is ordinary Australians who are picking up the tab for this Government's mismanagement. I do not know why there is not more criticism of the Government and more comment about a fundamentally new direction for economic management. I cannot understand why members of the Labor Party are not concerned about this. I am amazed that the best the Liberal Party can do, through Mr Howard, is to say: `The Government's policies are really our policies. The Government is pinching ideas we had. We think it is a great idea to deregulate the economy. We wish we had been able to do it before the Government did it'. That is essentially what the Liberals are saying. There is no fundamental criticism or constructive suggestions about a change of direction. The Liberals are saying: `Deregulate further. We will deregulate the labour market as well, and let the law of the jungle apply there'.

Until somebody is prepared to stand up in this place and say that there is another way of managing the economy, that there is a case to be made out, as I have said, supported by academics around this country, for some direction for the banks and the non-bank financial institutions to encourage investment in productive areas-nobody in this Parliament is standing up and saying it-I will continue, as leader of the Unite Australia Party and as its sole parliamentary representative, to say with all the vigour I can that, unless we change direction, this country is headed for disaster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is discussing the `Budget 1987-88-Initial Measures, May 1987-ministerial statement'. I have the unfortunate pleasure of following Senator Siddons in debate. Senator Siddons went on at some length and in some depth about the happenings in the Australian Democrats and criticisms of their policies and performance in this place. I think we have to give some credibility to the honourable senator's criticism because only very recently Senator Siddons was a leading member of that political party. Senator Siddons, unfortunately, went on to criticise the May economic statement and the performance of the Hawke Labor Government, which has been in office since 1983. When we look for ideas of what we can do to correct the ills of society, all Senator Siddons can offer us is a proposal to put young unemployed youth to work for one day a week. I am afraid that it will take quite a deal more than that. It will need in-depth research.

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably a pity that Senator Siddons is the only member of his party in this place because, although factions can be dangerous in a political party, as the Liberal Party and the National Party know only too well at present, they provide the opportunity for a divergence of opinions. When one gets a divergence of opinions other ideas come forward. If all that is to come out of the Unite Australia Party are the views espoused by one Senator Siddons, it is unfortunate. The Australian population deserves a little more. However, I want to confine my statements to the May economic statement. I will be critical of some aspects of it. As I said, it is difficult to contain factions within a political party but they can be of positive assistance to the party. I hope I will be making my criticisms tonight in a constructive fashion because they are meant to be made in a constructive fashion.

The statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 13 May has been widely hailed as a work of economic and political wisdom and responsibility. Times are tough, a point I shall expand on shortly. One of the pluses Australians have is that they have a government that is made up of people of talent. It is very talented and has a very talented Cabinet. It is prepared to face the realities of the situation we find ourselves in. How disastrous it would be if our destiny had to be directed by the sad, ragtag assortment of political simpletons who sit opposite, who have been brought to the brink of political extinction by their Leader, John Howard, whilst the mad dogs of the New Right snap at their reluctant heels which drag in the wet grass. The Liberal Party had no tax policy or economic policy-despite today's leaks; we saw its Leader denying them on television tonight. It follows that the Liberal Party has no idea how to tackle the ills that beset the national economy at this time. All its leadership can do, including the shadow spokes- person, is carp at the Government's initiatives and wait and hope that the Government will make some mistakes. I assure those opposite that with all the talent that is available on this side of the Parliament Mr Howard will be waiting a long time, even if his colleagues are prepared to give him the chance to wait.

The May statement needs to be put in the context of the national economy, which in turn has to be looked at in the context of world trade. This country owes $105 billion in foreign debt. That could be put forward as an indictment on this Government, but it is not all our doing. Only 20 per cent of that debt is directly attributable to us and a lot of it came about because of what we inherited in 1983. Of the $105 billion in foreign debt 60 per cent is owed by the private sector. We have some difficulties in our terms of trade as well. The prices of many of the commodities which Australia depends on for its export earnings have fallen dramatically on world markets. Australia's national income has been slashed by $9 billion. Commodities such as wheat and barley have had their value almost halved from their high point back at the start of this decade. Beef, coking coal, iron ore, copper, lead, nickel and steaming coal form part of the casualty list of world prices for our staple export items. The list goes on.

The extraordinary situation which Australia faced coming up to the Budget required extraordinary action by the Government. The Ministers who make up the Expenditure Review Committee went about their task thoroughly and bravely. No Treasurer wants to volunteer to hand down a Budget which claws back 2 per cent of government expenditure in what is likely to be an election year. The $4 billion that has been pared from the deficit represents the highest cutback-
