—Order! There is no point of order. I am certain that Senator McKiernan has copious notes.

—He has indeed. I am more than prepared to show the copious notes to the honourable senator should she so wish. The honourable senator must remember that I got my education back in Ireland. I have to go through a process of translation in picking up the notes I have. The $4 billion cut from the deficit represents the highest cutback made by an Australian government for something like 30 years. It is not my purpose, particularly as a left wing member of the Australian Labor Party, to eulogise all aspects of the mini-Budget but the fact that cuts of such magnitude could be made and be so widely accepted by the community has to be an indication that the Budget process which the Expenditure Review Committee went through was carried out with skill and aplomb. The Treasurer and his colleagues addressed the political and economic realities and got the balance largely right. The Australian people, after examining the statement delivered two weeks ago, recognise the economic realities and the dangers we face and generally have expressed appreciation of the steps that the Government has taken.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar, Mr Carlton, believes that it is his duty to carp and criticise-and indeed it is. But he takes it a step further. Not only does he have a go at the Government, which is his rightful duty, but also he has a go at those who seek to analyse what the Government has done and give credit to it, and turns his back on what has been an area of traditional support for his Party-the business sector. There was a reference to that in the West Australian on 20 May this year. It said `Carlton criticises business'. The once great Liberal Party is turning its back on those who used to support it. But is it any wonder that the business community is not looking to the Liberals at the moment?

As I said, there is little time available to speak on this subject tonight and I do not intend to run the whole 30 minutes allocated to address all of the specifics contained in the statement. But a number of them are worthy of comment, such as the removal of access to the unemployment benefit for 16- and 17-year-olds. It is a radical measure, one that must be backed up by resources which are devoted to training and job creation for this group. We note in the statement that an additional $32m will be allocated from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations for this purpose. We will be watching this matter with care to ensure that that money is used up, is well spent and will create real jobs for those young people.

Regarding changes in family allowances, perhaps I will take up what Senator Powell said earlier-that rather than implementing this change we could have looked at changes to the dependent spouse rebate. We could have done it for the following reason: Family allowances are generally paid to the woman in the family whereas the dependent spouse rebate is paid to the breadwinner, which in the case of a single income family is usually the male of the species. Perhaps it might have been better to have effected the savings through the dependent spouse rebate rather than through the family allowance. However, people whose incomes exceed $50,000 a year generally are in the best position to be able to look after themselves. In the context of the situation at the moment generally it is an equitable decision.

I have a few quarrels with the means testing of various allowances, including assets testing people over 25 years old who receive unemployment or sickness benefits. We are in very difficult times. We note and are concerned that there are to be considerable savings in the health portfolio. When we read and heard the announcement that there would be a saving of $121m in this arena we certainly were somewhat scared. However, we congratulate the Government on the fact that the current level of 85 per cent rebate for Medicare is being retained, together with the maximum patient payment of $20. Doctors have been asked to show constraint. Unfortunately, they are not community leaders by showing constraint when it comes to incomes. But hopefully it is not just wishful thinking on our part that they will contribute as well as the rest of the community that has been asked to contribute.

The abolition of the community employment program is another area of concern. I would have preferred this program to be maintained, perhaps in a different form. Certainly the CEP has been one of the most successful job creation schemes that we have witnessed. Not only has it provided employment for individuals but also it has given communities at a local level many benefits and assets that they would not have got through normal processes. For those people who took part in the program--

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not provided any permanent jobs.

—They were only temporary but they were additional benefits of the program. Unemployment not only concerns the hip pocket nerve; it affects the morale of the individual. If an individual is unemployed-particularly a young individual who has never been in a work force-for any length of time that person gets very demoralised. The CEP program assisted in breaking that demoralisation and in giving the individual some confidence to go out and enter the work stream.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area of concern is road funding. One hundred and eighty million dollars is a lot of money to come off road funding. One would have to admit that this would inevitably lead to a reduction in the number of jobs. At the best of times it is difficult to tackle the question of roads because the other question of road safety is raised. I trust that the Expenditure Review Committee, in making its very difficult decisions, took this question into account.

I believe that the thrust of the mini-Budget was directed at business, to give it the incentive to invest and, therefore, to create jobs. Hopefully if this takes place the jobs that will be created will take up the slack that has been lost in the areas of the community employment program and road funding. It is something that we hope for. I believe that the vast bulk of business people will take up the challenge, will get out and invest, and in turn will create those much needed jobs in the community at the moment. I take it as a positive sign, a sign that the restraint shown by working taxpayers in Australia which has been exercised for a period will be rewarded by this reinvestment and expansion in the private sector. I could think of nothing more obscene than if the opportunity which has been given to the business community is frittered away by expanding dividends and short term profits to the shareholders, or speculative profits to those sharks involved in the takeover games. If this happens I do not believe that Australians will either forgive or forget. Although we wish that the terms of trade will continue to decline, certainly our Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, is doing the best he can so that this will not happen. But I think the signs are ominous in a number of areas. If further cuts are required in the August Budget there are areas to which I think the Government should direct its attention. In order to get accurate information as to where we can direct our attention I believe that an inquiry into wealth in Australia is an absolute necessity.

TALK.START.PARA: —An inquiry into what?

—A wealth inquiry. We have been asking for it for some time. We have some commitments in this area but other things have pushed it to the back burner. Now that the country is in a difficult situation an inquiry into wealth, ownership and distribution would be timely. Another area at which we ought to look is the way in which superannuation funds make profits from investments. Perhaps that is an area at which the Government ought to look if it needs more money. I mentioned earlier the dependent spouse rebate. The Government, in its May economic statement, has announced that it will dispose of some assets. Whilst my philosophy urges me to approach this area with caution I do not have any real qualms about the decisions that the Government has made in this area. If the Government had been tackling Australian Airlines, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Qantas Airways Ltd or the Australian Telecommunications Commission-I will have something to say about Telecom later-or some other major enterprises owned by the Australian public I might have had a different attitude and perhaps I would have said something stronger about it but I think the Government has reached a balanced decision on the disposal of assets. If we are forced in to a position where we have to sell assets or, as Senator Siddons said in his contribution, to sell off parts of the farm, there are other areas at which we can look.

SPEECH.PARA: I might be criticised for my philistine approach to things. Fairly recently I had the dubious pleasure of visiting the Australian National Gallery-a gallery that is supposed to hold works of art which are of inestimable value, including Blue Poles. I mention that only because it is the most famous. I am not an arty-crafty person. Blue Poles is supposed to be worth 10 times in excess of what we paid for it. It is worth in excess of $10m now. If we have to sell off assets and there is a demand for some of those priceless works of art let us relieve Australians of the burden they have in holding them in the Gallery-a place which does not even have the money to put out programs for kids. If one goes into the gallery with two kids one gets only one directional map. Let us have a look at things such as paintings and treasures of the nation which are seen only by relatively few people. I am not picking particularly on Blue Poles. There were many other things on display in the art gallery on the day on which I visited which perhaps are priceless-I certainly would not have a number of them in my lounge room-and which we could dispose of. Obviously, if the National Gallery has bought them they must be of use to some people. Let us auction off some of the things like that to boost the Commonwealth's coffers and perhaps we might not have to look at cutting expenditure in other areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a philistine. It is not in your character.

—I still have doubts as to whether I am a philistine, but when times are tough we have to make tough decisions and, if it is a hard decision to flog off Blue Poles, that is a decision that ought to be made. If it will save $10m, $12m or $15m of government expenditure in another area I would think it would be money well saved. Another area in the May economic statement on which I will not dwell and with which I am not particularly happy is the slower implementation of the heavy engineering assistance package-a cut of some $10m. I think it is unfortunate that that has happened as it is an area of industry that badly needs a shot in the arm. It is an area that has shown increased co-operation between all the sectors involved in it-co-operation that in part is built upon by this heavy engineering assistance package.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that I would return to the matter of Telecom. Usually, when governments bring down statements such as this-as we saw in this morning's newspapers-individuals, organisations or groups go out and bucket it and have a knee-jerk reaction to what is contained in it. A Press statement was put out by Mr Brack, the Chairman of Telecom, and it was released by Keith Hainsworth, National Manager of Media. Telecom's reaction should be condemned by all of us in unison, irrespective of what side of the House we sit on and what political party we follow. As a supporter of Telecom I expected something a little better than an immediate call on the Government to allow it to increase local charges by about 3c-from 18c to 21c-and to increase the subscriber trunk dialling charges for short distances by 16.7 per cent, medium distances by 11 per cent and long distances by 5 per cent. Telecom has said that it will have to reduce staff by some 3 per cent. It will have to reduce spending on equipment in Australia by about $50m which, in turn, causes unemployment in the local manufacturing area. Telecom will also have to curtail the rural and remote program and the 1990 completion date that has been set will not be met. I think it is a deplorable state of affairs that an authority such as Telecom that is held in very high esteem in the community should react in this fashion and put out a three-page Press release which one would have expected from the corporate sector but which the corporate sector did not do. I think the corporate sector will pull its weight in the difficult times we are in but unfortunately we get a government instrumentality, such as Telecom, which goes for the easy fix. It might be an easy fix for Telecom but I assure Telecom and its supporters that it is not an easy fix for the Australian community, particularly those people in remote regions who are heavily dependent upon the services that Telecom offers.

I understand that Telecom will have to put a submission to the Prices Surveillance Authority requesting that it be allowed to increase the charges. I hope that our Government will bitterly and vigorously oppose any increase in charges so that Telecom, its management and the various experts that it employs who are well known to everyone in this chamber-I have some doubts about the experts-can be forced into examining the areas in which they can cut back and face the tough times as the rest of us are doing. I find Telecom's argument amazing because it recently made submissions to a couple of Caucus committees in which I am involved on the question of whether it should pay customs duty on its imports. Of course, one of the elements of the May economic statement was that Telecom would have to pay duty. I think it amounts to $75m or $80m a year. A couple of `experts' from Telecom addressed the Committee and they were not able to answer our questions. They then said that they would provide us with written submissions afterwards. I shall quote from part of a letter that was received by the chairman of one of the committees. The letter was from Mr R. P. Liggett, the Director of Finance of Telecom. I shall quote just a small part of the letter:
The first is on import substitution and looks at the issue from a macro point of view concluding that the change in the A$ is of more significance than the possible introduction of customs duty.

I did not hear anything from Telecom prior to 13 May about a demand for increases in charges, yet we are told by the Director of finance that the devaluation of the Australian dollar is having a tremendous impact on Telecom. In my view, the Australian people and the Australian public are deserving of better treatment than they are receiving from Telecom at present. I commend the measures-although I have been critical of some parts but overall it is a responsible package-taken in the May economic statement to this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the left wing spokesman from the Government side and I thought he contributed quite a few interesting points.
—Despite being a philistine?

—He claimed he was being like a philistine but I think some of the points he made contained some sense and he recognised that the Government was running into serious difficulties with the economy because it has certainly recognised that the economy of Australia is fraught with fundamental problems. That is the reason why the Government at last recognised the wisdom of the Opposition's urging that it should bring down a mini-Budget or an economic statement as it did this month.

SPEECH.PARA: It should have, too, because the reasons for the economic chaos are abundantly clear, or are abundantly clear to senators on this side of the House. They become quite apparent when one has regard to the fact that we have a very low productivity growth, a high cost structure, a massive external imbalance and a large public sector deficit. All of these, of course, have to be corrected if Australia is to reverse the experience of recent years, which has resulted in falling living standards. After four years of the Labor Government it has got a pretty impressive record, and this has been mentioned by honourable members on this side of the House during the debate. Senator Short commented that the Hawke Government is the biggest spending government ever, spending 29.7 per cent of the gross domestic product in 1984-85. The four Keating Budgets are the four biggest Budgets Australia has ever witnessed. The Government has certainly evidenced itself as a big spending government in 1986-87, when 24.8 per cent of the gross domestic product was expended.

The Government has presided over the lowest value of the Australian dollar ever, so far as I am concerned, and it has also imposed considerable pressures on home buyers in Australia because home loan interest rates are 15.5 per cent. If one uses a bankcard one experiences interest rates of 23 per cent for that facility.

TALK.START.PARA: —An almost unbelievable figure.

—It is an unbelievable figure and, regrettably, it is causing a tremendous amount of difficulty not only among small businesses and businesses at large but also for the average householder in Australia. The small overdraft interest rate is another example of what has happened under the Hawke Government. It is 21 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government has presided over the largest foreign debt Australia has ever experienced-$105 billion at the end of December 1986, which is the equivalent of something like $26,000 for every Australian family. One finds that Australia, under the Hawke Labor Government, has the worst inflation rate ever of any member of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Australia's rate of 9 per cent is almost four times the OECD average of 2.4 per cent. The Government has also contributed to the largest current deficit ever in our history. It was 6 per cent of GDP in 1985-86, the second worst in the Western World in 1986 and in 1987 it was exceeded only by Norway, so it is no wonder the Government had to submit to the pressures exerted by the Opposition and bring down a mini-Budget as it did recently.

I have heard comments concerning the attitude of the Government to the dole. I think the Government has adopted a responsible attitude there. I have always said that Australian parents should not abandon their children when their children leave school. The responsibility of a parent is to ensure that the child is looked after, if possible, until the child obtains employment. In Australia today plenty of jobs are available. According to the statistics some 65,000 jobs are available but I think that is the tip of the iceberg. I believe there are many other jobs available if people are anxious enough to seek employment. Certainly, a person may not find the job he would want to enjoy for the rest of his life-that certainly may not be so-but in the interim jobs are available.

I was in Melbourne a few months ago and I was talking to a hotel manager who said that he could not find anybody to clean the windows in Collins Street. It is not a very difficult job. The windows are not up high, they are on street level. The contractor to whom he spoke would have been happy to do the work but he cannot find anybody from the Commonwealth Employment Office to take the job. He would otherwise have been able to do the job. So, fairly simple work is available for people. Illiterate though they may be, they can still clean windows. Senator McKiernan talked about the community employment program and the fact that it is now being discarded. I can understand that because until last year, from memory, $1.4 billion was spent on CEP projects. On many occasions Senator Short has raised the matter of the Footscray swimming pool. Initially the cost of that was estimated to be $2.8m, and now it has escalated to $6.5m.

TALK.START.PARA: —An absolute scandal!

—It is a scandal because at one time, for many hundreds of thousands of dollars, all that had been obtained was a hole in the ground. That sort of project is not peculiar to Victoria. In South Australia we have had evidence of how these CEP projects have escalated in cost. The King William Road pavement project, which was carried out not far from where I live, was supposed to cost of the order of $3m. It escalated to over $5m. The number of people employed on that project, from memory, was about 54 and of that number only two were able to find permanent employment at the end of that project. It is quite clear that the Government has recognised that the money expended on that program has not been directed properly and that there are other ways in which people can be encouraged to find employment.

SPEECH.PARA: For a few moments I would like to refer to the effects of the statement on medical services. Senator Michael Baume dwelt on this matter earlier in the debate. The Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, proclaimed that although $208m has been cut from the Medicare budget. The reduction will be made `without any alteration to the fundamental principles of Medicare'. I am sure that $208m could be cut from the Medicare budget without adversely affecting health services for Australians, but I doubt whether the Minister or his Department could administer those cuts efficiently. The Minister proudly claimed:

The Hawke Government's universal health insurance system, introduced in February 1984 and based on an equitable levy on income, would continue to protect all Australians against the high cost of medical and hospital treatment. Medicare remains the fairest health insurance system ever established in this country.
Many years ago the Whitlam Government introduced Medibank. I remember at the time that the late Allan Fraser-probably one of the most intelligent Frasers to have been in this Parliament--

TALK.START.PARA: —All the Frasers were intelligent.

—Yes, but some were more intelligent than others. He roundly condemned that initiative of the Whitlam Government as a fraud. He was proven correct over Medibank and I think that Medicare is even worse than its predecessor. Of course, Allan Fraser knew something about medical services because he was chairman of the board which had run the Canberra community hospital for about 20 years before Medibank was introduced. Senator Michael Baume has demonstrated that in the last year the cost of health care to the average family which is privately insured has risen by $175 over and above the $75 rise due to the last Budget and the additional $50 caused by the 25 per cent increase in the Medicare levy. Health costs rose by 18.5 per cent last year. That is double the national inflation rate, even though the Medicare levy is not included in the consumer price index. The May statement will effectively cause health costs to rise further, and the waiting lists for hospitalisation will undoubtedly lengthen. The Minister, however, continues to boast in his typical way about fairness and about what he describes as the best of medical services that are being provided in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to reduce by 43 per cent in-patient remuneration for repeat consultations will have a devastating effect on the standards of practice of internal medicine. I was an optometrist prior to coming to Parliament and I still have some knowledge of my former profession. I note that item 180-which is an initial consultation fee which applies to refractions and which used to be payable once every year-will now be payable every two years. I think that is fair enough for the average patient, but there are a number of cases where this may not be quite equitable. For example, I cite the case of a young child who has myopia during its formative years. That myopic condition can increase. Even in six months that child may need further refractive treatment and the provision of additional correction. Those sorts of cases really need to be catered for.

I hope that the Minister and the Government will recognise that that sort of case, where it is clinically necessary to see the patient more frequently and provide spectacles more frequently than every two years, needs special attention. Of course, when the average person in Australia reaches the age of 40 he could conceivably require attention every 12 months or so, particularly if the intraocular tension-the tension within the eyeball-is elevated to a stage where it needs to be looked at every six months to ensure that that patient is not a glaucoma case. There are other cases where seeing the patient more frequently could be described as being clinically necessary. I refer to diabetic conditions and so on. I hope that the Government will recognise that there are a few anomalies in this regard and that those patients need special attention.

Also, I heard Senator Peter Baume ask a question earlier today about specialist physician treatments. From reading the statement I understand that the new provisions permit patients a full rebate for only three visits to a consultant physician whereas patients often require management by a consultant physician over days or even weeks for an acute condition, and for months or even years for a chronic condition. I think that this decision that has been made in the context of this May economic statement is unfortunate.

Also, a patient with cancer requiring highly specialised and potentially dangerous drugs may need to have such treatment monitored over long periods by a physician who has had years of experience in that special area of medical treatment. Under the new regulations, I understand that the patient will now need to be supervised by a medical practitioner who has no real specialised knowledge or training or, alternatively, queue up on the waiting lists for treatment at a public hospital. A patient with a chronic illness such as rheumatoid arthritis needs continuing specialist care, not only for optimum control of joint inflammation but also to reduce the crippling effects and serious complications of this very serious complaint.

I have referred to the diabetic patient in an ocular sense. Complications can affect the heart, the eye, the kidneys and major arteries. Continuous management by a consultant physician is required in order to save sight, prevent kidney failure and reduce the risk of heart attack. The only way in which patients suffering from that sort of complaint can now be dealt with and given the necessary services is apparently to pay for them themselves, because they will receive only a fairly trifling amount from their private health fund or Medicare. The only alternative for them is to resort to the already overcrowded public hospital system. I think that there are aspects in that area that need to be watched very carefully to ensure that the standard of treatment does not deteriorate to the extent that the health of the people of Australia is endangered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why can't the consultant physician refer the person back to the general practitioner? I am asking this as a general question.

—They can do that. I am talking about the more serious cases such as the optometric patients who, for clinically obvious reasons, need more frequent attention. Certainly, there are cases that could be referred back to the general practitioner.
—And are.

—That is right. When I spoke earlier, I was really referring to the chronically affected people. The Minister needs to have some compassion and regard for them. I imagine that either the Minister or the Department has the capacity to be flexible in those cases.
—Not the Minister.
—Senator Townley has joined me in the chamber. I would like to think that even the Minister would have some ability to recognise the cases to which I was referring.
—He used to, but he has become a Minister.
—It happens sometimes that Ministers lose the personal touch and the humane approach and become borne down by the heavy load of economic responsibility.
—And the necessity to fix up an early election.

—Yes; it is interesting that the Government has withdrawn its industrial relations package, which gives me some reason to suspect that it does not want to carry on too much longer and wants to go to the people before the disaster of its economic management becomes more abundantly clear.

SPEECH.PARA: I register my disapproval of the Minister's action in denying financial support to long-established organisations which obtain most of their funds from public donations but which have expected to receive some financial assistance from the Government. I refer to organisations such as the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia, the Association for the Welfare of Children in Hospital and the Australian Brain Foundation, all of which have been denied funds while the friends of the Minister have been rewarded. I refer to groups such as the Australian Consumers Medical Association and the Students Initiative in Community Health. Those groups seem to be able to attract abundant funds, but the other organisations that attract donations from people such as Senator Townley and others who recognise the importance of public contributions to these associations have been denied the support of the Government.

These organisations are dedicated to promoting the interests of the people they choose to serve in an honorary capacity. I hope the Government will recognise the points I have made with respect to chronically ill patients and patients of physicians to whom I have referred. I hope it will introduce some humane flexibility in its approach to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Towards the end of his speech, Senator Jessop made some good points. He referred to the fact that certain institutions and organisations need help from the public purse. In our charge down the path of reducing public expenditure, it is well to remember, as Senator Jessop has done, that some demands can legitimately be made on the public purse. In the end, we are not a collection of individuals but a community that should pull together.
—You are a socialist after all.

—I am a man committed to his fellow man, Senator Puplick, like yourself deep down, a man of decency and love of his fellow man-even the historic figure of Richard III, whom the honourable senator so valiantly defended this morning in the paper.

SPEECH.PARA: The May economic statement is yet another step in the direction towards economic health that the Government has pursued. It has floated the dollar and instituted tax reforms; it has encouraged research and development; it has imposed taxes where hopefully they can best be borne. In some cases, the May economic statement makes it harder to obtain social security payments, and it is well to consider that at this point. People who rort the system deserve to be caught and dealt with, but in accepting that principle, it is well to remember that the vast majority of social security recipients need the payments they receive under that scheme in order to live. There is a lot of tragedy, poverty and hardship in the community, and when parliamentarians talk about the need to be tough, we should remember that fact.

At times people refer to the social security system as a bonanza. One must remember that the payment for a sickness benefit is a little more than $100 a week. How luxurious a life can one live on that amount? The statement abolishes the family allowance for children resident outside Australia, and no one would cavil at that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Vietnamese families maintaining their children who are still in Vietnam?

—That is a good point and an exception that should be looked at. Legislation must embrace a broad statement. On the one hand, there are Vietnamese children and, on the other hand, there are children of European families who could very well be here but who are not here and who are being supported by Australia over there. That point must be taken into consideration. Like all things, it is a matter of balance. Taking the children who may be spread across the world, it is a matter that can be raised, but, on the whole, it can be accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: The income testing of family allowances can also be accepted. The sum of $50,000 is substantial and there is an allowance of $2,500 in respect of each child after the first which can be added to that sum before the benefit is affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the single bloke on $50,000? He pays the same tax as the family man.
—Certainly, there will be people in the community who are better off than others, and that must be accepted.
—You are treating children as luxuries.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—Of course we are not treating children as luxuries. The Government is simply stating that at a particular level of income, people should be able to support their children. Some of us are blessed with children who we enjoy no end; the little treasures are just that. The assets test is now to apply to unemployment and sickness benefits, invalid pensions and so on. It may cause hardship in some particular cases, but the broad principle is reasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: More efficient procedures have been adopted for reviewing pensions. If people are ripping off the system, they deserve to be investigated. However, the problem with investigation is that it can sometimes impinge harshly on honest people who, nevertheless, are subject to the scrutiny that has been devised for those who are not honest. That fact must be remembered when people are investigating pensions. Some categories of pensions have been reduced and some people currently receiving widow's pensions will have to go on unemployment benefits. When one considers the ages of the people involved, one can see an argument for those provisions.

The provision of unemployment benefits for young people aged 16 and 17 years has been cut out and a job search allowance has been provided. If in fact jobs are available-and Senator Jessop says that they are-and they can be filled by these people, that is all well and good. However, Senator Jessop said that there is many a job around that is not filled. He talked about people cleaning windows, and perhaps he could have gone on to say that there are ditches to fill. I think that in regard to employment we must remember this: Clearly, there are less jobs than there are people to fill them. It is very easy to say that this person can get a job or that person can get a job. I want to say a couple of things about that. First, many of those jobs are subject to employers who are harsh and unreasonable. I think it is important when we are talking--

TALK.START.PARA: —Cleaning windows?

—Senator Walters laughs, and I take it from that that she means to say that every employer in Australia is blessed, as it were, with a divine ability to be just, proper and reasonable; that employers are the one class of people who can properly define and state what jobs ought to be, what people ought to get paid and how they ought to be treated. I think that very statement indicates how absurd such a proposition is. All I am saying is this: When we talk about unemployment and about jobs that might be available, we ought to look not simply at the bare statement that a window cleaning job or a job filling ditches is available but at the circumstances under which those jobs might be given. The second thing that I want to say about that proposition is that the statement that one can get a job cleaning cars, cleaning windows or mending roads presumes that the generation of employment is simply a matter of creating jobs at any given level, but the reality is that to get out of its problems Australia needs jobs that can be and will be filled by sophisticated and educated people. Japan and West Germany, for example, whose economies have developed and continue to develop well, have a very high class of citizen-high class in the sense of people being educated and able to cope with the technology that is needed to advance in this world. It is at that level that we ought to look.
—Why have you cut research grants at the CSIRO in this mini-Budget?

—Of course what we have done is allowed a 150 per cent tax deduction on those going into research and development. But Senator Puplick will not get an argument from me about the necessity for research and development, as that is what I advocate. It is at that sort of level that this debate ought to be directed rather than having, as has occurred up until now, speaker after speaker talking in terms of economic policies and fiscals this and fiscals that, as well as monetary policy here and monetary policy there. That is not what we should be on about. We should be concentrating on directing industry and jobs in this country towards a more technological orientation. I do not think that we are doing enough of that. I do not think that we will solve our problems simply by reducing wages and sending off everybody who leaves school to clear ditches or clean out the spoutings at home and polish the brass door knob.
—That is how you get to be a Minister.
—There are a few people in the Gilbert and Sullivan works who have got places by polishing up the--
—Handle of the big front door!
—That is the one; I thank the honourable senator very much.
—Who was it?
—I will have to admit defeat following that penetrating question from the honourable senator opposite. I remember seeing HMS Pinafore at Xavier College one night, but I forgot--
—It was Sir Joseph Porter, KCB.

—But he was an exception; I do not think that many people would get too far by polishing up brass handles. When we debate economic matters, as we do constantly in this place, it seems to me that we confine ourselves too much in terms of simply pulling strings, as it were, and saying that if we allow a certain balance to blow out or if we draw this one in or if we send various people out to work on the roads and simply adjust in some sort of mechanical way the various elements that make up the economy, somehow all will be right. It is just the wrong way of looking at it. If we are looking at the question of the capital that we need, we must realise that what we need is human capital; people who can get out and struggle with the needs of the modern world, produce the sorts of goods that will sell overseas. Hopefully in solving our economic problems perhaps we will bring about a society which is not only economically sound but which is compassionate. That is the sort of word that one does not hear in these debates any more.
—What absolute nonsense!
—When did Senator Short last use the word `compassionate', as distinct from regaling this Government's economic policies?
—About four hours ago.

—I apologise if he did, and certainly if that is right I will have that text-if it has sympathy for his fellow man, his fellow worker, his fellow unionist and things like that-blown up and put on my board, held up with golden pins. So, I am looking forward to seeing those remarks. But really, in the context of this debate-and I do not want to continue on--
—I want you to-I don't want Senator Walters!

—Senator Walters was a nurse, Senator Tate. Deep down Senator Walters is a compassionate, loving human being, and I will not hear anybody saying anything against her. Other senators have said harsh things but Senator Walters has defended the State of Tasmania and has defended her Party, and I think there is great capacity for love and devotion in Senator Walters's heart, which I think we all ought to promptly pay heed to.
—Senator Grimes used to say as much.
—Yes, he speaks highly of her.
—Order! I think we should get back to the debate.

—I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. I shall refer to one other matter before I sit down. The matter of industrial relations has been referred to, and in this context I think it is important to remember that industrial relations is aimed at getting a harmonious industrial system going, as without a harmonious system we will not get anywhere. Harmony will not be achieved if people constantly attack one side of the equation, namely, the employees represented by their unions. Quite clearly, the workers of this country have taken a cut in wages over the past few years and profits have gone up-and that is a good thing, particularly if they are invested-but when call after call is made for greater cuts it becomes a matter of just how sincere and how credible those sorts of calls are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perhaps symbolic for those of us who, as Senator Cooney has noted, are historians by training that the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) `1987-88 Budget Initial Measures, May 1987' was delivered on 13 May 1987. In fact that was the 200th anniversary of the date on which the First Fleet set sail from Portsmouth. For the average family there was in this mini-Budget statement about as much hope and as much faith in the future as there was for the average passenger on that First Fleet. It is perhaps equally symbolic that the re-enactment of the journey of that First Fleet was only out of Portsmouth for two days before it had to return to port and start the journey all over again. This Government will be required to return to port and start its economic journey all over again because, fundamentally, it has got the economic equation completely wrong, and completely in reverse. Since Mr Keating has been the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia there have been wage increases for the average family in Australia of approximately $119. However the real increase in wages, allowing for inflation, has been only $9. Offset against that, the average family in Australia has had to pay $37 a week more in tax under this Government, $26 a week more in mortgage repayments, $4.70 more in health insurance costs and some 60 per cent of Australian families have kept their private health insurance intact because of this Government's deliberate and mendacious running down of the health system under its Medicare scheme. On an overall basis, the average tax for the family unit in Australia has risen from 17.5c to 20.5c in the dollar. In other words, under this Government in the course of the past four years, as we have repeatedly said on this side of the chamber, the living standards of ordinary Australian families have fallen.

SPEECH.PARA: Offset against that has been one of the most massive deceptions perpetuated by any government in its estimates of revenue raising. When Mr Keating introduced the capital gains tax he told us that initially it would raise $5m in its first year of operation. This would rise to $25m in its fifth year of operation. We now know that this tax will raise between $125m and $175m in its first year of operation. Within the Government's economic strategy there has been a deliberate downplaying of the impact that its policies have had on the welfare of the average family and a deliberate downplaying of the effect which its revenue raising new taxes have had across the Australian community in general.

This mini-Budget statement is a thimble and pea trick. Of the alleged $1.6 billion of restraint on the Commonwealth's own expenditure, $900m consists simply of deferrals, changes in timing and alleged efficiency savings. Less than half of the real expenditure restraint is actual restraint or reduction of costs. Interestingly, only four cuts out of the 80 in the statement will raise more than $100m and two of these are particularly large deferrals. Only 20 cuts are larger than $50m and few programs have actually been abolished which is the only real way to get massive expenditure restraint. This mini-Budget will not last the distance. I predict that it will not last beyond July, which is why we are now awash in this place and in the media generally with speculation about an early election. The mini-Budget will not hold together as a result of the wages blowout which takes place and which will continue to take place as a result of the two-tier wage fixation system, which this Government has sought to put into place. In the Weekend Australian of 16 and 17 May, David Potts, the economic editor, characterised the mini-Budget in the following terms:
Where did the $6 billion come from?-
he is talking about the deficit-
How did the deficit grow from $3.5 billion this year to $6 billion next year? Why weren't we told? Because this Government is more about taxing than axing.

That is a correct summary of the economic policy which this Government has pursued. There is no doubt that in one or two fields the Commonwealth has been correct in attempting to impose some degree of expenditure restraint. One of the areas in which I believe that expenditure restraint is properly applied is in relation to the grants to the States. The States have built up about $9 billion worth of assets in various hollow logs around the place and I believe that they should properly be required to disgorge this money in order to help meet the necessary restraint at Commonwealth, State and local government level. I do not believe that the cuts imposed upon the States have been unfair, nor do I believe that the States are incapable of shouldering those burdens without resorting to increased State taxes and charges which they will seek to impose as a way to avoid facing up to their own fiscal responsibilities.

I wish to point to one or two specific matters arising from the mini-Budget. I am particularly pleased that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is now in the chamber because a number of matters to which I wish to refer touch upon his responsibilities, either as the Minister responsible or as the representative Minister in this chamber. When we come to the debate on the sales tax legislation, I will have a great deal more to say about the imposition of the $400 limit on travellers' duty free concessions. I raise this matter at this stage only to indicate that the impact of that fairly small decision will be significant. It will have three effects. First, it will divert the resources of the Customs department away from the proper policing of its narcotics responsibilities into revenue raising for small scale items relating to the Australian tourist trade. Secondly, it clearly sets at nought the expert recommendations put to the Government by the Industries Assistance Commission in its analysis of passenger concessions. Thirdly, it is another significant blow against the operation of entrepreneurial small businesses in Australia and indicates the sorts of targets that this Government is prepared to identify. I will return in a moment to the question of the targets, the people who really suffer as a result of this Government's mini-Budget.

Another example of this is the decision which is made on Film Australia in the mini-Budget. This is described in a fairly specious way in the Budget statement. Here is an institution, so we are told, which will save the Commonwealth $1.3m by being restructured. We are not actually told how it will be restructured; we know that there has been an inquiry into Film Australia which provided the Government with four options about the restructuring. The Government has not actually responded to that inquiry but has simply said that it will take some steps and that it will save $1.3m in the process. However, on page 44 of its own statement, the Government admits that the restructuring will mean a once only redundancy cost of up to $1.4m to provide redundancy payments to staff within Film Australia. Therefore, it is not a saving of $1.3m, it is in fact a cost of $100,000 and we do not know the Government's projections for the work of Film Australia in future years.

There is one point in the statement for which I must give credit where credit is due and that is in the funding provided for the acquired immune deficiency syndrome treatment and education programs. An extra $2m has been earmarked for that. However, I do not think that this Government has yet faced up to the dimension of the public health crisis which it faces in terms of the economic cost for AIDS. Just last month the Age newspaper estimated that Victoria would be spending more than $30m a year treating AIDS patients by 1990. That cost will be well in excess of that figure in NSW which I have the honour to represent. There is no comprehension demonstrated in any of the Government's forward commitments and forward planning on health expenditure to accommodate the sort of price tag estimated as a result of this particular public health crisis. Dr Bruce Whyte, one of the AIDS medical experts, has estimated that AIDS will cost Australia $750m a year in lost earnings and hospital and medical care by 1991. Nobody in this Parliament will cavil at having to provide that money. Nobody in this Parliament will seek to avoid the expenditure which will be necessary for people who are suffering from AIDS. Yet this Government, in the way in which it has addressed the forward planning in the health portfolio, shows no indication that it is seized with the economic significance of this matter. An additional $1m has been provided in the statement for the funding of a pilot study for the AIDS treatment using the drug AZT, but we have recent estimates that individual patient treatments with AZT will cost between $10,000 and $15,000 a year, and we know that we will be looking at several hundred cases. Dr Whyte, whom I previously mentioned, indicated that he expected that about 3,000 people by the end of 1990 would be in category A as far as their AIDS health status is concerned. Again the Government shows no clear indication that it is planning for a blow-out within the Department of Health expenditure of that sort of measure.

I turn finally to address the question of the cuts that have been made in an area which may look very small to this Government and which picks up a point that Senator Cooney was making a few minutes ago about investment in this country's future and about the levels of skill within the Australian work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about TAFE.

—My colleague Senator Peter Baume says: `Tell us about TAFE'. I was about to mention the enormous reductions in expenditure which are being made for colleges of technical and further education throughout this mini-Budget statement. There is to be a reduction in general recurrent grants for TAFE in 1988-89 amounting to $45m. This is in an area where the improvement and the upgrading of skills, particularly technical skills, in Australia is of critical importance. Yet here is $45m to be taken out of the TAFE system and to be saved, so-called, on the basis of fairly short term gains.

SPEECH.PARA: Page 51 of the printed statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) shows a reduction of $1m in the Australian research grants scheme by reducing the number of new grants which are to be awarded under the ARGS and related grants systems. I look at the fact that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is to have imposed upon it a cut in 1988-89 amounting to $15m. When one looks at cuts in the TAFE sector, cuts in the ARGS arrangements and cuts in the CSIRO one is clearly seized with the prospect of cutting into the development of skills in Australia which are absolutely fundamental and absolutely vital to the revitalisation of our economic well-being whether it happens to be in the manufacturing industry or in any of those industries which are related to increased productivity through increased skill in the work force.

Only today an article appeared in the Age headed `PhD decline puts industry at risk: report', which made it quite clear that the failure to train enough skilled engineers and people with higher degrees in the engineering and science faculties of our universities is now getting to the stage that it is very clearly cutting into the capacity of Australian industry to take advantage of those niches and those windows of opportunity which are opening up for areas which need advanced skills. One looks, for instance, at the recent reports about the development of superconductors. I am sure my friend and colleague Senator Vigor has been following this as avidly as I have. Here is an area in which Australia can certainly take some part of what is probably one of the most exciting technological and scientific discoveries of recent years. It will take advantage of that by our development not only of the computing and engineering skills in Australia but also equally in terms of the development of our mineral sands industry, in terms of the production of yttrium and the production of the rare earths which Australia possesses in abundance and which will be absolutely necessary as the fundamental ceramic building blocks of the superconductor system. Superconductors of the future will revolutionise the way in which we do business and the way in which the economy grows and develops. Yet, without engineers, without trained scientists and without PhDs with skills in engineering and science, we will not be in a position to take advantage of either the mineral extractive side of things or indeed the superconductor research side of things because of the sorts of cuts which this Government is imposing.

I know that our time is pressed this evening, and I am anxious to provide my colleague Senator Walters with the opportunity to make some contribution to this debate. I will conclude quite simply by drawing attention to the number of lost opportunities which exist within this mini-Budget statement-the opportunity which could have been taken, given the recent near 40 per cent reduction in trade weighted depreciation of the dollar to cut protection levels, something which was not done with this mini-Budget but which we could have done.

This mini-Budget has imposed an undue burden upon the poor, the young, those seeking to improve their skills, those who are already disadvantaged, those who are weak and those who are not well organised. In doing so, it has failed a series of fundamental and elemental tests about making an investment in Australia's future. It is why this mini-Budget will fail. It is why this Government is now reinvigorating the debate about an early election in order to have the opportunity to cover up for its failures, its lost opportunities and its betrayal of the proper interests of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no better way in which I can open my part of the debate on the May economic statement than to quote Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance. Last year at one of the Australian Labor Party conferences he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I know some people believe that budget deficits don't matter. They do matter in the degree to which they lock in future expenditure. If we had a public debt interest payment, the same level of outlays as it was in 1982-
I interpose here to say that that was the last Budget of the Fraser Government-

we would in this financial year have about $4 billion extra to either cut taxes, increase welfare spending or whatever else you wanted to do with it. But because we have run a sequence of high budget deficits, we are lumbered with a crippling public debt interest payment which restricts the ability of this Government and Governments for the foreseeable future, to deliver the programs they would like to deliver elsewhere.

That is what the Finance Minister said last year. He admitted that the $4 billion was a result of his Government's having high Budget deficits which have caused the need for this mini-Budget. When Premier Cain complained at the Premiers Conference this week that the Government was behaving like the builders labourers in not keeping its promises made to the Premiers Conference last year, Mr Keating said that that was a result of the world not keeping its promises to Australia. It was not a result of the world not keeping promises to Australia, as Senator Walsh has said; it was a result of the Government having run a sequence of high Budget deficits since 1982. We have been told by Mr Keating that the Government has cut costs by $4 billion. Let us look at what that means. Like any bankrupt business, the Government is having an auction sale of its assets. Of the $4 billion, $1 billion-a quarter of that $4 billion-will be saved by selling, for instance, the Williamstown dockyard.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you agree with that. You would like to sell a few more.

—Is Senator Georges going to buy the Williamstown dockyard? Who would want the Williamstown dockyard? Who will pay for it? The Government will also sell all the international airport terminals. Who will buy them? It will be a very interesting auction. Defence enterprises and major assets, Commonwealth Government centres in Sydney and Melbourne, shareholdings in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, part of the Australian Embassy site in Tokyo and the former ambassadorial residence in Paris are the sorts of assets which the Government will auction. However, they are one off sales; the assets cannot be sold again next year and this measure will not help the deficit next year. So the proceeds from the auction will amount to a quarter of the so-called Budget cuts. It is not a cut at all; it is an auction sale.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go further and look at the taxes that this Government will raise. They are not cuts either. This Government is increasing taxes just as it has done ever since it has come to power. It has increased sales taxes and customs duties and dreamed up a fuel rebate scheme. As a result of these taxes, Telecom Australia and Australia Post have already decided to put up their charges; they have already put in their bid. That accounts for about half a billion dollars. So one and a half billion dollars are not cuts at all. One measure is an auction sale and the other is tax increases.

There is no doubt that the proposed increases in charges by Telecom and Australia Post will increase the inflation rate. We are now down to $2 1/2 billion of supposed cuts. The Government has taken $1 billion off the States. Were these hard decisions for the Federal Government to make? Not on your life. It has asked the States to make the hard decisions. However, the States will only increase their charges and that will again increase the inflation rate. So that amounts to an additional $2 1/2 billion worth of so-called cuts that the Federal Government has not made. It will have auction sales, cuts will be forced on the States and taxes will be raised. That leaves just over $1 1/2 billion of actual Federal cuts. Ross Gittins said most appropriately in the Sydney Morning Herald, this has been a rather rubbery axe. Who has the Government made bear the costs of these cuts? The majority of the cuts will fall on the students, the families and the poor of Australia.

The Opposition has been told that it has not mentioned compassion. I would be most interested to hear Senator Georges on this matter because surely to heavens the Government should have some compassion for the poor and the families of Australia. It has shown absolutely none in the mini-Budget. Most of the cuts will occur in about December this year or January next year so I do not know why the Government has brought down this mini-Budget. It could have brought in these measures in the August Budget-the measures will not be applicable until after then. The family allowance cuts will not start until October.

What has happened to families under this Government? We have only to compare the performance of this Government regarding families with that of the Fraser Government. It is very clear that when Fraser came to government there was a steady, gradual increase in family disposable income from an average of $297.90 a week to $316. That figure has dropped. It went from $316.80 to $302.92 a week in constant dollar figures. Disposable income has decreased and the family allowance has decreased. Family allowance is no longer payable for dependent children 16 years and over; parents are no longer entitled to it. We are now told that the family allowance will be means tested. Family allowance was never a welfare payment; it has always been an acknowledgment of the fact that families with children have greater costs than do those without children. We have been told cynically by the Government that we should not worry, the $50,000 family income group will have tax cuts. What about the families on $50,000 without children? They will be getting the tax cuts too but the families with children will not have the offset of receiving the family allowance. It is an absolute disgrace that the Government has introduced the means testing of the family allowance. It is not a social welfare payment; it is an acknowledgment of the fact that families with children bear greater costs than do those without children.

However, the Government does not stop there; it has attacked the class B widows. This measure was hidden by the Treasurer under the heading `Phase Out Class B Widow's Pension'. It was not in his speech; it was hidden in the small print in his statement. Widows, who perhaps have been out of the work force for 20 or 25 years looking after their families, who suddenly lose their husband and at the age of 45 or 50, instead of being given a widow's pension because they do not have any work skills-they lost all of their work skills during the years when they looked after their family-will suddenly be put on the unemployment benefit. They will not get a widow's pension; they will be sent weekly to the Commonwealth Employment Service to see whether they can get a job. What sort of a job will they be fit for? They will be fit for no more than cleaning someone else's home, and that is a disgrace. The Government is supposed to be interested in women. It is no more interested in women than any other Labor government has ever been. This is an appalling injustice to class B widows and it is perhaps the most vicious of all of the Government's cuts.

The other area in which families have been affected is in health costs. Again, due to the ideology of the Government and the socialisation of health care-Dr Deeble made this only too clear in his statements-bulk billing will not be cut. We will still have bulk billing. That is where the Government could save lots of money if it wanted to but its ideology will not allow it to do that. Dr Deeble has already told us that there is no way other than the socialisation of medicine. He said it is a first step. There is no doubt that the medical profession as a whole will eventually be socialised under this Government. But rather than face the proper cuts of abolishing bulk billing for everyone, the Government has decided to attack, yet again, those who are privately insured. They will have to pay for their hospitalisation not only twice but also double. Firstly, private patients pay for the public hospital system which they do not use and when they pay for a private hospital system that they do use they will then be made to pay 10 per cent more. They will no longer get 85 per cent of the schedule fee for their medical costs in a private hospital; they will get only 75 per cent. As I have pointed out, only $1 1/2 billion out of the $4 billion of cuts announced in the May statement are real Government cuts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Health aware that scientific research has shown that people-particularly children-who are constantly exposed to high noise levels-about 45 decibels-have a slower learning capacity.

(2) Has the Minister's Department or any other organisation conducted a feasibility study into the adoption of a national noise abatement policy such as those that have been adopted by a number of European countries, given these findings; if so, what were the major findings of this feasibility study; if not, will the Minister instruct his Department to undertake such a feasibility study with a view to the government, in consultation with the States, adopting such a policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that accumulated research over the past 15 years has indicated that continued exposure to noise in the home and classroom may impede cognitive and language development in infants and reading performance and other learning deficits in older children. Some of the noise levels encountered in this research are quite high and I am advised that it is difficult to put a figure on the lowest noise level that can produce these deficits.

However, noise levels equal to or greater than 45 decibels can interfere with the hearing of speech delivered with normal vocal effort at a distance of 10 metres. For this reason alone I am advised that it is desirable for extraneous noise in classrooms and dwellings to be kept below this level during daylight hours. Evening and night-time, and background noise levels should, ideally, be even lower.
(2) No. However, I am advised that much has been done relevant to such a policy.

Committees reporting to the Australian Environment Council are aiming to produce a national approach to the control of general traffic noise. Restrictions already apply to aircraft noise. Standards Association of Australia standards are available in relation to construction and industrial noise and attention is being given to methods of uniformly assessing community noise.

Acts and Regulations are in force in all States for the control of occupational noise and its effects on hearing. Currently the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission in collaboration with other agencies, including the National Acoustic Laboratories in my Department, is developing a national policy in respect of occupational noise control.

I will certainly ask my Department to examine the feasibility of incorporating the diversity of noise types and sources, of abatement strategies and of responsible jurisdictions within a single national policy in noise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 26 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What evidence does the Government have of the incidence in Australia, on a state by state basis, of surgery to remove, infibulate or otherwise alter the external genitalia of women in a manner consistent with the documented cultural practices of a number of African and Middle Eastern nations, on the basis of claims made under the Medicare Medical Benefits Schedule since 1980.

(2) Is any medical (as distinct from, for example, cultural) justification required to be given by the surgeon; if so what reasons were given in what proportion of cases, where Medicare claims were made for such procedures.
(3) What was the breakdown by age of the women upon whom these procedures were performed.
(4) Are any other indications (besides the incidence of Medicare claims) available to the government of the prevalence of these practices in Australia.

(5) What action has the Federal Government taken or will it take to examine the occurrence of and to prohibit the performance of mutilation of female genitals by surgery, except in carefully identified cases of medical necessity, in the public and private health sectors and in the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Two Items of the Medicare Benefits Schedule relate to surgery to the female genitals-Item 6299: amputation of the clitoris; and Item 6302: vulvectomy, vulviplasty or labioplasty. The major medical indication for such surgery is the treatment of cancer or the correction of congenital deformity. Both these Items carry the qualification ``where medically indicated''-that is, there is no entitlement to claim Benefits if the surgery is not medically indicated.

The qualification ``where medically indicated'' was included in the Schedule on 1 July 1985, specifically to address the issue of ritual female circumcision. Since that time there has been no variation in the incidence of claims made-for example, for the calendar years 1983, 1984 and 1985 the incidence of claims made for Item 6299 was 11, 12 and 13, respectively. Therefore, claims made under the Medicare Benefits Schedule do not provide any evidence of the incidence of ritual female circumcision in Australia.

(2) Notwithstanding that the existence of a Medicare Benefits Schedule Item has not encouraged or promoted the practice of female circumcision, I have arranged for the Health Insurance Commission to ensure that appropriate medical indications apply before Medicare Benefits are paid.
While this will not in itself diminish the practice, it will ensure that the cost of ritual female circumcision is not underwritten through the Medicare Benefits Schedule.
(3) An examination of the age breakdown of women upon whom these procedures were performed was carried out for the September quarter of 1986, with the following results:
Item 6299: Amputation of the clitoris-no claims were made for patients under the age of 35 years.
Item 6302: Vulvectomy, vulvoplasty or labioplasty-no claims were made for patients under the age of 10 years. The majority of claims were for patients aged 30 to 50.
This age breakdown is consistent with the medical indications for such surgery-that is, treatment of cancer and correction of congenital deformity.

(4) From time to time I and my Department have received representations concerning female genital mutilation practices, and attempts have been made to obtain as much information as possible about the situation in Australia. Attempts to elicit documented details from health authorities, general practitioners and interest groups have, however, not been successful. Much of the information concerning circumcision of female children is anecdotal. There is, for example, no record of children or women presenting to health services with any of the common complications of the more severe forms of ritual circumcision.

(5) The issues involved are complex and sensitive and, I believe, relate fundamentally to questions of child abuse. It is the view of Australian health authorities that steps should be taken to discourage the practice through a low key educational approach. The most appropriate avenue for such an approach is seen to be through health care providers and relevant community and religious groups. Primarily, of course, the matter is one for consideration by the States.

Apart from education and persuasion, any preventive action by way of deterrence through prohibition would need to be taken through child welfare and/or criminal law authorities at State level. Such action should be on the basis of well considered strategies that take account of practicalities involved and any limitations that exist as regards the State's responsibilities for the welfare and protection of its residents.

A sensitive approach needs to be taken to this issue in view of the undesirability-in Australia's multicultural society-of blanket condemnation of another culture's traditions and practices, particularly where symbolic forms of circumcision involving no long term physical effects are concerned.

The World Health Organisation reiterated in 1986 that change should not come from outside campaigners but from within communities where female circumcision is still entrenched. In Australia, health and welfare authorities in several States are developing policies and programs to assist the process of change within their communities.
For its part, my Department will continue to monitor the situation regarding the practice of ritual female circumcision in Australia.
