TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1987 (Hansard, page 592), Senator Robert Ray asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister representing the Minister for Communications give an assurance that when the 26 new licences for regional commercial radio stations are issued these licences will be given to applicants who have no other television or newspaper ownership or interests.

Honourable senators will recall that when answering this question on 25 February 1987, I replied that I thought that the policy was still to be considered and finalised, but that I would seek advice on this matter. The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In his Press Release of 27 November 1986, concerning new ownership rules for television ownership, the Minister for Communications said that the Government had decided, in principle, to regulate cross-ownership of media in Australia. Such regulation would prevent a person from holding a prescribed interest in a television licence to serve an area in which that person owns a licence for a monopoly commercial radio station or where a daily newspaper owned by that person has the bulk of its circulation.

In his statement of 24 February 1987, announcing the Government's decisions on additional commercial radio services in regional areas (covering the 26 new services referred to by Senator Ray) the Minister said that possible modifications to the ownership and control rules in radio will be taken up as part of the current study of ownership and control, particularly cross-media matters, being undertaken in his Department.

The initial legislation, covering cross media ownership of television in relation to radio and newspapers was introduced in Parliament on 29 April 1987. Another package of legislation, on these matters will follow in the Budget session.

It should be noted that Section 83 of the Broadcasting Act currently directs the ABT to have regard to the need to avoid undue concentration of influence within a non-metropolitan service area, when considering whether it is in the public interest to refuse to grant a licence to an applicant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 March 1987 (Hansard, page 1118), Senator Brownhill asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: In light of Telecom Australia's annual profit of $465m for 1985-86, and increase of $80m over the figure for the previous year, I ask: What justification has Telecom for making changes to charging times, especially the delaying of the cheap night rate until 10 p.m.? Considering that most people regard 10 p.m. as being far too late to contact anyone, why was this alteration made? How does this charge balance with Telecom's corporate objectives to provide services at an affordable rate and, wherever possible, to pass on savings to customers?

Honourable senators will recall that when answering this question on 23 March 1987 I undertook to confirm the reason for Telecom varying the commencement of the STD economy rate from 9 p.m. to 10 p.m. The Minister for Communications has provided the following information, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

The provision of cheaper off-peak rates for calls at various times is designed to encourage people to make calls during those hours when trunk lines are not fully utilized, thereby making better use of the network.

Virtually from its inception, demand for the economy rate exceeded the capacity of the trunk network on most routes between 9 p.m. and 9.30 p.m. This resulted in severe network congestion on a national basis and a general degradation of service during that period. In order to reduce this level of congestion on the national network, it was decided to delay the introduction of the economy rate by one hour.

If Telecom were to re-dimension the network to cater for peak periods occurring outside business hours, such as between 9 p.m. and 9.30 p.m., then a large amount of equipment would remain under-utilised for the majority of the day and night. The cost of this additional equipment would have to be recovered by increased rentals or call charges.

To compensate for the one hour delay, Telecom has extended the economy rate to Sundays between the hours of 8 a.m. and 10 p.m. This change gives customers affected by the one hour economy rate delay the opportunity to make calls any time between 10 p.m. Saturday and 8 a.m. Monday at the economy rate. It is also of note that the night rate (between 66-75% of the day rate tariff) still applies to calls between 6 p.m. and 10 p.m. Monday to Saturday and represents a real saving to customers.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Exports to United States of America

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1987 (Hansard, page 2397), Senator Crichton-Browne asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade, a question without notice relating to Bills introduced to the United States House of Representatives and the United States Senate designed to prohibit the importation into the United States of products from Australia including uranium, beef, lamb and wool. He specifically asked what steps were being taken by the Government to provide the United States Senate and House of Representatives with information on the implications of the Bills not only for the United States but also for Australia. He also asked what steps were being taken by the Australian Government to defeat the proposed legislation. The Acting Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Symms (Republican, Idaho) has introduced a Bill in the United States Senate (S980) that would prohibit the import of uranium, beef, lamb and wool from Australia and New Zealand.

Identical legislation has also been introduced in the United States House of Representatives by Congressman Craig (Republican, Idaho). The sponsors of the Bills have sought to justify the legislation on the grounds that ``the Government of Australia refuses to allow the use of its bases by United States aircraft in monitoring strategic missile tests''.

The Australian Embassy in Washington has made strong representations to both Congressmen opposing their Bills. In these representations it was pointed out that the alleged rationale for the Bills was incorrect and that it was a decision by the United States authorities not to use Australian support facilities for monitoring MX missile tests. In addition the defence relationship between Australia and the United States continues on a very sound and co-operative basis. This was evidenced by the 1986 San Francisco communique following the meeting there of the Australia/United States Ministerial Talks.

The Congressmen have been reminded that the trade balance between Australia and the United States is running two to one in favour of the United States and their proposal to cut imports from Australia for some of our key products would naturally adversely affect our ability to pay for imports from the United States and elsewhere.

More generally it was put to the Congressmen that their proposals would seriously damage trade relations between Australia and the United States. They should recognise that their Bills, when taken together with all the other trade difficulties we are having with the United States, could provoke a strong backlash in Australia against the United States.

While we shall continue monitoring the situation very closely, support for the Bills from the House and Senate leadership and from the relevant Congressional Committee does not seem to be growing. The Bills are also opposed by the US Administration.
Mr Dawkins intends raising this and other issues with Congressional Leaders and Administration Officials when he visits Washington later this month.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: United States of America: Agricultural Protection

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 May 1987 (Hansard, page 2634), Senator Collard asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. An assessment of the costs associated with US policies is being incorporated in these studies. To date most of the Bureau's attention has been directed toward grains and sugar.
